paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the KING, Lord John of LANCASTER, Earl of WESTMORELAND, with others$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: The KING, Lord John of LANCASTER, the Earl of WESTMORELAND, and others enter.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$So shaken as we are, so wan with care,$NEWLINE$Find we a time for frighted peace to pant$NEWLINE$And breathe short-winded accents of new broils$NEWLINE$To be commenced in strands afar remote.$NEWLINE$No more the thirsty entrance of this soil$NEWLINE$Shall daub her lips with her own children’s blood.$NEWLINE$Nor more shall trenching war channel her fields,$NEWLINE$Nor bruise her flow’rets with the armed hoofs$NEWLINE$Of hostile paces. Those opposèd eyes,$NEWLINE$Which, like the meteors of a troubled heaven,$NEWLINE$All of one nature, of one substance bred,$NEWLINE$Did lately meet in the intestine shock$NEWLINE$And furious close of civil butchery$NEWLINE$Shall now, in mutual well-beseeming ranks,$NEWLINE$March all one way and be no more opposed$NEWLINE$Against acquaintance, kindred, and allies.$NEWLINE$The edge of war, like an ill-sheathèd knife,$NEWLINE$No more shall cut his master. Therefore, friends,$NEWLINE$As far as to the sepulcher of Christ—$NEWLINE$Whose soldier now, under whose blessed cross$NEWLINE$We are impressèd and engaged to fight—$NEWLINE$Forthwith a power of English shall we levy,$NEWLINE$Whose arms were molded in their mothers' womb$NEWLINE$To chase these pagans in those holy fields$NEWLINE$Over whose acres walked those blessèd feet$NEWLINE$Which fourteen hundred years ago were nailed$NEWLINE$For our advantage on the bitter cross.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Despite how shaken and pale with worry we are, let’s take advantage of this moment of peace to catch our breath, and as we pant we’ll speak about the battles we’ll soon fight in foreign lands. England will no longer be wet with her own people’s blood. War will no longer damage her fields, and warhorses will no longer trample her flowers. The soldiers on either side of this vicious civil war were countrymen and brothers, as similar to one another as shooting stars. They may have clashed recently, but now they will march together in beautiful formation, no longer struggling against family and friend. War is like a mishandled knife: it can cut its owner, but it will no longer cut us. My friends, we are now soldiers for Christ, and we take his blessed cross as our battle flag. We’ll raise a new army of Englishmen and march all the way to the Holy Land. Our soldiers were born to chase non-believers from that holy ground touched by Jesus' feet—feet which, fourteen hundred years ago, were nailed to the cross for our sins.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: But this our purpose now is twelve month old,$NEWLINE$And bootless ’tis to tell you we will go.$NEWLINE$Therefor we meet not now. Then let me hear$NEWLINE$Of you, my gentle cousin Westmoreland,$NEWLINE$What yesternight our council did decree$NEWLINE$In forwarding this dear expedience.
paragraphs.translated: But that’s been my plan for a year now, so there’s no point in telling you all this again. That’s not the issue at hand. So tell me, my noble kinsman Westmoreland, what my royal advisors decided last night about this important undertaking.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$My liege, this haste was hot in question,$NEWLINE$And many limits of the charge set down$NEWLINE$But yesternight: when all athwart there came$NEWLINE$A post from Wales loaden with heavy news,$NEWLINE$Whose worst was that the noble Mortimer,$NEWLINE$Leading the men of Herefordshire to fight$NEWLINE$Against the irregular and wild Glendower,$NEWLINE$Was by the rude hands of that Welshman taken,$NEWLINE$A thousand of his people butcherèd,$NEWLINE$Upon whose dead corpse there was such misuse,$NEWLINE$Such beastly shameless transformation$NEWLINE$By those Welshwomen done, as may not be$NEWLINE$Without much shame retold or spoken of.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Your Highness, there was hot debate about this urgent mission, and many responsibilities had just been assigned when we were suddenly cut off by a messenger with bad news from Wales. The worst of it was that the noble Mortimer, who was leading the men of Herefordshire in battle against that barbarian Glendower, was captured. A thousand of his men have been butchered, their dead corpses desecrated by the Welsh women. The things they did were so horrible that I’m too ashamed to report them.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$It seems then that the tidings of this broil$NEWLINE$Brake off our business for the Holy Land.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$I suppose this news disrupts our plans to invade the Holy Land.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$This matched with other did, my gracious lord.$NEWLINE$For more uneven and unwelcome news$NEWLINE$Came from the north and thus it did import:$NEWLINE$On Holy-rood Day, the gallant Hotspur there,$NEWLINE$Young Harry Percy, and brave Archibald,$NEWLINE$That ever valiant and approvèd Scot,$NEWLINE$At Holmedon met, where they did spend$NEWLINE$A sad and bloody hour—$NEWLINE$As by discharge of their artillery$NEWLINE$And shape of likelihood the news was told;$NEWLINE$For he that brought them, in the very heat$NEWLINE$And pride of their contention did take horse,$NEWLINE$Uncertain of the issue any way.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$This and other things, your Highness: even more unsettling and unwelcome news has arrived from the north. On Holy Cross Day, the heroic young Harry Percy—who we know as Hotspur—fought at Holmeden against Archibald, Earl of Douglas, that brave and battle-proven Scotsman. The two of them fought a long and bloody battle there, judging by the way the guns were firing. The messenger who brought the news left when the battle was at its height, so he couldn’t say for sure who had won.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Here is a dear, a true-industrious friend,$NEWLINE$Sir Walter Blunt, new lighted from his horse.$NEWLINE$Stained with the variation of each soil$NEWLINE$Betwixt that Holmedon and this seat of ours,$NEWLINE$And he hath brought us smooth and welcome news.$NEWLINE$The Earl of Douglas is discomfited;$NEWLINE$Ten thousand bold Scots, two-and-twenty knights,$NEWLINE$Balked in their own blood, did Sir Walter see$NEWLINE$On Holmedon’s plains. Of prisoners Hotspur took$NEWLINE$Mordake, Earl of Fife, and eldest son$NEWLINE$To beaten Douglas, and the Earl of Atholl,$NEWLINE$Of Murray, Angus, and Menteith.$NEWLINE$And is not this an honorable spoil?$NEWLINE$A gallant prize? Ha, cousin, is it not?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$My loyal, hard-working friend Sir Walter Blunt has arrived here at court, fresh off his horse and covered with the mud of every town from Holmedon to here. He’s brought us very welcome news. The Earl of Douglas has been defeated. Blunt saw ten thousand Scotsmen and twenty-two knights piled up in their own blood on the fields of Holmedon. Hotspur took these men prisoner: Douglas' son Mordake, the Earl of Fife; as well as the Earls of Athol, Murray, Angus, and Menteith. That’s a valuable group! A fantastic catch, isn’t it, kinsman?

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$In faith, it is a conquest for a prince to boast of.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Truly, that’s a conquest to make even a prince brag.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Yea, there thou mak’st me sad, and mak’st me sin$NEWLINE$In envy that my Lord Northumberland$NEWLINE$Should be the father to so blest a son,$NEWLINE$A son who is the theme of Honor’s tongue,$NEWLINE$Amongst a grove the very straightest plant,$NEWLINE$Who is sweet Fortune’s minion and her pride;$NEWLINE$Whilst I, by looking on the praise of him,$NEWLINE$See riot and dishonor stain the brow$NEWLINE$Of my young Harry. O, that it could be proved$NEWLINE$That some night-tripping fairy had exchanged$NEWLINE$In cradle-clothes our children where they lay,$NEWLINE$And called mine “Percy,” his “Plantagenet”!$NEWLINE$Then would I have his Harry, and he mine.$NEWLINE$But let him from my thoughts. What think you, coz,$NEWLINE$Of this young Percy’s pride? The prisoners,$NEWLINE$Which he in this adventure hath surprised$NEWLINE$To his own use he keeps, and sends me word$NEWLINE$I shall have none but Mordake, Earl of Fife.
paragraphs.translated:
KING$NEWLINE$Yes, and that makes me sad. Seeing Lord Northumberland with such a blessed son makes me commit the sin of envy. When honor speaks, it speaks about Hotspur. In a grove of trees, Hotspur stands straightest. He is the favorite darling of Fortune. When I see how he is praised, I can only see my own son, Harry, and his reputation for wildness and dishonor. If only it could be proven that a fairy had come to their cradles at night and switched them! Then the Percy family would have my Harry, and we Plantagenets would have Hotspur! But stop thinking about Harry now. Westmoreland, what do you make of young Percy’s arrogance? He says he’ll keep all the
prisoners he captured for himself, and will only send me Mordrake, Earl of Fife.$NEWLINE$prisoners$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$This is his uncle’s teaching. This is Worcester,$NEWLINE$Malevolent to you in all aspects,$NEWLINE$Which makes him prune himself, and bristle up$NEWLINE$The crest of youth against your dignity.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$His uncle Worcester put him up to that. It is just like Worcester to act against you in all ways. He’s the one making Hotspur behave like this, flaunting his youth in the face of your dignified age.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$But I have sent for him to answer this.$NEWLINE$And for this cause awhile we must neglect$NEWLINE$Our holy purpose to Jerusalem.$NEWLINE$Cousin, on Wednesday next our council we$NEWLINE$Will hold at Windsor. So inform the lords.$NEWLINE$But come yourself with speed to us again,$NEWLINE$For more is to be said and to be done$NEWLINE$Than out of anger can be utterèd.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$I’ve sent for Hotspur to explain himself. We’ll have to postpone the plans for our crusade to Jerusalem. Go tell my advisers that our next meeting will be Wednesday at Windsor. Then hurry back here. There’s more to be said and done, but I’m too angry now to speak.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$I will, my liege.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$I will, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter HENRY, PRINCE of Wales, and Sir John FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$HENRY$NEWLINE$PRINCE$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: HENRY, PRINCE of Wales and Sir John FALSTAFF enter.$NEWLINE$HENRY$NEWLINE$PRINCE$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Now, Hal, what time of day is it, lad?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hal, what time is it, my boy?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Thou art so fat-witted, with drinking of old sack, and unbuttoning thee after supper, and sleeping upon benches after noon, that thou hast forgotten to demand that truly which thou wouldst truly know. What a devil hast thou to do with the time of the day? Unless hours were cups of sack, and minutes capons, and clocks the tongues of bawds, and dials the signs of leaping-houses, and the blessed sun himself a fair hot wench in flame-colored taffeta, I see no reason why thou shouldst be so superfluous to demand the time of the day.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You are so wasted from drinking booze and loosening your pants after lunch and sleeping on benches all afternoon that you don’t even remember how to ask for what you really want to know. What the hell does it matter to you what time it is? Unless hours were glasses of wine, minutes were chickens, clocks were whores' tongues, sundials were whorehouse signs and the sun itself were a hot woman in a flame-colored dress, I don’t see any reason why you would need to know the time.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Indeed, you come near me now, Hal, for we that take purses go by the moon and the seven stars, and not by Phoebus, he,that wand'ring knight so fair. And I prithee, sweet wag, when thou art king, as God save thy Grace—Majesty, I should say, for grace thou wilt have none—
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Now you’re talking, Hal. Thieves like us operate at night, by the moon and stars, and not by the sun. I hope, pretty boy, that when you become king, God save your Grace—or maybe I should just call you “Your Majesty,” since you don’t have any grace—

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What, none?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$None?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No, by my troth, not so much as will serve to be prologue to an egg and butter.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No, I swear. Not even enough to say grace before a snack.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, how then? Come, roundly, roundly.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Come on, out with it. Get to the point.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Marry, then, sweet wag, when thou art king, let not us that are squires of the night’s body be called thieves of the day’s beauty. Let us be Diana’s foresters, gentlemen of the shade, minions of the moon, and let men say we be men of good government, being governed, as the sea is, by our noble and chaste mistress the moon, under whose countenance we steal.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Okay then, pretty boy. Whey you become king, don’t let those of us who work at night be blamed for wasting daylight by sleeping through it. Give us fancy names: “Servants of the Moon Goddess Diana;” “Gentlemen of Shadows;” “Lunar Laborers.” Make people admire us for being well behaved. After all, we’re governed by the same force that governs the tides—the pale and cool moon, who lights our way as we sneak around.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Thou sayest well, and it holds well too, for the fortune of us that are the moon’s men doth ebb and flow like the sea, being governed, as the sea is, by the moon. As for proof now: a purse of gold most resolutely snatched on Monday night and most dissolutely spent on Tuesday morning, got with swearing “Lay by” and spent with crying “Bring in”; now in as low an ebb as the foot of the ladder, and by and by in as high a flow as the ridge of the gallows.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well said. And you’re right—our luck ebbs and flows like the tide, because, like the sea, we’re governed by the moon. I’ll prove it. Imagine a bag of gold, brilliantly swiped on a Monday night and extravagantly spent on a Tuesday morning. You snatch it, shouting, “Hand it off!” and spend it, calling, “Bring it on!” It’s like the gallows: one minute you’re at the bottom of the ladder—low tide. The next, you’re swinging from the top—high tide!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$By the Lord, thou sayest true, lad. And is not my hostess of the tavern a most sweet wench?
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$By God that’s right, my boy! And by the way, isn’t the
hostess of the tavern a delicious woman?$NEWLINE$hostess of the tavern$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$As the honey of Hybla, my old lad of the castle. And is not a buff jerkin a most sweet robe of durance?
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Sweet as honey from
Hybla, you dirty old man. And isn’t a sheriff’s uniform a pretty durable outfit?$NEWLINE$Hybla$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$How now, how now, mad wag? What, in thy quips and thy quiddities? What a plague have I to do with a buff jerkin?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What’s that supposed to mean, you crazy man? You’re in the mood for jokes? Why are you talking to me about a sheriff’s uniform?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, what a pox have I to do with my hostess of the tavern?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, why the hell are you asking me about the hostess of the tavern?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, thou hast called her to a reckoning many a time and oft.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You’ve asked her for the
bill enough times.$NEWLINE$bill$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Did I ever call for thee to pay thy part?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Did I ever ask you to pay for any of it?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No, I’ll give thee thy due. Thou hast paid all there.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No. I’ve got to admit, you’ve settled with her all by yourself.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Yea, and elsewhere, so far as my coin would stretch, and where it would not, I have used my credit.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And not just with her, but wherever my cash was good. And when I ran out, I switched to credit.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Yea, and so used it that were it not here apparent that thou art heir apparent—But I prithee, sweet wag, shall there be gallows standing in England when thou art king? And resolution thus fubbed as it is with the rusty curb of old father Antic the law? Do not thou, when thou art king, hang a thief.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$And you’ve stretched that so far that if it weren’t “here apparent” that you’re the “heir apparent,” your credit wouldn’t be worth a thing. But listen, pretty boy. Will England still have hangmen when you’re king? And will a thief’s courage still be thwarted by that nasty old clown, the law? When you’re king, don’t hang thieves.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$No, thou shalt.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$No. You will.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Shall I? O rare! By the Lord, I’ll be a brave judge.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I will? Excellent! By God, I’ll be a great judge.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Thou judgest false already: I mean thou shalt have the hanging of the thieves, and so become a rare hangman.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You’ve judged wrong already. I mean, you’ll be in charge of hanging thieves, and become a superb hangman.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, Hal, well, and in some sort it jumps with my humor as well as waiting in the court, I can tell you.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$All right, Hal. I’ll tell you this: in a way, being a hangman agrees with me just as well as hanging around the court.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$For obtaining of suits?
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Waiting to get your
suits granted?$NEWLINE$suits$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Yea, for obtaining of suits, whereof the hangman hath no lean wardrobe. 'Sblood, I am as melancholy as a gib cat or a lugged bear.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Exactly. I’ve got plenty of those, just like the hangman has plenty of suits—the suits he takes off the dead men he hangs.—Damn, I’m as depressed as a tomcat or a dancing bear in chains.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Or an old lion, or a lover’s lute.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Or an old lion, or a guitar playing a sad lovesong.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Yea, or the drone of a Lincolnshire bagpipe.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Or the wailing of a bagpipe.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What sayest thou to a hare, or the melancholy of$NEWLINE$Moorditch?
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How about a rabbit, or a trip to
Moorditch?$NEWLINE$Moorditch?$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Thou hast the most unsavory similes, and art indeed the most comparative, rascaliest, sweet young Prince. But, Hal, I comparative, rascaliest, sweet young Prince. But, Hal, I prithee trouble me no more with vanity. I would to God thou and I knew where a commodity of good names were to be bought. An old lord of the council rated me the other day in the street about you, sir, but I marked him not, and yet he talked very wisely, but I regarded him not, and yet he talked wisely, and in the street, too.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You have a knack for foul images. You are the most metaphorical and rascally, sweet young Prince. But Hal, please stop corrupting me with frivolous matters. I wish to God that you and I knew where we could buy a supply of good reputations. The other day, an elderly lord on the King’s Council came up to me in the street and lectured me about you, but I didn’t pay any attention. He spoke wisely, but I ignored him. But he made sense, and in the street, too.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Thou didst well, for wisdom cries out in the streets and no man regards it.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You did well. You know the scripture: “Wisdom cries out in the street but no man listens.”

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$O, thou hast damnable iteration, and art indeed able to corrupt a saint. Thou hast done much harm upon me, Hal, God forgive thee for it. Before I knew thee, Hal, I knew nothing, and now am I, if a man should speak truly, little better than one of the wicked. I must give over this life, and I will give it over. By the Lord, an I do not, I am a villain. I’ll be damned for never a king’s son in Christendom.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Oh, you have a wicked talent for wrongly quoting scripture, you really could corrupt a saint. You’ve deeply harmed me, Hal, and God forgive you for it! Before I met you, I was innocent. And now, if I can speak truly, I’m no better than a sinner. I’ve got to change my life, and I will change my life, by God. If I don’t, I’m an evildoer. I won’t be damned, not for any king’s son in the universe.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Where shall we take a purse tomorrow, Jack?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Where should we go stealing tomorrow, Jack?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Zounds, where thou wilt, lad. I’ll make one. An I do not, call me villain and baffle me.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, wherever you want, boy. I’ll be one of the gang. If I’m not, call me evildoer and string me up.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I see a good amendment of life in thee, from praying to purse-taking.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I see you’ve changed your life, alright. From praying to pursesnatching.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Why, Hal, ’tis my vocation, Hal. 'Tis no sin for a man to labor in his vocation.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$It’s my calling, Hal. It’s no sin for a man to follow his calling.

paragraphs.original: Enter POINS$NEWLINE$POINS
paragraphs.translated: POINS enters.$NEWLINE$POINS

paragraphs.original: Poins!—Now shall we know if Gadshill have set a match. O, if men were to be saved by merit, what hole in hell were hot enough for him? This is the most omnipotent villain that ever cried “Stand!” to a true man.
paragraphs.translated: Poins! Now we’ll find out whether Mr. Gadshill has planned a robbery. If good deeds bring a man to heaven, there’s no hell hot enough for Poins. This is the most incredible villain, whoever said “Stick 'em up!” to an honest man.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Good morrow, Ned.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Morning, Ned.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Good morrow, sweet Hal.—What says Monsieur Remorse? What says Sir John Sack-and-Sugar? Jack, how agrees the devil and thee about thy soul that thou soldest him on Good Friday last for a cup of Madeira and a cold capon’s leg?
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Morning, sweet Hal. What’s Mr. Feelbad got to say? What’s going on, Sir John, Wino Jack? How’s your deal with the devil coming along? You sold him your soul last Good Friday for some cold chicken and a glass of cheap wine, right?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Sir John stands to his word. The devil shall have his bargain, for he was never yet a breaker of proverbs. He will give the devil his due.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$The devil will get what’s coming to him. Sir John’s a man of his word, and he never disagrees with a proverb. He will “give the devil his due.”

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$(to FALSTAFF )Then art thou damned for keeping thy word with the devil.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$(to FALSTAFF )Then you’re damned for keeping your word with the devil.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Else he had been damned for cozening the devil.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$His only other choice is to be damned for cheating the devil.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$But, my lads, my lads, tomorrow morning, by four o'clock, early at Gad’s Hill, there are pilgrims going to Canterbury with rich offerings, and traders riding to London with fat purses. I have vizards for you all. You have horses for yourselves. Gadshill lies tonight in Rochester. I have bespoke supper tomorrow night in Eastcheap. We may do it as secure as sleep. If you will go, I will stuff your purses full of crowns. If you will not, tarry at home and be hanged.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$But boys, boys! Four o'clock tomorrow morning some pilgrims are going to pass by Gad’s Hill. They’ll be on their way to Canterbury Cathedral with expensive offerings, and traders will be heading to London with bags of money. I’ve got masks for you, you’ve got horses for yourselves. Mr. Gadshill is spending tonight in Rochester, and I’ve already ordered tomorrow night’s dinner in Eastcheap. We could do this in our sleep. If you come, I’ll make you rich. If not, stay home and hang yourselves.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hear ye, Yedward, if I tarry at home and go not, I’ll hang you for going.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Listen, Yedward. If I stay home and don’t go, I’ll hang you — for going.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$You will, chops?
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$You will, fatface?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hal, wilt thou make one?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hal, are you in?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Who, I rob? I a thief? not I, by my faith.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Who? Me, a robber? Me, a thief? Not me. No way.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$There’s neither honesty, manhood, nor good fellowship in thee, nor thou cam’st not of the blood royal, if thou darest not stand for ten shillings.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$If you don’t dare to fight for ten shillings, there’s no honesty, manhood, or friendship in you, and you never came from royal blood.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well then, once in my days I’ll be a madcap.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, okay. For once in my life, I’ll be a little crazy.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Why, that’s well said.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$There you go.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, come what will, I’ll tarry at home.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, you know what? I’ll stay home.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$By the Lord, I’ll be a traitor then when thou art king.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$By God, then I’ll be a traitor when you become king.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I care not.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I don’t care.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Sir John, I prithee, leave the Prince and me alone. I will lay him down such reasons for this adventure that he shall go.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Sir John, do me a favor: leave me and the Prince alone. I’ll spell out such good reasons for this adventure, he’s sure to join.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, God give thee the spirit of persuasion, and him the ears of profiting, that what thou speakest may move, and what he hears may be believed, that the true prince may, for recreation sake, prove a false thief, for the poor abuses of the time want countenance. Farewell. You shall find me in Eastcheap.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$May God give you the power of persuasion and him the good sense to listen, so that what you say will affect him and what he hears will sink in. This way, the true prince will turn into false thief, just for laughs. After all, all the poor, little vices of the age need encouragement. So long; you’ll find me in Eastcheap.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Farewell, thou latter spring. Farewell, All-hallown summer.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Farewell, you second spring! Farewell, you summer-in-November!$NEWLINE$Farewell$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exit FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF exits.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Now, my good sweet honey lord, ride with us tomorrow. I have a jest to execute that I cannot manage alone. Falstaff, Peto, Bardolph, and Gadshill shall rob those men that we have already waylaid. Yourself and I will not be there. And when they have the booty, if you and I do not rob them, cut this head off from my shoulders.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Now, my good sweet honey sir, come with us tomorrow. I have an idea for a practical joke, and I can’t do it by myself. Falstaff, Peto, Bardolph, and Mr. Gadshill will rob the travelers we’re planning to ambush, but you and I won’t be there. If you and I don’t rob them once they have the loot, then chop off my head!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How shall we part with them in setting forth?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$But we’re all planning to leave together. How will you and I separate ourselves?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Why, we will set forth before or after them, and appoint them a place of meeting, wherein it is at our pleasure to fail; and then will they adventure upon the exploit themselves, which they shall have no sooner achieved but we’ll set upon them.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$We’ll leave before them, or after them. We’ll tell them to meet us someplace, but then we won’t show up. They’ll pull off the robbery by themselves, and the second they’ve done it, we’ll attack them.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Yea, but ’tis like that they will know us by our horses, by our habits, and by every other appointment to be ourselves.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Sure, but they’ll recognize our horses, our clothes, and all our other things.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Tut, our horses they shall not see; I’ll tie them in the wood. Our vizards we will change after we leave them. And, sirrah, I have cases of buckram for the nonce, to immask our noted outward garments.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Psh! They won’t see our horses, because I’ll tie them in the forest. We’ll put on new masks after we leave them. And, just for this occasion, I’ve made cloaks out of rough buckram cloth, to cover our regular clothes.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Yea, but I doubt they will be too hard for us.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Okay. But I’m afraid they’ll be too tough for us.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Well, for two of them, I know them to be as true-bred cowards as ever turned back; and for the third, if he fight longer than he sees reason, I’ll forswear arms. The virtue of this jest will be the incomprehensible lies that this same fat rogue will tell us when we meet at supper: how thirty at least he fought with, what wards, what blows, what extremities he endured; and in the reproof of this lies the jest.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Well, I know that two of them are the biggest cowards who ever turned and ran. As for the third, if he fights even a second longer than is absolutely necessary, I promise to never fight again. The best part about this joke will be listening to the outlandish lies this fat clown will tell when we meet for dinner—how he fought at least thirty men, how he defended himself, how he got hit, what he endured. The funniest part will be when we call him on it.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, I’ll go with thee. Provide us all things necessary and meet me tomorrow night in Eastcheap. There I’ll sup. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Okay. I’ll go. Get everything together and meet me in Eastcheap tomorrow. I’ll eat there. Farewell.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Farewell, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Farewell, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exit POINS$NEWLINE$POINS
paragraphs.translated: POINS exits.$NEWLINE$POINS

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I know you all, and will awhile uphold$NEWLINE$The unyoked humor of your idleness.$NEWLINE$Yet herein will I imitate the sun,$NEWLINE$Who doth permit the base contagious clouds$NEWLINE$To smother up his beauty from the world,$NEWLINE$That, when he please again to be himself,$NEWLINE$Being wanted, he may be more wondered at$NEWLINE$By breaking through the foul and ugly mist$NEWLINE$Of vapors that did seem to strangle him.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I understand all of you. For now, I’ll put on the rowdy behavior of your good-for-nothing ways. But in this way, I’ll be like the sun, who allows the vulgar, corrupting clouds to hide his beauty from the world. Then, when the sun wants to be himself again, he breaks through the foul mists and vapors that seemed to be strangling him.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If all the year were playing holidays,$NEWLINE$To sport would be as tedious as to work,$NEWLINE$But when they seldom come, they wished for come,$NEWLINE$And nothing pleaseth but rare accidents.$NEWLINE$So when this loose behavior I throw off$NEWLINE$And pay the debt I never promisèd,$NEWLINE$By how much better than my word I am,$NEWLINE$By so much shall I falsify men’s hopes;$NEWLINE$And, like bright metal on a sullen ground,$NEWLINE$My reformation, glitt'ring o'er my fault,$NEWLINE$Shall show more goodly and attract more eyes$NEWLINE$Than that which hath no foil to set it off.$NEWLINE$I’ll so offend to make offense a skill,$NEWLINE$Redeeming time when men think least I will.
paragraphs.translated: And because people have missed him so much, they are that much more impressed when he finally appears. If every day were a vacation, playing would grow as tedious as working. But when it’s rare, it’s looked forward to. Nothing is as precious as the unexpected occurrence. So when I throw off this wild behavior and accept the responsibilities of being king—a destiny I didn’t choose but was born into—I’ll suddenly seem like a far better man. In this way, I’ll give everyone the wrong expectation of me. Like a bright metal on a dark background, my reformation will shine even more brilliantly when it’s set against my wicked past. I’ll be so wild, I’ll make wildness an art form, then redeem myself when the world least expects me to.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the KING, NORTHUMBERLAND, WORCESTER, HOTSPUR, Sir Walter BLUNT, with others$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$BLUNT
paragraphs.translated: The KING, NORTHUMBERLAND, WORCESTER, HOTSPUR, Sir Walter BLUNT and others enter.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$BLUNT

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$My blood hath been too cold and temperate,$NEWLINE$Unapt to stir at these indignities,$NEWLINE$And you have found me, for accordingly$NEWLINE$You tread upon my patience. But be sure$NEWLINE$I will from henceforth rather be myself,$NEWLINE$Mighty and to be feared, than my condition,$NEWLINE$Which hath been smooth as oil, soft as young down,$NEWLINE$And therefore lost that title of respect$NEWLINE$Which the proud soul ne'er pays but to the proud.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$I’ve been too calm and even-tempered, unwilling to react angrily to these indignities. You have discovered this, and so you’ve walked all over my patience. Know this: from now on, I’m going to be my royal self again, powerful and frightening. My natural condition, which was as smooth as oil and soft as feathers, has lost me the respect that powerful people only pay to the similarly powerful.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Our house, my sovereign liege, little deserves$NEWLINE$The scourge of greatness to be used on it,$NEWLINE$And that same greatness too which our own hands$NEWLINE$Have holp to make so portly.
paragraphs.translated:
WORCESTER$NEWLINE$My lord, the
Percy family does not deserve to bear the brunt of your anger and power, especially since we helped you become so powerful in the first place.$NEWLINE$Percy family$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$My lord—
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Your Highness —

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Worcester, get thee gone; for I do see$NEWLINE$Danger and disobedience in thine eye.$NEWLINE$O sir, your presence is too bold and peremptory,$NEWLINE$And majesty might never yet endure$NEWLINE$The moody frontier of a servant brow.$NEWLINE$You have good leave to leave us. When we need$NEWLINE$Your use and counsel, we shall send for you.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Worcester, get out. I see danger and disobedience in your eyes. You carry yourself too boldly and proudly, and royalty should never have to endure a servant’s frowning face. You have my permission to leave now. When I need you or your advice, I’ll call for you.

paragraphs.original: Exit WORCESTER$NEWLINE$WORCESTER
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER exits.$NEWLINE$WORCESTER

paragraphs.original: (to NORTHUMBERLAND)You were about to speak.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: (to NORTHUMBERLAND)You were about to speak.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Yea, my good lord.$NEWLINE$Those prisoners in your Highness' name demanded,$NEWLINE$Which Harry Percy here at Holmedon took,$NEWLINE$Were, as he says, not with such strength denied$NEWLINE$As is delivered to your Majesty:$NEWLINE$Either envy, therefore, or misprison$NEWLINE$Is guilty of this fault, and not my son.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Yes, my Lord. The prisoners you asked for, which my son Harry Percy captured at Holmedon, were not kept from you in anger. He’s already told you that. Whoever told you my son meant to defy you was either mistaken or trying to make trouble. He’s done nothing wrong.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$My liege, I did deny no prisoners.$NEWLINE$But I remember, when the fight was done,$NEWLINE$When I was dry with rage and extreme toil,$NEWLINE$Breathless and faint, leaning upon my sword,$NEWLINE$Came there a certain lord, neat, and trimly dressed,$NEWLINE$Fresh as a bridegroom, and his chin new reaped$NEWLINE$Showed like a stubble land at harvest home.$NEWLINE$He was perfumèd like a milliner,$NEWLINE$And ’twixt his finger and his thumb he held$NEWLINE$A pouncet box, which ever and anon$NEWLINE$He gave his nose and took ’t away again,$NEWLINE$Who therewith angry, when it next came there,$NEWLINE$Took it in snuff; and still he smiled and talked.$NEWLINE$And as the soldiers bore dead bodies by,$NEWLINE$He called them untaught knaves, unmannerly,$NEWLINE$To bring a slovenly unhandsome corse$NEWLINE$Betwixt the wind and his nobility.$NEWLINE$With many holiday and lady terms$NEWLINE$He questioned me; amongst the rest demanded$NEWLINE$My prisoners in your Majesty’s behalf.$NEWLINE$I then, all smarting with my wounds being cold,$NEWLINE$To be so pestered with a popinjay,$NEWLINE$Out of my grief and my impatience$NEWLINE$Answered neglectingly I know not what—$NEWLINE$He should, or he should not; for he made me mad$NEWLINE$To see him shine so brisk and smell so sweet$NEWLINE$And talk so like a waiting-gentlewoman
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Sir, I didn’t hold back any prisoners. But I remember this: when the battle ended, I was exhausted with rage and exertion. I was out of breath, dizzy and bent over. All of a sudden a man approached me, neat, clean, and tidily dressed, like a bridegroom. His beard was freshly shaven, like a newly plowed field. He wore fancy cologne and he carried a perfume box, which he kept raising to his nose as he smiled and talked on. Whenever soldiers walked past, bearing dead bodies, he called them rude hoodlums for bringing a foul, disgusting corpse within breathing distance of him. He interrogated me, with his fancy language, and demanded that I give him my prisoners, to be taken on your behalf. There I was, with the cold aggravating all my wounds, being pestered by this idiot. In my grief and impatience, I gave him some kind of answer. I don’t even remember what I said—he could take them, or he couldn’t.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Of guns, and drums, and wounds—God save the mark!—$NEWLINE$And telling me the sovereignest thing on earth$NEWLINE$Was parmacety for an inward bruise,$NEWLINE$And that it was great pity, so it was,$NEWLINE$This villanous saltpeter should be digged$NEWLINE$Out of the bowels of the harmless earth,$NEWLINE$Which many a good tall fellow had destroyed$NEWLINE$So cowardly, and but for these vile guns$NEWLINE$He would himself have been a soldier.$NEWLINE$This bald unjointed chat of his, my lord,$NEWLINE$I answered indirectly, as I said,$NEWLINE$And I beseech you, let not his report$NEWLINE$Come current for an accusation$NEWLINE$Betwixt my love and your high Majesty.
paragraphs.translated:
I was so angry, looking at him all shiny and sweet-smelling, and speaking like a squeamish woman about guns and battle drums and wounds—God almighty! —and telling me the best thing for an injury is
parmaceti, and that it was a shame that the blameless earth had to be dug up to find saltpeter for the gunpowder, when so many good, brave men had been cowardly destroyed by guns, and that if it hadn’t been for those disgusting guns, he would have been a soldier himself. All this trivial, incoherent talk I answered offhandedly, as I’ve already told you. So I beg you: please don’t take his word as evidence that there’s anything wrong between you and me, your Majesty.$NEWLINE$parmaceti$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$The circumstance considered, good my lord,$NEWLINE$Whate'er Lord Harry Percy then had said$NEWLINE$To such a person and in such a place,$NEWLINE$At such a time, with all the rest retold,$NEWLINE$May reasonably die and never rise$NEWLINE$To do him wrong or any way impeach$NEWLINE$What then he said, so he unsay it now.
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$Given the circumstances, my lord, whatever Harry Percy may have said to a man like that, in a place and time like that, should be allowed to die and never be spoken of again. It should never be used against Harry in any way, since he has taken it all back now.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Why, yet he doth deny his prisoners,$NEWLINE$But with proviso and exception$NEWLINE$That we at our own charge shall ransom straight$NEWLINE$His brother-in-law, the foolish Mortimer,$NEWLINE$Who, on my soul, hath willfully betrayed$NEWLINE$The lives of those that he did lead to fight$NEWLINE$Against that great magician, damned Glendower,$NEWLINE$Whose daughter, as we hear, the Earl of March$NEWLINE$Hath lately married. Shall our coffers then$NEWLINE$Be emptied to redeem a traitor home?$NEWLINE$Shall we buy treason and indent with fears$NEWLINE$When they have lost and forfeited themselves?$NEWLINE$No, on the barren mountains let him starve,$NEWLINE$For I shall never hold that man my friend$NEWLINE$Whose tongue shall ask me for one penny cost$NEWLINE$To ransom home revolted Mortimer.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$But he still won’t turn over his prisoners unless he can add these stipulations and exceptions. He wants me, at my own cost, to pay ransom for his brother-in-law, the foolish Mortimer, a man who, on my life, willfully betrayed his own men, whom he had led in fighting against that great magician, the damned Glendower. And now we hear that Mortimer has married Glendower’s daughter! Should the treasury be emptied to ransom a traitor? Should I pay for treason, and bargain for a coward, when it was Mortimer who lost himself? No. Let him starve in the wilderness. No man who asks me to spend one penny on that traitor Mortimer can ever be a friend of mine.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Revolted Mortimer!$NEWLINE$He never did fall off, my sovereign liege,$NEWLINE$But by the chance of war. To prove that true$NEWLINE$Needs no more but one tongue for all those wounds,$NEWLINE$Those mouthèd wounds, which valiantly he took$NEWLINE$When on the gentle Severn’s sedgy bank$NEWLINE$In single opposition hand to hand$NEWLINE$He did confound the best part of an hour$NEWLINE$In changing hardiment with great Glendower.$NEWLINE$Three times they breathed, and three times did they drink,$NEWLINE$Upon agreement, of swift Severn’s flood,$NEWLINE$Who then, affrighted with their bloody looks,$NEWLINE$Ran fearfully among the trembling reeds$NEWLINE$And hid his crisp head in the hollow bank,$NEWLINE$Bloodstainèd with these valiant combatants.$NEWLINE$Never did bare and rotten policy$NEWLINE$Color her working with such deadly wounds,$NEWLINE$Nor could the noble Mortimer$NEWLINE$Receive so many, and all willingly.$NEWLINE$Then let not him be slandered with revolt.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$“That traitor Mortimer!” He never faltered, my lord, except through an accident of war. I’ll prove it, by speaking about the many wounds he heroically suffered when he spent an hour in brutal hand-to-hand combat against Glendower on the grassy banks of the Severn River. They broke three times from fighting, and they drank three times from the Severn. The river itself was frightened by their horrible looks. Its water became discolored with the blood of these brave fighters, and the Severn ran off, as if to hide itself in the weeds on its banks. Treachery has never used deadly wounds to cover its operations, and Mortimer could never have willingly suffered so many injuries. Do not let him be slandered by calling him a traitor.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Thou dost belie him, Percy; thou dost belie him.$NEWLINE$He never did encounter with Glendower.$NEWLINE$I tell thee, he durst as well have met the devil alone$NEWLINE$As Owen Glendower for an enemy.$NEWLINE$Art thou not ashamed? But, sirrah, henceforth$NEWLINE$Let me not hear you speak of Mortimer.$NEWLINE$Send me your prisoners with the speediest means,$NEWLINE$Or you shall hear in such a kind from me$NEWLINE$As will displease you.—My lord Northumberland,$NEWLINE$We license your departure with your son.—
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$You speak wrongly about him, Percy, you speak wrongly! He never fought Glendower. I tell you, he would just as soon dare to meet the devil himself as fight Glendower. Aren’t you ashamed of yourself? Don’t ever let me hear you speak of Mortimer again. Send me your prisoners as quickly as possible, or you’ll hear about it from me, and you won’t like what I have to say. Northumberland, I give you and your son permission to leave now.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Send us your prisoners, or you will hear of it.
paragraphs.translated: Send your prisoners, or you’ll hear about it.

paragraphs.original: Exit KING Henry, BLUNT, and train$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$BLUNT
paragraphs.translated: KING Henry, BLUNT, and the attendants exit.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$BLUNT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$An if the devil come and roar for them,$NEWLINE$I will not send them. I will after straight$NEWLINE$And tell him so, for I will ease my heart,$NEWLINE$Albeit I make a hazard of my head.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Even if the devil himself comes screaming for them, I won’t send those prisoners. I’m going to go after him and tell him so; it will ease my heart, though it might cost me my head.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$What, drunk with choler? stay and pause awhile.$NEWLINE$Here comes your uncle.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$What, drunk with anger? Wait a minute. Here comes your uncle.

paragraphs.original: Enter WORCESTER$NEWLINE$WORCESTER
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER enters.$NEWLINE$WORCESTER

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Speak of Mortimer?$NEWLINE$Zounds, I will speak of him, and let my soul$NEWLINE$Want mercy if I do not join with him.$NEWLINE$Yea, on his part I’ll empty all these veins$NEWLINE$And shed my dear blood drop by drop in the dust,$NEWLINE$But I will lift the downtrod Mortimer$NEWLINE$As high in the air as this unthankful King,$NEWLINE$As this ingrate and cankered Bolingbroke.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Talk about Mortimer? God damn, I will talk about him. And damn my soul if I don’t join him! I’ll empty out my veins for him, and I’ll pour my precious blood onto the ground, drop by drop! And I’ll lift this put-upon Mortimer as high up as this ungrateful King, this ungenerous, rotten Bolingbroke!

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$(to WORCESTER) Brother, the King hath made your nephew mad.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$(toWORCESTER ) Brother, the King’s driven your nephew crazy.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Who struck this heat up after I was gone?
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Who started this trouble after I left?

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$He will forsooth have all my prisoners,$NEWLINE$And when I urged the ransom once again$NEWLINE$Of my wife’s brother, then his cheek looked pale,$NEWLINE$And on my face he turned an eye of death,$NEWLINE$Trembling even at the name of Mortimer.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$He wants all my prisoners, for God’s sake! And when I asked again for him to ransom my brother-in-law, he looked pale, and he shot me a look that could kill. Just the mention of Mortimer’s name makes him shake.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$I cannot blame him. Was not he proclaimed$NEWLINE$By Richard, that dead is, the next of blood?
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$I don’t blame him. Didn’t the late King Richard II proclaim that Mortimer should be next in line for the throne?

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$He was; I heard the proclamation.$NEWLINE$And then it was when the unhappy King—$NEWLINE$Whose wrongs in us God pardon!—did set forth$NEWLINE$Upon his Irish expedition;$NEWLINE$From whence he, intercepted, did return$NEWLINE$To be deposed and shortly murderèd.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$He did; I heard the proclamation. That was when the wretched King Richard (may God forgive us for wronging him!) set out to invade Ireland. When that was interrupted, he returned to England, only to be deposed and then murdered.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$And for whose death we in the world’s wide mouth$NEWLINE$Live scandalized and foully spoken of.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$And for our part in his death, the whole world is scandalized by us, and speaks ill of us.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$But soft, I pray you. Did King Richard then$NEWLINE$Proclaim my brother Edmund Mortimer$NEWLINE$Heir to the crown?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Stop a moment, please. Did King Richard really proclaim that my brother-in-law Edmund Mortimer was next in line for the throne?

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$He did; myself did hear it.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$He did. I heard it myself.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Nay then, I cannot blame his cousin King$NEWLINE$That wished him on the barren mountains starve.$NEWLINE$But shall it be that you that set the crown$NEWLINE$Upon the head of this forgetful man$NEWLINE$And for his sake wear the detested blot$NEWLINE$Of murderous subornation—shall it be$NEWLINE$That you a world of curses undergo,$NEWLINE$Being the agents or base second means,$NEWLINE$The cords, the ladder, or the hangman rather?$NEWLINE$O, pardon me that I descend so low$NEWLINE$To show the line and the predicament$NEWLINE$Wherein you range under this subtle King.$NEWLINE$Shall it for shame be spoken in these days,$NEWLINE$Or fill up chronicles in time to come,$NEWLINE$That men of your nobility and power
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Then I can’t blame King Henry for wishing for him to starve in the wilderness. But is it right that you—who put the crown on Henry’s forgetful head, and who carry the accusations of murder for Henry’s sake—should be the target of the world’s curses? When you were only accomplices and instruments? Is it right to blame the ropes, the ladder, or the hangman for a man’s death? Forgive me for mentioning that you two are like those sordid objects, having been exploited by this conniving King. But will you stand by while people today speak of your shame?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Did gage them both in an unjust behalf$NEWLINE$(As both of you, God pardon it, have done)$NEWLINE$To put down Richard, that sweet lovely rose,$NEWLINE$An plant this thorn, this canker, Bolingbroke?$NEWLINE$And shall it in more shame be further spoken$NEWLINE$That you are fooled, discarded, and shook off$NEWLINE$By him for whom these shames you underwent?$NEWLINE$No, yet time serves wherein you may redeem$NEWLINE$Your banished honors and restore yourselves$NEWLINE$Into the good thoughts of the world again,$NEWLINE$Revenge the jeering and disdain’d contempt$NEWLINE$Of this proud King, who studies day and night$NEWLINE$To answer all the debt he owes to you$NEWLINE$Even with the bloody payment of your deaths.$NEWLINE$Therefore I say—
paragraphs.translated: While history books record that men of your nobility and power dedicated themselves to as unjust a cause (which, God forgive you, you both did) as the overthrowing of Richard, that sweet lovely rose, and the planting of this thorn, this weed, Bolingbroke in Richard’s place? Will you listen as people say that you are fools, and that you’ve been tossed away by the very person you shamed yourselves to help? No. There is still time for you to redeem your reputations and restore your good names in the eyes of the world. Take revenge against this King who mocks and scorns you. He thinks constantly about how to repay you for all you did—by putting you to death. So I say—

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Peace, cousin, say no more.$NEWLINE$And now I will unclasp a secret book,$NEWLINE$And to your quick-conceiving discontents$NEWLINE$I’ll read you matter deep and dangerous,$NEWLINE$As full of peril and adventurous spirit$NEWLINE$As to o'erwalk a current roaring loud$NEWLINE$On the unsteadfast footing of a spear.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Quiet, nephew; don’t say any more. I have a secret for you, which is hidden like a book with a lock. I will open the book and read you a dark, dangerous story that will appeal to your righteous anger. It’s full of peril and adventure, as risky as walking across a churning, thundering river while balanced unsteadily on a spear.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$If he fall in, good night, or sink or swim!$NEWLINE$Send danger from the east unto the west,$NEWLINE$So honor cross it from the north to south,$NEWLINE$And let them grapple: O, the blood more stirs$NEWLINE$To rouse a lion than to start a hare!
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$If he falls in, then it’s all over, whether he sinks or swims. The honor of the struggle is all that counts, no matter what the danger is or where it comes from. It takes more courage to wake a sleeping lion than to frighten a rabbit!

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Imagination of some great exploit$NEWLINE$Drives him beyond the bounds of patience.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Dreaming about this heroic exploit is driving him past his patience.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$By heaven, methinks it were an easy leap$NEWLINE$To pluck bright honor from the pale-faced moon,$NEWLINE$Or dive into the bottom of the deep,$NEWLINE$Where fathom line could never touch the ground,$NEWLINE$And pluck up drownèd honor by the locks,$NEWLINE$So he that doth redeem her thence might wear$NEWLINE$Without corrival all her dignities.$NEWLINE$But out upon this half-faced fellowship!
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$By God, I think it would be easy to jump up and grab honor off of the moon’s pale face, or to dive into the deepest ocean and pull up honor by its hair.$NEWLINE$Then the man who rescues honor can wear her glory alone, without rivals. To hell with sharing the glory!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$(to NORTHUMBERLAND) He apprehends a world of figures here,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$But not the form of what he should attend.—$NEWLINE$(to HOTSPUR) Good cousin, give me audience for a while.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$(to NORTHUMBERLAND) He sees a world built by his imagination, but that world is not the one he should be paying attention to. (to HOTSPUR) Nephew, listen to me a minute.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I cry you mercy.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I beg your pardon.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Those same noble Scots$NEWLINE$That are your prisoners—
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$These Scotsmen that you’ve taken prisoner —

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I’ll keep them all.$NEWLINE$By God, he shall not have a Scot of them.$NEWLINE$No, if a Scot would save his soul, he shall not.$NEWLINE$I’ll keep them, by this hand!
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I’ll keep them all. By God, the King won’t get a single Scot, even if having a Scot would save his soul! I’ll keep them, I swear.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$You start away$NEWLINE$And lend no ear unto my purposes:$NEWLINE$Those prisoners you shall keep—
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$You’re off again and not listening to me. You will get to keep the prisoners —

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Nay, I will. That’s flat!$NEWLINE$He said he would not ransom Mortimer,$NEWLINE$Forbad my tongue to speak of Mortimer.$NEWLINE$But I will find him when he lies asleep,$NEWLINE$And in his ear I’ll hollo “Mortimer.”$NEWLINE$Nay,$NEWLINE$I’ll have a starling shall be taught to speak$NEWLINE$Nothing but “Mortimer,” and give it him$NEWLINE$To keep his anger still in motion.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Yes, I will; there’s no doubt about it. The King said he would not pay ransom for Mortimer. He forbid me from speaking of Mortimer. But I’ll find him when he’s sleeping, and I’ll shout “Mortimer!” into his ears. No; I’ll get a bird and teach it to say nothing but “Mortimer,” and I’ll give it to the King to anger him forever.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Hear you, cousin, a word.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Listen, nephew, please.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$All studies here I solemnly defy,$NEWLINE$Save how to gall and pinch this Bolingbroke.$NEWLINE$And that same sword-and-buckler Prince of Wales—$NEWLINE$But that I think his father loves him not$NEWLINE$And would be glad he met with some mischance—$NEWLINE$I would have him poisoned with a pot of ale.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$From now on, all other pursuits I’ll cast aside, except for scheming how to aggravate this Bolingbroke and his son, the lowlife Prince of Wales. If it weren’t for the fact that I suspect Henry doesn’t love his son, and that he’d be glad to see misfortune befall him, I’d poison the Prince’s ale.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Farewell, kinsman. I’ll talk to you$NEWLINE$When you are better tempered to attend.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Goodbye, nephew. I’ll talk to you when you’re in a better mood to listen.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$(to HOTSPUR) Why, what a wasp-stung and impatient fool$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Art thou to break into this woman’s mood,$NEWLINE$Tying thine ear to no tongue but thine own!
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$(to HOTSPUR)You are an impatient and short-tempered fool to start nattering on like a woman, not listening to any voice but your own!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Why, look you, I am whipped and scourged with rods,$NEWLINE$Nettled and stung with pismires, when I hear$NEWLINE$Of this vile politician, Bolingbroke.$NEWLINE$In Richard’s time—what do you call the place?$NEWLINE$A plague upon it! It is in Gloucestershire.$NEWLINE$'Twas where the madcap duke his uncle kept,$NEWLINE$His uncle York; where I first bowed my knee$NEWLINE$Unto this king of smiles, this Bolingbroke.$NEWLINE$'Sblood, when you and he came back from Ravenspurgh.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Listen, I feel like I’m being whipped with sticks and stung by ants when I hear about this vile politician, Bolingbroke. When Richard was alive—what is that place called? Damn, it’s in Gloucestershire; it’s where that crazy duke’s uncle lived, his uncle York. It’s where I first met this lying Bolingbroke, and bowed to him.—Shoot!—It happened when you and Bolingbroke came back from Ravenspurgh.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$At Berkley Castle.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$At Berkley castle.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$You say true.$NEWLINE$Why, what a candy deal of courtesy$NEWLINE$This fawning greyhound then did proffer me:$NEWLINE$“Look when his infant fortune came to age,”$NEWLINE$And “gentle Harry Percy,” and “kind cousin.”$NEWLINE$O, the devil take such cozeners!—God forgive me!$NEWLINE$Good uncle, tell your tale. I have done.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Right. What great courtesy that flattering dog paid me! “The promise of his childhood has come true,” he said. “Gentle Harry Percy,” he called me, and “kind kinsman.” To hell with liars like him! — I’m sorry. Uncle, go on. I’m done.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Nay, if you have not, to it again.$NEWLINE$We will stay your leisure.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$No, if you’re not done yet, keep going. We’ll wait until you’re ready.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I have done, i' faith.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I’m done. I swear.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Then once more to your Scottish prisoners:$NEWLINE$Deliver them up without their ransom straight,$NEWLINE$And make the Douglas' son your only mean$NEWLINE$For powers in Scotland, which, for divers reasons$NEWLINE$Which I shall send you written, be assured$NEWLINE$Will easily be granted.—(to NORTHUMBERLAND) You, my lord,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Your son in Scotland being thus employed,$NEWLINE$Shall secretly into the bosom creep$NEWLINE$Of that same noble prelate, well beloved,$NEWLINE$The Archbishop.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Then go back to your Scottish prisoners. Release them at once, without ransom. Make friends with Douglas, and use his influence to gather an army in Scotland. He’ll gladly help you for many reasons, which I’ll write you about soon. (to NORTHUMBERLAND) Now you, sir. While your son is busy in Scotland, you will strike up a close alliance with the Archbishop, that noble, well-beloved churchman.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Of York, is it not?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$He is the Archbishop of York, no?

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$True; who bears hard$NEWLINE$His brother’s death at Bristol, the Lord Scroop.$NEWLINE$I speak not this in estimation,$NEWLINE$As what I think might be, but what I know$NEWLINE$Is ruminated, plotted, and set down,$NEWLINE$And only stays but to behold the face$NEWLINE$Of that occasion that shall bring it on.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Yes, and he’s sorely upset about his brother, Lord Scroop, whom Bolingbroke put to death in Bristol. I’m not merely speculating; I’m telling you what I know for a fact has been considered, plotted, and set into motion. They’re only waiting now for the right moment to strike.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I smell it. Upon my life, it will do well.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I get it. And it’s good, I bet my life on it!

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Before the game is afoot thou still let’st slip.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Look, you’ve let your dogs slip off of their leashes before the hunt has even begun.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Why, it cannot choose but be a noble plot.$NEWLINE$And then the power of Scotland and of York$NEWLINE$To join with Mortimer, ha?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$There’s no way this excellent plan won’t work. And the armies of Scotland and York will join with Mortimer, right?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$And so they shall.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Yes, they will.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$In faith, it is exceedingly well aimed.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I swear, it’s extremely well thought out.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$And ’tis no little reason bids us speed$NEWLINE$To save our heads by raising of a head,$NEWLINE$For, bear ourselves as even as we can,$NEWLINE$The King will always think him in our debt,$NEWLINE$And think we think ourselves unsatisfied,$NEWLINE$Till he hath found a time to pay us home.$NEWLINE$And see already how he doth begin$NEWLINE$To make us strangers to his looks of love.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$And we’ve got good reasons to hurry and save ourselves by raising an army. No matter how hard we try to look like everything’s fine, the King will always think he owes us for having helped him take the throne, and he’ll worry that we don’t feel we’ve been properly compensated. Until he finds a way to pay us for good—by killing us. You can see that he’s already begun to distance himself from us.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$He does, he does. We’ll be revenged on him.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$He has, he has. We’ll get revenge!

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Cousin, farewell. No further go in this$NEWLINE$Than I by letters shall direct your course.$NEWLINE$When time is ripe, which will be suddenly,$NEWLINE$I’ll steal to Glendower and Lord Mortimer,$NEWLINE$Where you and Douglas and our powers at once,$NEWLINE$As I will fashion it, shall happily meet$NEWLINE$To bear our fortunes in our own strong arms,$NEWLINE$Which now we hold at much uncertainty.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Nephew, farewell. Don’t do any more than I tell you to do in the letters I’ll write you. When the time comes, which will be soon, I’ll sneak off to Glendower and Mortimer. I’ll plan it so that you, Douglas and all our armies will arrive together. Then we can face our future with strength instead of the uncertainty we feel now.

paragraphs.original: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$Farewell, good brother. We shall thrive, I trust.
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND$NEWLINE$So long, brother. I believe we’ll prevail.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Uncle, adieu: O, let the hours be short$NEWLINE$Till fields and blows and groans applaud our sport.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Good bye, uncle. Oh, I hope it won’t be long until battlefields and collisions and groans are witnesses to our game of war!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a CARRIER with a lantern in his hand$NEWLINE$CARRIER
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST
CARRIER enters, holding a lantern.$NEWLINE$CARRIER$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$Heigh-ho! An it be not four by the day, I’ll be hanged. Charles’s Wain is over the new chimney, and yet our horse not packed.—What, ostler!
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$I’ll be damned if it isn’t 4 A.M. already. The Big Dipper has already risen above the chimney, and our horses aren’t ready yet. Hey,
ostler!$NEWLINE$ostler!$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: OSTLER$NEWLINE$(within) Anon, anon.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: OSTLER$NEWLINE$(offstage) Just a second!$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$I prithee, Tom, beat Cut’s saddle. Put a few flocks in the point. Poor jade is wrung in the withers out of all cess.
paragraphs.translated:
FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$Hey,
Tom, give the saddle of my horse, Cut, a few whacks to soften it up, and stuff some wool under it—the old nag’s got some bad bruises on her shoulders.$NEWLINE$Tom$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter another CARRIER$NEWLINE$CARRIER
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CARRIER enters.$NEWLINE$SECOND CARRIER

paragraphs.original: SECOND CARRIER$NEWLINE$Peas and beans are as dank here as a dog, and that is the next way to give poor jades the bots. This house is turned upside down since Robin ostler died.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CARRIER$NEWLINE$The feed here’s as damp as anything. That’s a fast way for a horse to get parasites. This stable’s upside down since Ostler Robin died.

paragraphs.original: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$Poor fellow never joyed since the price of oats rose. It was the death of him.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$Poor guy. Once the price of oats went up, he was never happy again. It killed him.

paragraphs.original: SECOND CARRIER$NEWLINE$I think this be the most villanous house in all London road for fleas. I am stung like a tench.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND CARRIER$NEWLINE$This stable’s got worse fleas than any in London. I’m stung like a
tench.$NEWLINE$tench$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$Like a tench? By the Mass, there is ne'er a king christen could be better bit than I have been since the first cock.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$Like a tench? I’m telling you, not even a king could be bitten more than I’ve been bitten since midnight.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SECOND CARRIER$NEWLINE$Why, they will allo w us ne'er a jordan, and then we leak in your chimney, and your chamber-lye breeds fleas like a loach.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CARRIER$NEWLINE$They don’t even give us a bathroom. So we pee in the fireplace, and you know that urine breeds fleas like nobody’s business.

paragraphs.original: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$What, ostler, come away and be hanged. Come away.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$Hey, ostler! Come on already, damn you!

paragraphs.original: SECOND CARRIER$NEWLINE$I have a gammon of bacon and two races of ginger to be delivered as far as Charing Cross.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CARRIER$NEWLINE$I’ve got to deliver a ham and some ginger root all the way to Charing Cross.

paragraphs.original: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$God’s body, the turkeys in my pannier are quite starved.— What, ostler! A plague on thee! Hast thou never an eye in thy head? Canst not hear? An ’twere not as good deed as drink to break the pate on thee, I am a very villain. Come, and be hanged. Hast no faith in thee?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$God almighty! The turkeys I’m carrying are starving! Hey, Stable-boy! Curse you! Can’t you see? Can’t you hear? If it isn’t a good idea to knock you on the head, I’m a fool. Come on, damn you! Can’t we trust you to do your job?

paragraphs.original: Enter GADSHILL$NEWLINE$GADSHILL
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL enters.$NEWLINE$GADSHILL

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Good morrow, carriers. What’s o'clock?
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Morning, deliverymen. What time is it?

paragraphs.original: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$I think it be two o'clock.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$I think it’s two o'clock.

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$I prithee, lend me thy lantern to see my gelding in the stable.
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Let me borrow your lantern so I can check on my horse in the stable.

paragraphs.original: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$Nay, by God, soft. I know a trick worth two of that, i' faith.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CARRIER$NEWLINE$No way, by God; just hold on a minute. I know a few tricks like that myself, I swear.

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$(to SECOND CARRIER) I pray thee, lend me thine.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$(to SECOND CARRIER) Please, let me borrow yours.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SECOND CARRIER$NEWLINE$Ay, when, canst tell? “Lend me thy lantern,” quoth he.$NEWLINE$Marry, I’ll see thee hanged first.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CARRIER$NEWLINE$Sure, whenever. Whatever you say. “Let me borrow your lantern,” he says? Yeah, right. I’ll see you dead first.

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Sirrah carrier, what time do you mean to come to London?
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Sirrah, what time do you plan to be in London?$NEWLINE$Sirrah$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SECOND CARRIER$NEWLINE$Time enough to go to bed with a candle, I warrant thee. Come, neighbour Mugs, we’ll call up the gentlemen. They will along with company, for they have great charge.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CARRIER$NEWLINE$At a reasonable enough time. (to FIRST CARRIER) Come on, Mugs, old friend. Let’s wake up the gentlemen. They want to travel in a group because they’re carrying a lot of valuables.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt CARRIERS$NEWLINE$CARRIERS
paragraphs.translated: Both CARRIERS exit.$NEWLINE$CARRIERS

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$What ho, chamberlain!
paragraphs.translated:
GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Hey,
chamberlain!$NEWLINE$chamberlain!$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$(within) At hand, quoth pickpurse.$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated:
CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$(offstage)
“I’m there for you,” as the pickpockets say!$NEWLINE$(offstage)$NEWLINE$“I’m there for you,”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$That’s even as fair as “at hand, quoth the Chamberlain,” for thou variest no more from picking of purses than giving direction doth from laboring: thou layest the plot how.
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$That’s as good as saying, “‚I’m there for you,' said the chamberlain.” You’re only as different from a pickpocket as a supervisor is from a worker; you’re the one who sets the plans.

paragraphs.original: Enter CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$CHAMBERLAIN
paragraphs.translated: The CHAMBERLAIN enters.$NEWLINE$CHAMBERLAIN

paragraphs.original: CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$Good morrow, Master Gadshill. It holds current that I told you yesternight: there’s a franklin in the Wild of Kent hath brought three hundred marks with him in gold. I heard him tell it to one of his company last night at supper—a kind of auditor, one that hath abundance of charge too, God knows what. They are up already and call for eggs and butter. They will away presently.
paragraphs.translated: CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$Morning, Mr. Gadshill. What I told you last night is still true. There’s a rich landowner all the way from Kent staying here, and he’s got three hundred gold coins with him. I heard him say so to a man at supper last night. That man’s some kind of tax collector, and he has plenty of money with him, too. They just woke up and they’ve ordered breakfast; they’ll be leaving soon.

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Sirrah, if they meet not with Saint Nicholas' clerks, I’ll give thee this neck.
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Sirrah, if they don’t run into some highway robbers today, you can have my neck.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$No, I’ll none of it. I pray thee keep that for the hangman, for I know thou worshipest Saint Nicholas as truly as a man of falsehood may.
paragraphs.translated: CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$I don’t want it; keep it for the hangman. I know you worship the patron saint of highway robbery, as much as a godless man like you worships anything.

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$What talkest thou to me of the hangman? If I hang, I’ll make a fat pair of gallows, for if I hang, old Sir John hangs with me, and thou knowest he is no starveling. Tut, there are other Troyans that thou dream’st not of, the which for sport sake are content to do the profession some grace, that would, if matters should be looked into, for their own credit sake make all whole. I am joined with no foot-land-rakers, no long-staff sixpenny strikers, none of these mad mustachio purple-hued malt-worms, but with nobility and tranquillity, burgomasters and great oneyers, such as can hold in, such as will strike sooner than speak, and speak sooner than drink, and drink sooner than pray, and yet, zounds, I lie, for they pray continually to their saint the commonwealth, or rather not pray to her but prey on her, for they ride up and down on her and make her their boots.
paragraphs.translated:
GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Why are you taking to me about the hangman? If I hang, I’ll make half of a fat pair on the gallows, because if I hang, old Sir John will be hanging right with me—and he’s not exactly thin. Please! Our gang has some members you could never guess, and for their own amusement, they’re happy to lend the profession of thievery some respect.
