If we were ever investigated, they would smooth everything over. I’ve got no wandering highwaymen, no thieves with homemade weapons, no red-faced drunks with crazy mustaches. Only men of calm and noble demeanor for me: magistrates and court officials. Men who can keep a secret; who’d rather smack you than speak, rather speak than drink, and rather drink than pray.—No! That’s a lie! They pray all the time to England, their patron saint. Or rather, they don’t pray to her; they prey on her. They ride her up and down and then make her their
boots.$NEWLINE$boots$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$What, the commonwealth their boots? Will she hold out water in foul way?
paragraphs.translated: CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$Make her their boots? Why, will she keep their feet dry from muddy water?

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$She will, she will. Justice hath liquored her. We steal as in a castle, cocksure. We have the receipt of fern seed; we walk invisible.
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$She can, she can. She’s been greased with so many bribes that she’s waterproof. We thieve in complete safety; we’ve got a potion that makes us invisible.

paragraphs.original: CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$Nay, by my faith, I think you are more beholding to the night than to fern seed for your walking invisible.
paragraphs.translated: CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$Oh, I don’t think so. It’s the dark of night that makes you hard to see, not a secret potion.

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Give me thy hand. Thou shalt have a share in our purchase, as I am a true man.
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Let’s shake hands. You’ll get a share of our spoils; I swear on my honor as a true man.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$Nay, rather let me have it as you are a false thief.
paragraphs.translated: CHAMBERLAIN$NEWLINE$I’d rather have you swear by your reputation as a dishonest thief.

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Go to. Homo is a common name to all men. Bid the ostler bring my gelding out of the stable. Farewell, you muddy knave.$NEWLINE$Homo
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Whatever. I’m a true man, even if I’m a dishonest thief. Tell the stable-boy to get my horse. Farewell, you fool.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY, POINS, BARDOLPH, and PETO$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PETO
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY, POINS, PETO, and BARDOLPH enter.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS$NEWLINE$PETO$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Come, shelter, shelter! I have removed Falstaff’s horse, and he frets like a gummed velvet.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Come on, hide, hide! I stole Falstaff’s horse, and he’s rubbed the wrong way; he’s fraying like cheap velvet.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Stand close.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Stay hidden.

paragraphs.original: Exit POINS, BARDOLPH, and PETO exit$NEWLINE$POINS$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PETO
paragraphs.translated: POINS, PETO and BARDOLPH exit.$NEWLINE$POINS$NEWLINE$PETO$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF enters.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Poins! Poins, and be hanged! Poins!
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Poins! Poins, damn you! Poins!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Peace, you fat-kidneyed rascal. What a brawling dost thou keep!
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Quiet, you fat-bellied jerk! What a racket you’re making!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Where’s Poins, Hal?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Where’s Poins, Hal?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$He is walked up to the top of the hill. I’ll go seek him.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$He walked up the hill. I’ll go find him.

paragraphs.original: Exit PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY exits.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I am accursed to rob in that thief’s company. The rascal hath removed my horse and tied him I know not where. If I travel but four foot by the square further afoot, I shall break my wind. Well, I doubt not but to die a fair death for all this, if I ’scape hanging for killing that rogue. I have forsworn his company hourly any time this two-and-twenty years, and yet I am bewitched with the rogue’s company. If the rascal hath not given me medicines to make me love him, I’ll be hanged. It could not be else: I have drunk medicines.— Poins! Hal! A plague upon you both.—Bardolph! Peto!— I’ll starve ere I’ll rob a foot further. An ’twere not as good a deed as drink to turn true man and to leave these rogues, I am the veriest varlet that ever chewed with a tooth. Eight yards of uneven ground is threescore and ten miles afoot with me, and the stony-hearted villains know it well enough. A plague upon it when thieves cannot be true one to another!
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I got a raw deal, to be out robbing with him. He stole my horse and tied him up someplace. If I have to walk even four feet more, I’ll be totally out of breath. Still, I bet I’ll die a natural death—if I don’t get hanged for killing that jerk, that is. Every hour for the past twenty-two years, I’ve sworn I’d never talk to him again, but I love his company. He must have slipped me a love potion that makes me adore him. Damn, that must be it: I have drunk love potions. Poins! Hal! Drop dead, the both of you! Bardolph! Peto! I’ll die if I have to walk another foot. If turning honest and abandoning these jerks weren’t the best things I could possibly do for myself, then I’m the worst scoundrel that ever lived. Eight yards of rough road is like seventy miles to me, and these hard-hearted crooks know it. It stinks when there’s no honor among thieves.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: They whistle.
paragraphs.translated: They whistle from offstage.

paragraphs.original: Whew!
paragraphs.translated: Whew!

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY, POINS, PETO, and BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS$NEWLINE$PETO$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY, POINS, PETO, and BARDOLPHenter.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS$NEWLINE$PETO$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: A plague upon you all! Give me my horse, you rogues. Give me my horse and be hanged!
paragraphs.translated: The hell with you all! Give me my horse, you deadbeats. Give me my horse and the hell with you!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Peace, you fat guts! Lie down, lay thine ear close to the ground, and list if thou canst hear the tread of travelers.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Shut up, fatso! Lie down, put your ear to the ground, and listen for the footsteps of travelers.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Have you any levers to lift me up again being down? 'Sblood, I’ll not bear mine own flesh so far afoot again for all the coin in thy father’s Exchequer. What a plague mean you to colt me thus?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Do you have a crane to lift me up again once I’m down? Damn, I wouldn’t walk my fat self this far again for all the money in your father’s treasury. What are you doing horsing around with me like this?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Thou liest. Thou art not colted; thou art uncolted.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You’re lying. We can’t horse around, because you don’t have a horse.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I prithee, good Prince Hal, help me to my horse, good king’s son.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Please, my good Hal, help me find my horse, you good king’s son.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Out, you rogue! Shall I be your ostler?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Later with that! You want me to be your stable boy?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hang thyself in thine own heir-apparent garters! If I be ta'en, I’ll peach for this. An I have not ballads made on you all and sung to filthy tunes, let a cup of sack be my poison—when a jest is so forward, and afoot too! I hate it.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Go drop dead in your own heir-apparent pants. If I’m arrested, I’ll rat you out, too. If I don’t get them singing dirty songs in the street about you all, let me be poisoned to death with booze. I hate it when a practical joke gets so out of hand—and with me out of a horse, too!

paragraphs.original: Enter GADSHILL$NEWLINE$GADSHILL
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL enters.$NEWLINE$GADSHILL

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Stand.
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Freeze!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$So I do, against my will.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I am, and I don’t like it.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$O, ’tis our setter. I know his voice, Bardolph. —What news?
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Oh, that’s the man who planned the whole thing; I recognize his voice, Bardolph.— What’s going on?

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Case you, case you. On with your vizards. There’s money of the King’s coming down the hill. 'Tis going to the King’s Exchequer.
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Cover your faces, cover your faces. Get your masks on. There’s tax money coming down the hill, on its way to the King’s treasury.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You lie, you rogue. 'Tis going to the King’s Tavern.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$That’s a lie, you clown. It’s on its way to the king’s bank.

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$There’s enough to make us all.
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$There’s enough to make us all rich.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$To be hanged.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Or to get us all hanged.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Sirs, you four shall front them in the narrow lane. Ned Poins and I will walk lower. If they ’scape from your encounter, then they light on us.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Listen, you four confront them in the narrow lane. Ned Poins and I will wait further down. If they get away from you, they’ll run right into us.

paragraphs.original: PETO$NEWLINE$How many be there of them?
paragraphs.translated: PETO$NEWLINE$How many of them are there?

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Some eight or ten.
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$About eight or ten.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Zounds, will they not rob us?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Damn! Won’t they rob us?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What, a coward, Sir John Paunch?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What, are you a coward, Sir John Fatstuff?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Indeed, I am not John of Gaunt, your grandfather, but yet no coward, Hal.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, I’m certainly not John of
Gaunt, your grandfather, but I’m no coward, Hal.$NEWLINE$Gaunt$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, we leave that to the proof.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, we’ll see about that.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Sirrah Jack, thy horse stands behind the hedge. When thou needest him, there thou shalt find him. Farewell, and stand fast.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Jack, sirrah, your horse is there behind the hedge. When you need him, that’s where you’ll find him. So long, and be brave.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Now cannot I strike him, if I should be hanged.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I can’t hit him. I’d be hanged.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$(aside to POINS ) Ned, where are our disguises?$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$(to POINS, so others cannot hear) Ned, where are our disguises?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$, so others cannot hear)

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$(aside to PRINCE HENRY) Here, hard by. Stand close.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$(to PRINCE HENRY) They’re here, close by. Now hide.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PRINCE HENRY and POINS$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY and POINS exit.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Now, my masters, happy man be his dole, say I. Every man to his business.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Now, men, here’s to happy endings. Every man to his station.

paragraphs.original: Enter the TRAVELERS$NEWLINE$TRAVELERS
paragraphs.translated: The TRAVELERS enter.$NEWLINE$TRAVELERS

paragraphs.original: FIRST TRAVELER$NEWLINE$Come, neighbor, the boy shall lead our horses down the hill.$NEWLINE$We’ll walk afoot awhile and ease our legs.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST TRAVELER$NEWLINE$Come on, friend. The boy will lead our horses down the hill while we walk a bit and stretch our legs.

paragraphs.original: THIEVES$NEWLINE$Stand!
paragraphs.translated: THIEVES$NEWLINE$Freeze!

paragraphs.original: TRAVELERS$NEWLINE$Jesus bless us!
paragraphs.translated: TRAVELERS$NEWLINE$Jesus bless us!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Strike! Down with them! Cut the villains' throats! Ah, whoreson caterpillars, bacon-fed knaves, they hate us youth. Down with them! Fleece them!
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hit them! Down with them! Cut their throats! Yahhhhh! No-good bloodsuckers! Overfed morons! They hate young people like us. Down with them! Rob them blind!

paragraphs.original: TRAVELERS$NEWLINE$O, we are undone, both we and ours forever!
paragraphs.translated: TRAVELERS$NEWLINE$Oh! We’re done for!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hang, you gorbellied knaves! Are you undone? No, you fat chuffs. I would your store were here. On, bacons, on! What, you knaves, young men must live. You are grandjurors, are you? We’ll jure you, faith.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Damn it, you potbellied morons, are you finished? No, you fat misers. I wish everything you owned were here. Come on, pigs, come on! What, you idiots! Young men have to survive. You’re
Grand Jurors, aren’t you? Well here’s some justice for you!$NEWLINE$Grand Jurors$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Here they rob them and bind them. Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: The thieves rob the travelers and tie them up. They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY and POINS$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY and POINS enter.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$The thieves have bound the true men. Now could thou and I rob the thieves and go merrily to London, it would be argument for a week, laughter for a month, and a good jest forever.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$The thieves have tied up the honest men. If you and I can now rob the robbers and run laughing to London, we would talk about it for a week, laugh about it for a month, and it would be a hilarious story forever.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Stand close, I hear them coming.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Get down. I hear them coming.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY and POINS hide. Enter the thieves again$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY and POINS hide. The THIEVES return.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS$NEWLINE$THIEVES

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Come, my masters, let us share, and then to horse before day. An the Prince and Poins be not two arrant cowards, there’s no equity stirring. There’s no more valor in that Poins than in a wild duck.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Come on, boys, let’s divide up the spoils and then ride off before dawn. If the Prince and Poins aren’t cowards, there’s no justice in the universe. Poins is about as brave as a duck.

paragraphs.original: As they are sharing, PRINCE HENRY and POINS set upon them.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS
paragraphs.translated: As the thieves split the money, PRINCE HENRY and POINS attack them.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Your money!
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$(in disguise) Give us your money!$NEWLINE$(in disguise)

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Villains!
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$(in disguise) Crooks!$NEWLINE$(in disguise)

paragraphs.original: They all run away, and FALSTAFF , after a blow or two, runs away too, leaving the booty behind them.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: The thieves all run away. FALSTAFF fights for a moment, then runs away as well, leaving all of the money behind.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Got with much ease. Now merrily to horse.$NEWLINE$The thieves are all scattered, and possessed with fear$NEWLINE$So strongly that they dare not meet each other.$NEWLINE$Each takes his fellow for an officer.$NEWLINE$Away, good Ned. Falstaff sweats to death,$NEWLINE$And lards the lean earth as he walks along.$NEWLINE$Were ’t not for laughing, I should pity him.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Too easy. Now we ride off happily. The thieves have scattered, and they’re so terrified that they don’t even want to run into each other—they’ll each think that the other guy is an officer! Let’s go, Ned. Falstaff is sweating so hard that he’s watering the ground as he walks along. If I weren’t laughing so hard, I’d actually feel sorry for him.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$How the fat rogue roared!
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$How loud that fat rogue screamed!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter HOTSPURalone, reading a letter$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR enters alone, reading a letter.$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$But, for mine own part, my lord, I could be well contented to be there, in respect of the love I bear your house. He could be contented; why is he not, then? In respect of the love he bears our house—he shows in this he loves his own barn better than he loves our house. Let me see some more. The purpose you undertake is dangerous. Why, that’s certain. 'Tis dangerous to take a cold, to sleep, to drink; but I tell you, my lord fool, out of this nettle, danger, we pluck this flower, safety. The purpose you undertake is dangerous, the friends you have named uncertain, the time itself unsorted, and your whole plot too light for the counterpoise of so great an opposition. Say you so, say you so? I say unto you again, you are a shallow, cowardly hind, and you lie. What a lack-brain is this! By the Lord, our plot is a good plot as ever was laid, our friends true and constant—a good plot, good friends, and full of expectation; an excellent plot, very good friends. What a frosty-spirited rogue is this! Why, my Lord of York commends the plot and the general course of the action. Zounds, an I were now by this rascal, I could brain him with his lady’s fan. Is there not my father, my uncle, and myself? Lord Edmund Mortimer, my Lord of York, and Owen Glendower? Is there not besides the Douglas? Have I not all their letters to meet me in arms by the ninth of the next month, and are they not some of them set forward already? What a pagan rascal is this—an infidel! Ha, you shall see now in very sincerity of fear and cold heart, will he to the King and lay open all our proceedings. O, I could divide myself and go to buffets, for moving such a dish of skim milk with so honorable an action! Hang him, let him tell the King. We are prepared. I will set forward tonight.$NEWLINE$But, for mine own part, my lord, I could be well contented to$NEWLINE$be there, in respect of the love I bear your house.$NEWLINE$The purpose you undertake is dangerous.$NEWLINE$The purpose you undertake is dangerous, the friends you have named uncertain, the time itself unsorted, and your whole plot too light for the counterpoise of so great an$NEWLINE$opposition.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$“As for me, sir, I would be happy to be there because of the love I bear for your family.” He would be happy to be here. Well, why isn’t he, then? He says he loves my family, but he clearly loves his barn more than our house. I’ll read on. “Your plan is dangerous.” That’s true, and it’s also dangerous to catch a cold, to sleep, to drink. But I tell you, my lord fool, we shall pluck a flower of safety from this thorn of danger. “Your plan is dangerous; your allies untrustworthy; your timing poor; and your whole project too weak to counter so powerful an opponent.” Is that so? Is that so? I’ll say it once again: you are a stupid, cowardly dog, and a liar. What an idiot this is! By God, our plan is as good a plan as ever hatched, our allies loyal and firm. A good plan, good allies, and very promising; it’s an excellent plan, very good allies. What a yellowbellied fool this is! Why, the Archbishop of York approves of the plan, and how it’s progressing. Damn! If I were with this imbecile right now, I’d break his head open with his wife’s fan. Don’t we have my father? And my uncle, and me? Edmund Mortimer, York, and Owen Glendower? And besides, don’t we have Douglas? Haven’t they all sent me letters, promising to meet me with their armies by the ninth of next month? And aren’t some of them on their way already? What an unbelievable ass this is! Faithless! Ha! Just watch; he’ll run to the King in cold fear and spill our secrets. Oh, I could split myself in two and knock my own self senseless for unfolding this important plan to such a coward. To hell with him! Let him tell the King; we’re ready. I’ll set off tonight.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter his lady, LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$LADY PERCY
paragraphs.translated: His wife, LADY PERCY, enters.$NEWLINE$LADY PERCY

paragraphs.original: How now, Kate? I must leave you within these two hours.
paragraphs.translated: What is it, Kate? I must leave you in a few hours.

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$O my good lord, why are you thus alone?$NEWLINE$For what offense have I this fortnight been$NEWLINE$A banished woman from my Harry’s bed?$NEWLINE$Tell me, sweet lord, what is ’t that takes from thee$NEWLINE$Thy stomach, pleasure, and thy golden sleep?$NEWLINE$Why dost thou bend thine eyes upon the earth$NEWLINE$And start so often when thou sit’st alone?$NEWLINE$Why hast thou lost the fresh blood in thy cheeks$NEWLINE$And given my treasures and my rights of thee$NEWLINE$To thick-eyed musing and curst melancholy?$NEWLINE$In thy faint slumbers I by thee have watched,$NEWLINE$And heard thee murmur tales of iron wars,$NEWLINE$Speak terms of manage to thy bounding steed,$NEWLINE$Cry “Courage! To the field!” And thou hast talk’d$NEWLINE$Of sallies and retires, of trenches, tents,$NEWLINE$Of palisadoes, frontiers, parapets,$NEWLINE$Of basilisks, of cannon, culverin,$NEWLINE$Of prisoners' ransom and of soldiers slain,$NEWLINE$And all the currents of a heady fight.$NEWLINE$Thy spirit within thee hath been so at war,$NEWLINE$And thus hath so bestirred thee in thy sleep,$NEWLINE$That beads of sweat have stood upon thy brow$NEWLINE$Like bubbles in a late-disturbèd stream,$NEWLINE$And in thy face strange motions have appeared,$NEWLINE$Such as we see when men restrain their breath$NEWLINE$On some great sudden hest. O, what portents are these?$NEWLINE$Some heavy business hath my lord in hand,$NEWLINE$And I must know it, else he loves me not.
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Oh, my good lord, why are you alone like this? What have I done to make my Harry banish me from his bed these past two weeks? Tell me, sweet husband, what has stolen your appetite, your desire, and your sleep? Why do you stare at the ground and jump in your skin when you are sitting alone? Where is the color in your cheeks? Why have you taken all your attention, which should be mine, and given it to this dark mood and terrible sadness? While you sleep so lightly, I’ve watched you and heard you mumble stories of war. I’ve heard you give commands to your horse. I’ve heard you yell, “Courage! To the field!” And you have talked of charges and retreats; of trenches, tents; of fences, ramparts, and walls; of all types of cannon; of prisoners' ransoms and of dead soldiers, and of all the movements of a violent battle. Your soul has also been at war and has disturbed you in your sleep. Beads of sweat have broken out on your forehead, like bubbles in a churning stream. And on your face I’ve seen strange expressions, like a man who’s gulping his breath at an awful, sudden command. Oh, what does all this mean? My lord is contemplating some serious matters, and if he doesn’t tell me about them, he surely doesn’t love me.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$What, ho!
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$You there!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: A SERVANT enters.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: Is Gilliams with the packet gone?
paragraphs.translated: Has Gilliams left with my letters?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$He is, my lord, an hour ago.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$He has, my lord, an hour ago.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Hath Butler brought those horses from the sheriff?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Did Butler bring those horses from the sheriff?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$One horse, my lord, he brought even now.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$He brought one of them just now.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$What horse? A roan, a crop-ear, is it not?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Which one? A brown one, right? With its ears clipped?

paragraphs.original: SERVANT$NEWLINE$It is, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: SERVANT$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$That roan shall be my throne.$NEWLINE$Well, I will back him straight. O, Esperance!$NEWLINE$Bid Butler lead him forth into the park.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$That brown horse will be my throne. I’ll mount him in a second. Oh, “Hope is my Comfort!” Tell Butler to walk him out in the fields.

paragraphs.original: Exit SERVANT$NEWLINE$SERVANT
paragraphs.translated: The SERVANT exits.$NEWLINE$SERVANT

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$But hear you, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Listen, my lord.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$What say’st thou, my lady?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$What is it, my lady?

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$What is it carries you away?
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$What is it that’s got you so carried away?

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Why, my horse,$NEWLINE$My love, my horse.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$My horse, my love. My horse.

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Out, you mad-headed ape!$NEWLINE$A weasel hath not such a deal of spleen$NEWLINE$As you are tossed with. In faith,$NEWLINE$I’ll know your business, Harry, that I will.$NEWLINE$I fear my brother Mortimer doth stir$NEWLINE$About his title, and hath sent for you$NEWLINE$To line his enterprise; but if you go—
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Enough, you crazy fool! Not even a weasel is as hotheaded as you are. I swear, I’ll find out what you’re up to, Harry, I will. I fear that my brother, Mortimer, is making some kind of move over his claim to the throne, and has asked you to help. But if you go—

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$—So far afoot, I shall be weary, love.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$—such a long way on foot, I’ll be tired.

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Come, come, you paraquito, answer me$NEWLINE$Directly unto this question that I ask.$NEWLINE$In faith, I’ll break thy little finger, Harry,$NEWLINE$An if thou wilt not tell me all things true.
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Stop it, you little parrot. Answer me straight. I swear, Harry, I’ll break your little finger if you don’t tell me everything, and the truth, too.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Away!$NEWLINE$Away, you trifler. Love, I love thee not.$NEWLINE$I care not for thee, Kate. This is no world$NEWLINE$To play with mammets and to tilt with lips.$NEWLINE$We must have bloody noses and cracked crowns,$NEWLINE$And pass them current too.—Gods me, my horse!—$NEWLINE$What say’st thou, Kate? What would’st thou have with me?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Get away from me, you nag! Love? I don’t love you. I don’t even care about you, Kate. This is no time for playing with dolls and jousting with kisses; we’ll have bloody noses and broken heads, and spread them around, too. For God’s sake, my horse! What, Kate? What do you want from me?

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Do you not love me? Do you not indeed?$NEWLINE$Well, do not then, for since you love me not,$NEWLINE$I will not love myself. Do you not love me?$NEWLINE$Nay, tell me if you speak in jest or no.
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$You don’t love me? Really, you don’t? Well, fine then; don’t love me. And since you don’t love me, I won’t love myself. You don’t love me? Seriously, tell me if you’re joking or if you mean it.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Come, wilt thou see me ride?$NEWLINE$And when I am a-horseback, I will swear$NEWLINE$I love thee infinitely. But hark you, Kate,$NEWLINE$I must not have you henceforth question me$NEWLINE$Whither I go, nor reason whereabout.$NEWLINE$Whither I must, I must; and to conclude,$NEWLINE$This evening must I leave you, gentle Kate.$NEWLINE$I know you wise, but yet no farther wise$NEWLINE$Than Harry Percy’s wife; constant you are,$NEWLINE$But yet a woman; and for secrecy$NEWLINE$No lady closer, for I well believe$NEWLINE$Thou wilt not utter what thou dost not know,$NEWLINE$And so far will I trust thee, gentle Kate.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Will you see me off? Once I’m on my horse, I’ll swear I love you till the end of time. But listen here, Kate. From now on, I won’t have you asking me where I’m going, nor guessing why I’m doing what I’m doing. I must go where I must go. This is final: tonight I must leave you, sweet Kate. I know you are wise, but your wisdom doesn’t go further than your role as my wife. You may be able to keep a secret, but you’re still a woman; and yet no woman can keep secrets like you, because you cannot reveal what you don’t actually know. And that is as far as I will trust you, sweet Kate.

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$How? So far?
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Oh really? That far?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Not an inch further. But hark you, Kate,$NEWLINE$Whither I go, thither shall you go too.$NEWLINE$Today will I set forth, tomorrow you.$NEWLINE$Will this content you, Kate?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Not an inch further. But listen here, Kate. Wherever I go, you will go too. I leave today, and tomorrow, you. Will this make you content, Kate?

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$It must, of force.
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$It must.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY and POINS$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY and POINS enter.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$POINS

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Ned, prithee, come out of that fat room and lend me thy hand to laugh a little.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Ned, come out of that airless room and help me laugh a bit.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Where hast been, Hal?
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Where’ve you been, Hal?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$With three or four loggerheads amongst three or fourscore hogsheads. I have sounded the very bass string of humility. Sirrah, I am sworn brother to a leash of drawers, and can call them all by their christen names, as Tom, Dick, and Francis. They take it already upon their salvation that though I be but Prince of Wales, yet I am the king of courtesy, and tell me flatly am no proud jack, like Falstaff, but a Corinthian, a lad of mettle, a good boy—by the Lord, so they call me—and when I am King of England, I shall command all the good lads in Eastcheap. They call drinking deep “dyeing scarlet,” and when you breathe in your watering, they cry “Hem!” and bid you “Play it off!” To conclude, I am so good a proficient in one quarter of an hour that I can drink with any tinker in his own language during my life. I tell thee, Ned, thou hast lost much honor that thou wert not with me in this action; but, sweet Ned—to sweeten which name of Ned, I give thee this pennyworth of sugar, clapped even now into my hand by an underskinker, one that never spake other English in his life than “Eight shillings and sixpence,” and “You are welcome,” with this shrill addition, “Anon, anon, sir.—Score a pint of bastard in the Half-moon,” or so. But, Ned, to drive away the time till Falstaff come, I prithee, do thou stand in some by-room while I question my puny drawer to what end he gave me the sugar; and do thou never leave calling “Francis,” that his tale to me may be nothing but “Anon.” Step aside, and I’ll show thee a precedent.
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$With three or four knuckleheads and a few dozen kegs of liquor. I’ve been with the lowest of the low. Sirrah, I’ve made great friends with these three bartenders, and I’m on a first-name basis with them: Tom, Dick, and Francis. They swear on their souls that, even though I’m only the Prince of Wales, I’m the king of niceness. They say I’m no pompous fool, like Falstaff, but a good sport, a spirited man, a good boy. When I’m King of England, all the good men of Eastcheap will follow me gladly. When you drink deeply, they joke that you have been dyed red; and if you stop for a breath when you’re drinking, they yell “Cough!” and they command you to keep going. In fifteen minutes, I got so good at being a drinking companion, I could be at ease with any man over a drink, in any setting. Ned, you didn’t do yourself any favors by missing this. But, sweet Ned, I’ll sweeten the name Ned with this bit of sugar, given to me by an apprentice
drawer who never spoke any English his whole life, except, “That’ll be eight shillings and sixpence,” and “You’re welcome,” and also, “Just a second, just a second! Bring a pint of
bastard to the
Half-Moon room!” But Ned, let’s pass the time until Falstaff gets here. Hide in a side room while I ask that little apprentice drawer why he gave me the sugar. Keep calling out his name, Francis, and don’t stop, so that all he’s able to say is, “Just a second!” Step aside, and I’ll give you a taste.$NEWLINE$drawer$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$bastard$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Half-Moon$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit POINS$NEWLINE$POINS
paragraphs.translated: POINS exits.$NEWLINE$POINS

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$(within) Francis!$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$(offstage) Francis!$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Thou art perfect.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Perfect.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$(within) Francis!$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$(offstage) Francis!$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: Enter FRANCIS, a drawer$NEWLINE$FRANCIS
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS, a drawer, enters.$NEWLINE$FRANCIS

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Anon, anon, sir.—Look down into the Pomgarnet, Ralph.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Just a second, sir.—Ralph, make sure everything’s okay in the Pomegranate Room!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Come hither, Francis.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Come here, Francis.

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$My lord?
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Sir?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How long hast thou to serve, Francis?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How many more years of your apprenticeship do you have, Francis?

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Forsooth, five years, and as much as to—
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Truly, five years, which is as long —

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$(within) Francis!$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$(offstage) Francis!$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Anon, anon, sir.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Just a second, sir!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Five year! By 'r lady, a long lease for the clinking of pewter! But, Francis, darest thou be so valiant as to play the coward with thy indenture, and show it a fair pair of heels, and run from it?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Five years! Wow, that’s a long time to be clinking beer mugs. But Francis, are you brave enough to play the coward with your contract? To flash it your heels, as you run away?

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$O Lord, sir, I’ll be sworn upon all the books in England, I could find in my heart—
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Oh Lord, sir. I’d swear on a stack of Bibles that I’d love to be able to—

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$(within) Francis!$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$(offstage) Francis!$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Anon, sir.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Just a second, sir!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How old art thou, Francis?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How old are you, Francis?

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Let me see. About Michaelmas next, I shall be—
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Let’s see—at the end of next September, I’ll be—

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$(within) Francis!$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$(offstage) Francis!$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Anon, sir. (to PRINCE HENRY) Pray, stay a little, my lord.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Just a second, sir! (to PRINCE HENRY ) Wait here a moment, my lord.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Nay, but hark you, Francis, for the sugar thou gavest me,’twas a pennyworth, was ’t not?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$No, listen to me, Francis. The sugar you gave me was worth about a penny, right?

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$O Lord, I would it had been two!
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Oh lord, I wish I could have given you two pennies' worth!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I will give thee for it a thousand pound. Ask me when thou wilt, and thou shalt have it.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I’ll give you a thousand pounds for it. Ask for it whenever you want it, and it’s yours.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$(within) Francis!$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$(offstage) Francis!$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Anon, anon.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Just a second!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Anon, Francis? No, Francis, but tomorrow, Francis; or,$NEWLINE$Francis, o' Thursday; or indeed, Francis, when thou wilt.$NEWLINE$But, Francis—
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You want it in a second, Francis? No, Francis. Maybe tomorrow, Francis, or Thursday, Francis, whenever you want it. But, Francis.

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$My lord?
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Sir?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Wilt thou rob this leathern jerkin, crystal-button, not-pated, agate-ring, puke-stocking, caddis-garter, smooth-tongue, Spanish-pouch—
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Are you ready to rob
this man? This man, with his leather jacket, fashionable crystal buttons, short hair, agate signet ring, dark stockings, ribboned garters, oily speech, Spanish leather pouch—$NEWLINE$this man?$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$O Lord, sir, who do you mean?
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Oh Lord, sir, who are you talking about?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, then, your brown bastard is your only drink, for look you, Francis, your white canvas doublet will sully. In Barbary, sir, it cannot come to so much.
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well then, it looks like
brown bastard will continue to be your only drink. Because listen, Francis, your white canvas shirt will get stained out there. Even in North Africa, sir, you won’t get so much.$NEWLINE$brown bastard$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$What, sir?
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Excuse me, sir?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$(within) Francis!$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$(offstage) Francis!$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Away, you rogue! Dost thou not hear them call?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Get going, you good-for-nothing. Can’t you hear people calling you?

paragraphs.original: Here they both call him. FRANCIS the drawer stands amazed, not knowing which way to go.$NEWLINE$FRANCIS
paragraphs.translated: POINS and PRINCE HENRY both begin to shout “Francis!” FRANCIS stands there bewildered, not knowing what to do.$NEWLINE$POINS$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$FRANCIS

paragraphs.original: Enter VINTNER$NEWLINE$VINTNER
paragraphs.translated:
The
VINTNER enters.$NEWLINE$VINTNER$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VINTNER$NEWLINE$What, stand’st thou still and hear’st such a calling? Look to the guests within.
paragraphs.translated: VINTNER$NEWLINE$Why are you standing there when people are calling you? Take care of the customers inside!

paragraphs.original: Exit FRANCIS$NEWLINE$FRANCIS
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS exits.$NEWLINE$FRANCIS

paragraphs.original: My lord, old Sir John with half a dozen more are at the door.$NEWLINE$Shall I let them in?
paragraphs.translated: My lord, old Sir John and a half-dozen others are at the door. Should I let them in?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Let them alone awhile, and then open the door.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Leave them out there for a while, and then open the door.

paragraphs.original: Exit VINTNER$NEWLINE$VINTNER
paragraphs.translated: VINTNER exits.$NEWLINE$VINTNER

paragraphs.original: Poins!
paragraphs.translated: Poins!

paragraphs.original: Reenter POINS$NEWLINE$POINS
paragraphs.translated: POINS enters.$NEWLINE$POINS

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Anon, anon, sir.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Just a second, sir!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Sirrah, Falstaff and the rest of the thieves are at the door.$NEWLINE$Shall we be merry?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Sirrah, Falstaff and the rest of the thieves are here. Are we ready for a laugh?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$As merry as crickets, my lad. But hark you, what cunning match have you made with this jest of the drawer. Come, what’s the issue?
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$We’ll be happy as crickets, my lad. But listen, what’s with this gag you played on the waiter? What’s the point?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I am now of all humors that have showed themselves humors since the old days of Goodman Adam to the pupil age of this present twelve o'clock at midnight.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I’m up for anything. Right now, I’m feeling all the moods that anyone has ever felt, from the old days of Adam to this young age, right now, at twelve o'clock midnight.

paragraphs.original: Enter FRANCIS$NEWLINE$FRANCIS
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS enters.$NEWLINE$FRANCIS

paragraphs.original: What’s o'clock, Francis?
paragraphs.translated: What time is it, Francis?

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Anon, anon, sir.
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS$NEWLINE$Just a second, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit FRANCIS$NEWLINE$FRANCIS
paragraphs.translated: FRANCIS exits.$NEWLINE$FRANCIS

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$That ever this fellow should have fewer words than a parrot, and yet the son of a woman! His industry is upstairs and downstairs, his eloquence the parcel of a reckoning. I am not yet of Percy’s mind, the Hotspur of the north, he that kills me some six or seven dozen of Scots at a breakfast, washes his hands, and says to his wife “Fie upon this quiet life! I want work.” “O my sweet Harry,” says she, “how many hast thou killed today?” “Give my roan horse a drench,” says he, and answers “Some fourteen,” an hour after. “A trifle, a trifle.” I prithee, call in Falstaff. I’ll play Percy, and that damned brawn shall play Dame Mortimer his wife. “Rivo!” says the drunkard. Call in Ribs, call in Tallow.$NEWLINE$“Rivo!”
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$This boy has fewer words than a parrot, but he’s actually a person! All he does is run up and down stairs, and the only things he can say are the names of the items on your bill. I’m not yet like Percy, the Hotspur of the North. He kills six or seven dozen Scotsmen before breakfast, washes his hands, and then says to his wife, “To hell with this boring life! I need something to do!” “Oh, my sweet Harry,” she says, “How many have you killed today?” “Give my brown horse a dose of medicine,” he says. And then about an hour later, he answers her: “About fourteen.” Then he says, “That’s nothing, nothing.” Listen, bring in Falstaff. I’ll play Percy, and that damned fat slob will play his wife, Dame Mortimer. “Bottom’s up!” as the drunk says. Bring in the meat, bring in blubber.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF, GADSHILL, PETO, and BARDOLPH, followed by FRANCIS with wine$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$GADSHILL$NEWLINE$PETO$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$FRANCIS
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF , GADSHILL, BARDOLPH, and PETO enter. FRANCIS follows with wine.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$GADSHILL$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PETO$NEWLINE$FRANCIS

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Welcome, Jack. Where hast thou been?
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Welcome, Jack. Where’ve you been?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A plague of all cowards, I say, and a vengeance too! Marry and amen!—Give me a cup of sack, boy.—Ere I lead this life long, I’ll sew netherstocks and mend them, and foot them too. A plague of all cowards!—Give me a cup of sack, rogue. —Is there no virtue extant? (he drinketh)$NEWLINE$(he drinketh)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A curse on all cowards, I say, and revenge on them, too! Amen to that! Give me some wine, boy. I’m not going to keep up this way of life much longer. I’ll knit socks, mend them, and fix their feet. A curse on all cowards! Give me a cup of wine, you lowlife! Isn’t there any honesty left in this world? (he drinks)$NEWLINE$(he drinks)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Didst thou never see Titan kiss a dish of butter?—Pitiful- hearted Titan!—that melted at the sweet tale of the sun’s? If thou didst, then behold that compound.
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Did you ever see the sun kiss a dish of
butter? The tender-hearted sun, melting the butter with its sweet words! If you have, then take a look at Falstaff.$NEWLINE$butter?$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(to FRANCIS ) You rogue, here’s lime in this sack too.—There is nothing but roguery to be found in villanous man, yet a coward is worse than a cup of sack with lime in it. A villanous coward! Go thy ways, old Jack. Die when thou wilt. If manhood, good manhood, be not forgot upon the face of the earth, then am I a shotten herring. There lives not three good men unhanged in England, and one of them is fat and grows old, God help the while. A bad world, I say. I would I were a weaver. I could sing psalms, or anything. A plague of all cowards, I say still.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(to FRANCIS ) You bastard! Somebody put
lime in my wine! All men are cheaters and schemers, but a coward is worse than a glass of wine with lime in it. A miserable coward! Go on, old Jack, die already. If there’s even one real man left on this earth besides me, then I’m as skinny as a herring. In all of England there are only three good men that haven’t been put to death, and one of them is fat and growing old. God help us all! It’s a bad world, I say. I wish I were a weaver; I could sing psalms while I was sewing. I’ll say it again: a curse on all cowards.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$lime$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How now, woolsack, what mutter you?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What’s the matter, you sack of wool? What are you muttering about?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A King’s son! If I do not beat thee out of thy kingdom with a dagger of lath, and drive all thy subjects afore thee like a flock of wild geese, I’ll never wear hair on my face more. You, Prince of Wales!
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A King’s son! If I don’t drive you out of the kingdom with a
wooden dagger, and send your subjects running before you like a flock of geese, then I’ll never grow a beard again. You, Prince of Wales? What a joke!$NEWLINE$wooden dagger$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, you whoreson round man, what’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You fat son of a whore, what’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Are not you a coward? Answer me to that—and Poins there?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Aren’t you a coward? Tell me that. And Poins there?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Zounds, ye fat paunch, an you call me coward, by the Lord,$NEWLINE$I’ll stab thee.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Dammit, you fat belly. If you call me a coward, I swear, I’ll stab you.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I call thee coward? I’ll see thee damned ere I call thee coward, but I would give a thousand pound I could run as fast as thou canst. You are straight enough in the shoulders you care not who sees your back. Call you that backing of your friends? A plague upon such backing! Give me them that will face me.—Give me a cup of sack.—I am a rogue if I drunk today.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I call you coward? I’d sooner see you damned than call you a coward, but I tell you; I’d give a thousand pounds to be able to run as fast as you can. You’ve got good-enough–;looking shoulders; you don’t care who sees your back! Is that what you call backing up your friends? Damn anyone who backs up like that! I’d rather have a man who faces me. Give me some wine! I’ll be damned if I’ve had anything to drink today.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$O villain, thy lips are scarce wiped since thou drunk’st last.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Liar! You’ve barely had time to wipe your lips since your last drink.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$All is one for that. (he drinketh) A plague of all cowards, still say I.$NEWLINE$(he drinketh)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Whatever. (he drinks) A curse on all cowards, I still say.$NEWLINE$(he drinks)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What’s the matter? There be four of us here have ta'en a thousand pound this day morning.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What’s the matter? There are four of us here who stole a thousand pounds this very morning.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Where is it, Jack? Where is it?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Where is it, Jack? Where is it?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Where is it? Taken from us it is. A hundred upon poor four of us.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Where is it? It was stolen from us. A hundred men against only four of us.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What, a hundred, man?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What, a hundred, man?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I am a rogue if I were not at half-sword with a dozen of them two hours together. I have ’scaped by miracle. I am eight times thrust through the doublet, four through the hose, my buckler cut through and through, my sword hacked like a handsaw. Ecce signum! I never dealt better since I was a man. All would not do. A plague of all cowards! (points to GADSHILL, PETO and BARDOLPH ) Let them speak. If they speak more or less than truth, they are villains, and the sons of darkness.$NEWLINE$Ecce signum!$NEWLINE$(points to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’ll be damned if I didn’t fight with a dozen of them for two straight hours. It’s a miracle I managed to get away. They stabbed through my shirt eight times. Four through my pants. My shield’s got holes through and through. My sword’s as cut up as a hacksaw. Behold the evidence! It was the best fighting I’ve ever done, but even my all wasn’t enough. A curse on all cowards! (points to GADSHILL, PETO and BARDOLPH) Ask these men. If they don’t tell you the whole truth, they’re liars and devils.$NEWLINE$(points to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Speak, sirs, how was it?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Tell us, men. What happened?

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$We four set upon some dozen.
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$The four of us jumped about a dozen—

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Sixteen at least, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Sixteen at least, my lord.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$And bound them.
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$And tied them up.

paragraphs.original: PETO$NEWLINE$No, no, they were not bound.
paragraphs.translated: PETO$NEWLINE$No, no. We didn’t tie them up.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You rogue, they were bound, every man of them, or I am a$NEWLINE$Jew else, an Ebrew Jew.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You jerk, we did tie them up, every single one of them, or I’m a Jew, a true Hebrew Jew.

paragraphs.original: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$As we were sharing, some six or seven fresh men set upon us.
paragraphs.translated: GADSHILL$NEWLINE$Then, when we were dividing the money, about six or seven other men jumped us—

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$And unbound the rest, and then come in the other.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$And untied the rest, and then all the others showed up.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What, fought you with them all?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What, you fought with all of them?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$All? I know not what you call all, but if I fought not with fifty of them I am a bunch of radish. If there were not two- or hree-and-fifty upon poor old Jack, then am I no two-legged creature.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$All? I don’t know what you mean by “all.” But if I didn’t fight with fifty of them, I’m a bunch of radishes. If fifty-two or fifty-three of them didn’t attack me, then I’m no man.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Pray God you have not murdered some of them.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I pray to God you didn’t kill any of them.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Nay, that’s past praying for. I have peppered two of them. Two I am sure I have paid, two rogues in buckram suits. I tell thee what, Hal, if I tell thee a lie, spit in my face, call me horse. Thou knowest my old ward. Here I lay, and thus I bore my point. Four rogues in buckram let drive at me.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Too late for praying now. I made things hot for two of them; two I’m sure I got, two thugs wearing clothes made of buckram cloth. I’ll tell you what, Hal: if I’m lying to you, spit in my face and call me a horse. You know my old fighting stance. Here’s how I stood, and here’s how I handled my sword. Four thugs in buckram came right at me—

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What, four? Thou saidst but two even now.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What? Four? You said two a second ago.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Four, Hal, I told thee four.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Four, Hal. I said four.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Ay, ay, he said four.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$That’s right. He said four.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$These four came all afront, and mainly thrust at me. I made me no more ado, but took all their seven points in my target, thus.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$These four threw everything they had right at me. I made no big fuss of it; I just put up my shield and all seven of their swords hit it.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Seven? Why there were but four even now.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Seven? But just now there were only four.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$In buckram?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Wearing buckram?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Ay, four in buckram suits.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Yes. Four in clothes made of buckram.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Seven, by these hilts, or I am a villain else.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Seven, I swear on my sword. If not, I’m a liar.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$(aside to POINS ) Prithee, let him alone. We shall have more anon.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$(to POINS , so no one else can hear) Leave him alone. There’ll be more in a minute.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$, so no one else can hear)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Dost thou hear me, Hal?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Are you listening to me, Hal?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Ay, and mark thee too, Jack.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I’m listening, Jack.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Do so, for it is worth the listening to. These nine in buckram that I told thee of—
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Good, because it’s worth paying attention to. Anyway, these nine guys in buckram that I told you about—

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$So, two more already.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$So, two more already.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Their points being broken—
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Since their points were broken—

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Down fell their hose.
paragraphs.translated:
POINS$NEWLINE$Their
stockings fell down.$NEWLINE$stockings$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Began to give me ground, but I followed me close, came in foot and hand, and with a thought, seven of the eleven I paid.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$They started to run away, but I followed them closely. And as quick as a thought, I finished off seven of the eleven.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$O monstrous! Eleven buckram men grown out of two!
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Unbelievable! Eleven buckram men have grown out of two!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$But as the devil would have it, three misbegotten knaves in Kendal green came at my back, and let drive at me, for it was so dark, Hal, that thou couldst not see thy hand.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$But as the devil would have it, three wretched bastards wearing green came from behind and ran right at me. It was so dark, Hal, that you couldn’t see your hand in front of your face.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$These lies are like their father that begets them, gross as a mountain, open, palpable. Why, thou claybrained guts, thou knotty-pated fool, thou whoreson, obscene, greasy tallow- catch—
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$These lies are like the man who tells them: huge as a mountain, obvious, and plain as day. You clay-brained fatso, you knuckleheaded fool, you son of a whore, you obscene tub of lard—

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What, art thou mad? Art thou mad? Is not the truth the truth?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What are you, crazy? Are you crazy? Isn’t the truth the truth?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, how couldst thou know these men in Kendal green, when it was so dark thou couldst not see thy hand? Come, tell us your reason. What sayest thou to this?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, how could you know that these men were wearing green when it was so dark you couldn’t see your hand in front of your face? Go ahead, tell us. What do you have to say to that?

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Come, your reason, Jack, your reason.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Come on, tell us, Jack, go on.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What, upon compulsion? Zounds, an I were at the strappado or all the racks in the world, I would not tell you on compulsion. Give you a reason on compulsion? If reasons were as plentiful as blackberries, I would give no man a reason upon compulsion, I.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What, just because you command me? Dammit, if I were being tortured on all the contraptions in the world, I wouldn’t speak just because you commanded. Speak just because you command! If my reasons were as cheap as blackberries, I wouldn’t give away my reasons just because I was commanded. Not I.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I’ll be no longer guilty of this sin. This sanguine coward, this bed-presser, this horseback-breaker, this huge hill of flesh—
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I’m not going to put up with this any longer. This red-faced coward, this flattener of mattresses, this breaker of horses' backs, this huge hill of flesh—

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$'Sblood, you starveling, you elfskin, you dried neat’s tongue, you bull’s pizzle, you stockfish! O, for breath to utter what is like thee! You tailor’s-yard, you sheath, you bowcase, you vile standing tuck—
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Dammit! You scarecrow, you skin of an elf, you dried-out ox’s tongue, you bull’s penis, you salted cod! Oh, I wish I had enough breath to tell you all the things you are! You yardstick, you empty sheath, you case for a violinist’s bow, you disgusting erect sword—

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, breathe awhile, and then to it again, and when thou hast tired thyself in base comparisons, hear me speak but this.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Catch your breath for a moment, then start again. And when you’ve tired yourself with these awful comparisons, listen to me say just one thing.

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Mark, Jack.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Listen closely, Jack.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$We two saw you four set on four, and bound them and were masters of their wealth. Mark now how a plain tale shall put you down. Then did we two set on you four and, with a word, outfaced you from your prize, and have it; yea, and can show it you here in the house. And, Falstaff, you carried your guts away as nimbly, with as quick dexterity, and roared for mercy, and still run and roared, as ever I heard bull-calf. What a slave art thou to hack thy sword as thou hast done, and then say it was in fight! What trick, what device, what starting-hole canst thou now find out to hide thee from this open and apparent shame?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$The two of us saw you four jump four men, tie them up and take their money. Now listen to how the simple truth will shame you. Then the two of us jumped the four of you. And with just a word, we stole your prize from you. Now we have it, and we can show it to you right here in the bar. And Falstaff, you ran away as quickly and as lightfootedly, as a cow from the slaughter, screaming for mercy, as you ran and screamed. What a lowlife you are, to hack up your sword and say it happened in a fight! What outrageous story, what trick, what hiding place can you possibly find to hide you from your open and obvious shame?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Come, let’s hear, Jack. What trick hast thou now?
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Come on, let’s hear it, Jack. What trick have you got now?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$By the Lord, I knew you as well as he that made you. Why, hear you, my masters, was it for me to kill the heir apparent? Should I turn upon the true Prince? Why, thou knowest I am as valiant as Hercules, but beware instinct. The lion will not touch the true Prince. Instinct is a great matter. I was now a coward on instinct. I shall think the better of myself, and thee, during my life—I for a valiant lion, and thou for a true Prince. But, by the Lord, lads, I am glad you have the money.—Hostess, clap to the doors.— Watch tonight, pray to-morrow. Gallants, lads, boys, hearts of gold, all the titles of good fellowship come to you. What, shall we be merry? hall we have a play extempore?
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$By God, I knew it was you the whole time, like I was your own father! Listen to me, men: would it be right for me to kill the heir-apparent? Should I have attacked the true Prince? Look, you know I’m as brave as
Hercules, but you must listen to your instinct. It’s like that old superstition, about how a lion will never attack a true Prince. Instinct is a powerful thing; I was only a coward by instinct. From now on, I’ll have to think of myself as a brave lion, and you as a true Prince. But good God, men, I’m glad you have the money. Hostess! Lock the doors; we’ll celebrate tonight and pray tomorrow. Gentlemen, lads, boys, hearts of gold—I’ll call you every good name I can think of, all at once! Hey! Shall we have some fun? Shall we stage a little play?$NEWLINE$Hercules$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Content, and the argument shall be thy running away.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Of course, and the play will be about you running away.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Ah, no more of that, Hal, an thou lovest me.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Oh, let it go, Hal, if you love me.

paragraphs.original: Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY enters.$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O Jesu, my lord the Prince!
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Oh, Jesus—Your Majesty!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How now, my lady the hostess, what sayest thou to me?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Hello there, my lady the hostess! Do you have something to say to me?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Marry, my lord, there is a nobleman of the court at door would speak with you. He says he comes from your father.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Indeed, my lord. There’s a nobleman from the royal court at the door, and he wants to speak with you. He says your father sent him.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Give him as much as will make him a royal man and send him back again to my mother.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Give him some coins and send him right back to my mother.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What manner of man is he?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What kind of man is he?

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$An old man.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$An old man.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What doth Gravity out of his bed at midnight? Shall I give him his answer?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What is an old man doing out of bed at midnight? Do you want me to talk to him?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Prithee do, Jack.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Please do, Jack.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Faith, and I’ll send him packing.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Truly, I’ll send him on his way.

paragraphs.original: Exit FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF exits.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Now, sirs. By 'r lady, you fought fair.—So did you, Peto.— So did you, Bardolph.—You are lions too. You ran away upon instinct. You will not touch the true Prince. No, fie!
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Now, men: by God, you fought well. So did you, Peto, and you, Bardolph. You must be lions, too, since your instinct told you to run away. You wouldn’t touch the true Prince; no, indeed!

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Faith, I ran when I saw others run.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Honestly, I ran when I saw the others run.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Faith, tell me now in earnest, how came Falstaff’s sword so hacked?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Okay, now tell me the truth. How did Falstaff’s sword get broken like that?

paragraphs.original: PETO$NEWLINE$Why, he hacked it with his dagger and said he would swear truth out of England but he would make you believe it was done in fight, and persuaded us to do the like.
paragraphs.translated: PETO$NEWLINE$He hacked away at it with his dagger. He said he would swear up and down to make you believe that it happened in a fight, and he made us do the same.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yea, and to tickle our noses with speargrass to make them bleed, and then to beslubber our garments with it, and swear it was the blood of true men. I did that I did not this seven year before: I blushed to hear his monstrous devices.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yes, and he made us rub our noses with rough weeds until they started to bleed, then smear our clothes with the blood and swear that it was from the men we fought. When he told me the crazy things he wanted us to do, I did something I haven’t done in seven years: I blushed.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$O villain, thou stolest a cup of sack eighteen years ago, and wert taken with the manner, and ever since thou hast blushed extempore. Thou hadst fire and sword on thy side, and yet thou ran’st away. What instinct hadst thou for it?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Liar! You stole a cup of wine eighteen years ago, got caught in the act, and you’ve been blushing ever since. You had your fiery-red face and your weapons going for you, but still you ran away. What instinct made you do that?

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$My lord, do you see these meteors? Do you behold these exhalations?
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Sir, do you see these red welts on my face? Do you see these swellings?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I do.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I do.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$What think you they portend?
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$What do you think they mean?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Hot livers and cold purses.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$That your temper is hot and your wallet is empty.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Choler, my lord, if rightly taken.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$It means anger, sir, you interpret it correctly.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$No, if rightly taken, halter.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$It means you’ll be hanged if the authorities catch you.

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF enters.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: Here comes lean Jack. Here comes bare-bone.—How now, my sweet creature of bombast? How long is ’t ago, Jack, since thou sawest thine own knee?
paragraphs.translated: Here comes skinny Jack; here comes the bag of bones. What’s going on, now, my sweet windbag? How long has it been, Jack, since you saw your own knees?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My own knee? When I was about thy years, Hal, I was not an eagle’s talon in the waist. I could have crept into any alderman’s thumb-ring. A plague of sighing and grief! It blows a man up like a bladder. There’s villanous news abroad. Here was Sir John Bracy from your father. You must to the court in the morning. That same mad fellow of the north, Percy, and he of Wales that gave Amamon the bastinado, and made Lucifer cuckold, and swore the devil his true liegeman upon the cross of a Welsh hook—what a plague call you him?
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My own knees? When I was your age, Hal, my waist was as skinny as an eagle’s talon; I could have crawled through a councilman’s thumb ring. But damn all that sighing and sadness! It blows a man up like a balloon. There’s bad news out there. That was Sir John Bracy, sent by your father. You have to go to court in the morning. Percy, that mad man from up north, and that Welshman who gave
Amamon a beating, and stole Lucifer’s wife, and made a pact to be the devil’s master—what’s his name again?$NEWLINE$Amamon$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: POINS$NEWLINE$Owen Glendower.
paragraphs.translated: POINS$NEWLINE$Oh, Glendower.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Owen, Owen, the same, and his son-in-law Mortimer, and old Northumberland, and that sprightly Scot of Scots, Douglas, that runs a-horseback up a hill perpendicular—
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Owen, Owen, that’s the one. And his son-in-law Mortimer, and old Northumberland, and Douglas, that lively Scot of Scots, who can ride a horse straight up a wall—

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$He that rides at high speed, and with his pistol kills a sparrow flying.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$The man who can ride at high speeds, then kill a flying sparrow with his pistol.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You have hit it.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You’ve hit it; that’s him exactly.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$So did he never the sparrow.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I may have hit it, but Owen never hit the sparrow.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, that rascal hath good mettle in him. He will not run.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, that rascal has bravery in him; he won’t run away.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, what a rascal art thou then to praise him so for running?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, you rascal! You just praised him for running!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A-horseback, you cuckoo, but afoot he will not budge a foot.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$He’ll run on his horse, you cuckoo. But when fighting on foot, he’ll never budge.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Yes, Jack, upon instinct.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Yes he will, Jack. By instinct.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I grant you, upon instinct. Well, he is there too, and one Mordake, and a thousand blue-caps more: Worcester is stolen away tonight. Thy father’s beard is turned white with the news. You may buy land now as cheap as stinking mackerel.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You’re right, by instinct. Well, he’s there, and a man named Mordake, and a thousand Scottish soldiers besides. Worcester snuck out of London tonight, and your father’s hair turned white when he heard. The price of land has dropped as low as a bucket of stinking fish.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, then, it is like if there come a hot June, and this civil buffeting hold, we shall buy maidenheads as they buy hob- nails, by the hundreds.
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$If that’s the case, then when the weather gets hot and the
civil war has really broken out, we can buy women’s virtues the way other people buy nails: by the hundreds.$NEWLINE$civil war$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$By the Mass, thou sayest true. It is like we shall have good trading that way. But tell me, Hal, art not thou horrible afeard? Thou being heir apparent, could the world pick thee out three such enemies again as that fiend Douglas, that spirit Percy, and that devil Glendower? Art thou not horribly afraid? Doth not thy blood thrill at it?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$By God, lad, you tell the truth. We’ll probably have good luck in that area. But Hal, aren’t you scared? You’re the heir apparent. Can you imagine three worse enemies than that demon Douglas, that spirit Percy, and that devil Glendower? Aren’t you horribly scared? Isn’t your blood running cold at the thought?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Not a whit, i' faith; I lack some of thy instinct.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Not in the least, truly: I don’t have your instinct.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, thou wert be horribly chid tomorrow when thou comest to thy father. If thou love me, practice an answer.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, you’ll be rebuked horribly when you see your father tomorrow. If you love me, practice a response.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Do thou stand for my father and examine me upon the particulars of my life.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You pretend to be my father; ask me about the details of my life.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Shall I? Conten. This chair shall be my state, this dagger my scepter, and this cushion my crown.
