paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Really? Excellent! This chair will be my throne, this dagger my scepter, and this cushion will be my crown.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Thy state is taken for a joined stool, thy golden scepter for a leaden dagger, and thy precious rich crown for a pitiful bald crown.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Your throne is a wooden stool, your gold scepter is a dagger of lead, and your precious, expensive crown is a lousy bald head.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, an the fire of grace be not quite out of thee, now shalt thou be moved.—Give me a cup of sack to make my eyes look red, that it may be thought I have wept, for I must speak in passion, and I will do it in King Cambyses' vein.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$If you still have a shred of divine grace in you, you’ll be moved by this. Give me some wine to make my eyes bloodshot, so that it looks like I’ve been crying. I must speak with passion, and I’ll do it like
King Cambyses.$NEWLINE$King Cambyses$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, here is my leg.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well then, I’ll bow to you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$And here is my speech. Stand aside, nobility.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$And I’ll speak to you. Step aside, gentlemen.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O Jesu, this is excellent sport, i' faith!
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Oh, Jesus! This is an excellent game, truly!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Weep not, sweet queen, for trickling tears are vain.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Don’t cry, sweet queen; your trickling tears do no good.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O the father, how he holds his countenance!
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Oh Lord, look how well he’s keeping it up!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, lords, convey my tristful queen,$NEWLINE$For tears do stop the floodgates of her eyes.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, gentlemen; take my queen away from here. The floodgates of her eyes are being overwhelmed by her tears.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O Jesu, he doth it as like one of these harlotry players as ever$NEWLINE$I see.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$My God! He’s just as good as those silly old professional actors!

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Peace, good pint-pot. Peace, good tickle-brain.— (to PRINCE HENRY ) Harry, I do not only marvel where thou spendest thy time, but also how thou art accompanied. For though the camomile, the more it is trodden on, the faster it grows, so youth, the more it is wasted, the sooner it wears. That thou art my son I have partly thy mother’s word, partly my own opinion, but chiefly a villanous trick of thine eye and a foolish-hanging of thy nether lip that doth warrant me. If then thou be son to me, here lies the point: why, being son to me, art thou so pointed at? Shall the blessed sun of heaven prove a micher and eat blackberries? A question not to be asked. Shall the sun of England prove a thief and take purses? A question to be asked. There is a thing, Harry, which thou hast often heard of, and it is known to many in our land by the name of pitch: this pitch, as ancient writers do report, doth defile; so doth the company thou keepest. For, Harry, now I do not speak to thee, in drink but in tears; not in pleasure, but in passion; not in words only, but in woes also. And yet there is a virtuous man whom I have often noted in thy company, but I know not his name.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Quiet, little ale pot. Quiet, little booze-brain. (to PRINCE HENRY) Harry, I am not only amazed at where you are spending your time, but whom you’re spending it with. They say that stepping on a chamomile plant will make it grow faster. But when it comes to youth, the more it is wasted, the faster is wears away. I know you are my son. Your mother says so, I believe so, and the wicked glint in your eye and foolish expression on your face prove it. If it’s true that you are my son, then here is my point: why, since you are my son, do so many people point at you? Should the blessed sun in heaven waste its time eating blackberries? That is not a question worth asking. Should the son of the king of England become a thief and steal wallets? That is worth asking. Harry, you’ve heard of a substance known as pitch.
Pitch, as the wise men tell us, makes one filthy, and so does the company you keep. Harry, I speak to you not drunk but weeping, not in happiness but in anger, not just in words but also in sadness. And yet, there is a very good and pious man whom I’ve often seen you with, but I do not know his name.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Pitch$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What manner of man, an it like your Majesty?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What kind of man, your highness?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A goodly portly man, i' faith, and a corpulent; of a cheerful look, a pleasing eye, and a most noble carriage, and, as I think, his age some fifty, or, by 'r Lady, inclining to three score; and now I remember me, his name is Falstaff. If that man should be lewdly given, he deceiveth me, for, Harry, I see virtue in his looks. If then the tree may be known by the fruit, as the fruit by the tree, then peremptorily I speak it: there is virtue in that Falstaff; him keep with, the rest banish. And tell me now, thou naughty varlet, tell me, where hast thou been this month?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A stout man, truly; and overweight. He has a cheerful expression, a handsome look, and a noble bearing. I think he is about fifty years old, or perhaps closer to sixty. Now I remember! His name is Falstaff. If that man has a bad character, then I have been fooled. Harry, I see goodness in him. If one can tell a tree by its fruit, and a fruit by its tree, then let me come right out and say this: there is goodness in that Falstaff. Stay with him, but get rid of everyone else. Now tell me, you naughty boy, tell me; where have you been for the past month?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Dost thou speak like a king? Do thou stand for me, and I’ll play my father.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You think you sound like a king? You play me, and I’ll play my father.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Depose me? If thou dost it half so gravely, so majestically, both in word and matter, hang me up by the heels for a rabbit- sucker or a poulter’s hare.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You’re overthrowing me? If you play him even half as well as I did, half as majestically, then hang me up like a rabbit for sale in a butcher shop.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, here I am set.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I’m all set.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$And here I stand. — (to the others) Judge, my masters.$NEWLINE$(to the others)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$As am I. (to the others) Judge us, everyone.$NEWLINE$(to the others)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Now, Harry, whence come you?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Now, Harry, where are you coming from?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My noble lord, from Eastcheap.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$From Eastcheap, my noble lord.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$The complaints I hear of thee are grievous.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$The complaints I have heard about you are very serious.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$'Sblood, my lord, they are false.— (to the others) Nay, I’ll tickle you for a young prince, i' faith.$NEWLINE$(to the others)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, my lord, they are lies. (to the others) I’ll make you laugh by playing a young prince, I truly will.$NEWLINE$(to the others)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Swearest thou? Ungracious boy, henceforth ne'er look on me. Thou art violently carried away from grace. There is a devil haunts thee in the likeness of an old fat man. A tun of man is thy companion. Why dost thou converse with that trunk of humors, that bolting-hutch of beastliness, that swollen parcel of dropsies, that huge bombard of sack, that stuffed cloakbag of guts, that roasted Manningtree ox with the pudding in his belly, that reverend Vice, that gray iniquity, that father ruffian, that vanity in years? Wherein is he good, but to taste sack and drink it? Wherein neat and cleanly but to carve a capon and eat it? Wherein cunning but in craft? Wherein crafty but in villany? Wherein villanous but in all things? Wherein worthy but in nothing?
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Are you swearing, you ungracious boy? From now on, do not even look at me. You have been violently turned away from goodness; there is a devil that haunts you, in the shape of an old, fat man. A ton of man is your companion. Why do you associate with that trunk of bodily fluids, that sifting bin of beastliness, that swollen sack of disease, that huge jug of wine, that stuffed suitcase of guts, that roasted ox crammed with pudding, that ancient
Vice, that gray-haired immorality, that father criminal, that aged vanity? What is he good for, besides tasting wine and drinking it? What does he do skillfully, besides carving chickens and eating them? What’s he smart about besides schemes? What does he scheme about besides crime? What is he criminal about besides everything? What is he good for besides nothing?$NEWLINE$Vice$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I would your Grace would take me with you. Whom means your Grace?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I wish your highness would help me follow your meaning. Who do you mean, your grace?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$That villanous abominable misleader of youth, Falstaff, that old white-bearded Satan.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$That criminal, loathsome corrupter of youth: Falstaff, that old, white-bearded devil.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My lord, the man I know.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$My lord, I know the man.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I know thou dost.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I know you do.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$But to say I know more harm in him than in myself were to say more than I know. That he is old, the more the pity; his white hairs do witness it. But that he is, saving your reverence, a whoremaster, that I utterly deny. If sack and sugar be a fault, God help the wicked. If to be old and merry be a sin, then many an old host that I know is damned. If to be fat be to be hated, then Pharaoh’s lean kine are to be loved. No, my good lord, banish Peto, banish Bardolph, banish Poins, but for sweet Jack Falstaff, kind Jack Falstaff, true Jack Falstaff, valiant Jack Falstaff, and therefore more valiant being, as he is old Jack Falstaff, banish not him thy Harry’s company, banish not him thy Harry’s company. Banish plump Jack, and banish all the world.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$But to make me claim that he’s any more harmful than I am—well, I can’t claim that. Yes he’s old, and it’s a shame: his white hair proves it. But that he’s a—forgive me—pimp? That I absolutely deny. If drinking wine and sugar is a fault, then God forgive us all. If being old and merry is a sin, then I know a lot of old men who are going to hell. If being fat means you should be hated, than we should all love
Pharoah’s lean cows. No, your highness. Get rid of Peto, get rid of Bardolph, get rid of Poins. But as for sweet Jack Falstaff, kind Jack Falstaff, honest Jack Falstaff, brave Jack Falstaff, and therefore even more brave, given that he is old Jack Falstaff—do not get rid of him. Do not get rid of him. If you get rid of him, you’ll be getting rid of the whole world.$NEWLINE$Pharoah’s lean cows$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I do, I will.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I do. I will.

paragraphs.original: Knocking within. Exeunt BARDOLPH, MISTRESS QUICKLY, and FRANCIS. Enter BARDOLPH, running$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$FRANCIS$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: There are knocks from offstage. MISTRESS QUICKLY, FRANCIS, and BARDOLPH exit. BARDOLPH comes back, running.$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$FRANCIS$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$O, my lord, my lord, the Sheriff with a most monstrous watch is at the door.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Oh sir, sir! The Sheriff and a frightening group of officers are at the door.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Out, you rogue.—Play out the play. I have much to say in the behalf of that Falstaff.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Wait, you ass! We’ll finish the play: I have much to say on behalf of that Falstaff.

paragraphs.original: Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY enters.$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O Jesu, my lord, my lord—
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Jesus! Sir, sir!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Heigh, heigh, the devil rides upon a fiddlestick. What’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, look here! All this mess over nothing! What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$The Sheriff and all the watch are at the door. They are come to search the house. Shall I let them in?
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$The Sheriff and the officers are at the door. They’ve come to search the place. Should I let them in?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Dost thou hear, Hal? Never call a true piece of gold a counterfeit. Thou art essentially made, without seeming so.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Do you hear that,
Hal? Be careful about calling a piece of real gold a counterfeit; you are genuine, even though it may not seem so.$NEWLINE$Hal?$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And thou a natural coward without instinct.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And you are a genuine coward, with no instinct.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I deny your major. If you will deny the Sheriff, so; if not, let him enter. If I become not a cart as well as another man, a plague on my bringing up. I hope I shall as soon be strangled with a halter as another.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I deny that. And if you’ll deny the Sheriff, then please do; otherwise, let him in. If I don’t look as good on the
hangman’s cart as any other man, then a curse on my upbringing. I’m as willing to be hanged as any man.$NEWLINE$hangman’s cart$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Go, hide thee behind the arras. The rest walk up above.—$NEWLINE$Now, my masters, for a true face and good conscience.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Go, hide behind the arras. The rest of you, go upstairs. Now, my men. Here’s wishing for an honest face and a clear conscience.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Both which I have had, but their date is out; and therefore I’ll hide me. (he hides behind the arras)$NEWLINE$(he hides behind the arras)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’ve had both of those, but their shelf-life has expired. I’d better hide. (he hides behind the arras)$NEWLINE$(he hides behind the arras)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but PRINCE HENRY and PETO$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PETO
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except for PRINCE HENRY and PETO exits.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PETO

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Call in the Sheriff.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Call in the Sheriff.

paragraphs.original: Enter SHERIFF and the CARRIER$NEWLINE$SHERIFF$NEWLINE$CARRIER
paragraphs.translated: The SHERIFF and a CARRIER enter.$NEWLINE$SHERIFF$NEWLINE$CARRIER

paragraphs.original: Now, Master Sheriff, what is your will with me?
paragraphs.translated: Now, Sheriff, what is it you want from me?

paragraphs.original: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$First pardon me, my lord. A hue and cry$NEWLINE$Hath followed certain men unto this house.
paragraphs.translated: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$First, please forgive me, my lord. A group of citizens followed some criminals into this bar.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What men?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What men?

paragraphs.original: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$One of them is well known, my gracious lord,$NEWLINE$A gross fat man.
paragraphs.translated: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$One of them is well known, my gracious lord. A huge, fat man.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CARRIER$NEWLINE$As fat as butter.
paragraphs.translated: CARRIER$NEWLINE$As fat as butter.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$The man, I do assure you is not here,$NEWLINE$For I myself at this time have employed him.$NEWLINE$And, Sheriff, I will engage my word to thee$NEWLINE$That I will by tomorrow dinner time$NEWLINE$Send him to answer thee or any man$NEWLINE$For any thing he shall be charged withal.$NEWLINE$And so let me entreat you leave the house.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I promise you, that man isn’t here, since he’s currently running an errand for me. Sheriff, I give you my word that by lunchtime tomorrow I’ll send him to you, or anyone else you need to see. He’ll answer to anything he may be accused of. So please, I’d like you to leave this tavern.

paragraphs.original: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$I will, my lord. There are two gentlemen$NEWLINE$Have in this robbery lost three hundred marks.
paragraphs.translated:
SHERIFF$NEWLINE$I will, my lord. There are also two gentlemen who, in this robbery, lost three hundred
marks.$NEWLINE$marks$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$It may be so. If he have robbed these men,$NEWLINE$He shall be answerable; and so farewell.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$It’s possible. If he did it, he’ll answer for it. And with that, farewell.

paragraphs.original: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$Good night, my noble lord.
paragraphs.translated: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$Good night, my noble lord.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I think it is good morrow, is it not?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I think it’s good morning, isn’t it?

paragraphs.original: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$Indeed, my lord, I think it be two o'clock.
paragraphs.translated: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$Yes, sir. I think it’s two o'clock.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt SHERIFF and CARRIER$NEWLINE$SHERIFF$NEWLINE$CARRIER
paragraphs.translated: The SHERIFF and CARRIER exit.$NEWLINE$SHERIFF$NEWLINE$CARRIER

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$This oily rascal is known as well as Paul’s. Go call him forth.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$This oily rascal is as famous as St. Paul’s Cathedral. Go, call him out here.

paragraphs.original: PETO$NEWLINE$Falstaff!— (pulls back the arras) Fast asleep behind the arras, and snorting like a horse.$NEWLINE$(pulls back the arras)
paragraphs.translated: PETO$NEWLINE$Falstaff! (pulls back the arras) Fast asleep behind the arras, and snoring like a horse.$NEWLINE$(pulls back the arras)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Hark, how hard he fetches breath. Search his pockets.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Listen, how heavily he breathes! Look in his pockets.

paragraphs.original: PETO searcheth his pockets, and findeth certain papers$NEWLINE$PETO
paragraphs.translated: PETO searches FALSTAFF’s pockets and finds some papers.$NEWLINE$PETO$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: What hast thou found?
paragraphs.translated: What did you find?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PETO$NEWLINE$Nothing but papers, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: PETO$NEWLINE$Nothing but some papers, my lord.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Let’s see what they be. Read them.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Let’s see what they are. Read them.

paragraphs.original: PETO$NEWLINE$(reads) Item, a capon, … 2s. 2d.$NEWLINE$(reads) Item, a capon, … 2s. 2d.$NEWLINE$Item, sauce, … 4d.$NEWLINE$Item, sauce, … 4d.$NEWLINE$Item, sack, two gallons, … 5s. 8d.$NEWLINE$Item, sack, two gallons, … 5s. 8d.$NEWLINE$Item, anchovies and sack after supper, , , , 2s. 6d.$NEWLINE$Item, anchovies and sack after supper, , , , 2s. 6d.$NEWLINE$Item, bread, ob.$NEWLINE$Item, bread, ob.
paragraphs.translated: PETO$NEWLINE$(reads) First, a chicken — two shillings and two pence. Second, sauce — four pence. Third, wine, two gallons —five shillings and eight pence. Fourth, anchovies and dessert wine — two shillings and six pence. Fifth, bread — a halfpenny.$NEWLINE$(reads)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$O monstrous! But one halfpennyworth of bread to this intolerable deal of sack! What there is else, keep close. We’ll read it at more advantage. There let him sleep till day. I’ll to the court in the morning. We must all to the wars, and thy place shall be honorable. I’ll procure this fat rogue a charge of foot, and I know his death will be a march of twelve score. The money shall be paid back again with advantage. Be with me betimes in the morning, and so good morrow, Peto.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Oh horrible! A halfpenny’s worth of bread against this enormous amount of wine? Hang onto everything else you found; we’ll read it when we have time. Let him sleep there till tomorrow. I’ll go to court in the morning. We’re all off to the wars, and you will have honorable positions. I’ll put this fat rogue in charge of an infantry company, and a quarter mile’s march will be the end of him. The money we stole will be repaid with interest. Meet me early in the morning; and with that, good morning, Peto.

paragraphs.original: PETO$NEWLINE$Good morrow, good my lord.
paragraphs.translated: PETO$NEWLINE$Good morning, my good lord.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter HOTSPUR,WORCESTER, Lord MORTIMER, and Owen GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$MORTIMER$NEWLINE$GLENDOWER
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR, WORCESTER, Lord MORTIMER, and Owen GLENDOWER enter.$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$MORTIMER$NEWLINE$GLENDOWER

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$These promises are fair, the parties sure,$NEWLINE$And our induction full of prosperous hope.
paragraphs.translated: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$These commitments are reliable, our allies are solid, and the beginning of our project bodes well.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Lord Mortimer and cousin Glendower,$NEWLINE$Will you sit down? And Uncle Worcester—$NEWLINE$A plague upon it, I have forgot the map.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Lord Mortimer, and kinsman Glendower, won’t you please sit? And Uncle Worcester—Dammit! I forgot the map!

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$No, here it is. Sit, cousin Percy$NEWLINE$Sit, good cousin Hotspur, for by that name$NEWLINE$As oft as Lancaster doth speak of you$NEWLINE$His cheek looks pale and with a rising sigh$NEWLINE$He wisheth you in heaven.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Here it is. Sit, kinsman Percy. Sit, good cousin Hotspur. For that is the name King Henry calls you, and whenever he says it, he grows pale, and with a sigh he wishes you were in heaven.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$And you in hell,$NEWLINE$As oft as he hears Owen Glendower spoke of.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$And you in hell, whenever he hears someone say “Owen Glendower.”

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$I cannot blame him. At my nativity$NEWLINE$The front of heaven was full of fiery shapes,$NEWLINE$Of burning cressets, and at my birth$NEWLINE$The frame and huge foundation of the earth$NEWLINE$Shaked like a coward.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$I don’t blame him. The sky was full of fiery meteors and comets when I was conceived, and when I was born, the entire earth shook like a coward.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Why, so it would have done$NEWLINE$At the same season if your mother’s cat$NEWLINE$Had but kittened, though yourself had never been born.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Why, the same thing would have happened if your mother’s cat had given birth to kittens that day, whether you’d been born or not.

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$I say the earth did shake when I was born.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$I say there was an earthquake when I was born.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$And I say the earth was not of my mind,$NEWLINE$If you suppose as fearing you it shook.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$And I say that if you think the earth shook because it was afraid of you, then the earth and I do not agree.

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$The heavens were all on fire; the earth did tremble.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$The heavens were all on fire, and the earth trembled.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$O, then the earth shook to see the heavens on fire,$NEWLINE$And not in fear of your nativity.$NEWLINE$Diseas—d nature oftentimes breaks forth$NEWLINE$In strange eruptions; oft the teeming earth$NEWLINE$Is with a kind of colic pinched and vexed$NEWLINE$By the imprisoning of unruly wind$NEWLINE$Within her womb, which, for enlargement striving,$NEWLINE$Shakes the old beldam earth and topples down$NEWLINE$Steeples and moss-grown towers. At your birth$NEWLINE$Our grandam earth, having this distemperature,$NEWLINE$In passion shook.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Oh! Then the earth trembled when it saw the heavens on fire, and not in fear of your birth. When nature is diseased, strange eruptions can break forth. Often, the earth is pinched with a kind of colic, and troubled by gas in her belly. When that gas struggles to be released, it shakes old Mother Earth, bringing down steeples and moss-covered towers. When you were born, our Mother Earth was ill and shook with pain.

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Cousin, of many men$NEWLINE$I do not bear these crossings. Give me leave$NEWLINE$To tell you once again that at my birth$NEWLINE$The front of heaven was full of fiery shapes,$NEWLINE$The goats ran from the mountains, and the herds$NEWLINE$Were strangely clamorous to the frighted fields.$NEWLINE$These signs have marked me extraordinary,$NEWLINE$And all the courses of my life do show$NEWLINE$I am not in the roll of common men.$NEWLINE$Where is he living, clipped in with the sea$NEWLINE$That chides the banks of England, Scotland, Wales,$NEWLINE$Which calls me pupil or hath read to me?$NEWLINE$And bring him out that is but woman’s son$NEWLINE$Can trace me in the tedious ways of art$NEWLINE$And hold me pace in deep experiments.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Kinsman, I don’t take this kind of contrary behavior from many people. With your permission, I’ll say one more time that when I was born, the heavens were full of shooting stars. The goats ran down from the mountains, and herds of animals stampeded strangely through the fields. These signs marked me as an extraordinary person. All the events of my life prove that I should not be counted with ordinary men. Is there a man who lives anywhere within England, Scotland, or Wales who can say I learned from him, or that he taught me? And bring forward one human who can follow me in the complicated ways of magic, or keep up with me in my obscure experiments.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I think there’s no man speaks better Welsh.$NEWLINE$I’ll to dinner.
paragraphs.translated:
HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Well, nobody speaks better
Welsh. I’m going to lunch.$NEWLINE$Welsh$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$Peace, cousin Percy. You will make him mad.
paragraphs.translated: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$Stop now, kinsman Percy. You will upset him.

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$I can call spirits from the vasty deep.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$I can summon spirits from the deep ocean.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Why, so can I, or so can any man,$NEWLINE$But will they come when you do call for them?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Why, so can I, and so can any other man! But will they come when you summon them?

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Why, I can teach you, cousin, to command the devil.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Why, kinsman, I can teach you to command the devil.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$And I can teach thee, coz, to shame the devil$NEWLINE$By telling truth. Tell truth and shame the devil.$NEWLINE$If thou have power to raise him, bring him hither,$NEWLINE$And I’ll be sworn I have power to shame him hence.$NEWLINE$O, while you live, tell truth and shame the devil!
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$And I can teach you, kinsman, how to shame the devil—by telling the truth! “Tell the truth and shame the devil,” as the old saying goes. If you do have the power to call him up, then bring him here. And I’ll swear I have the power to shame him into leaving. Oh, for goodness sake, tell the truth and shame the devil!

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$Come, come, no more of this unprofitable chat.
paragraphs.translated: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$Enough already; stop this useless talking.

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Three times hath Henry Bolingbroke made head$NEWLINE$Against my power; thrice from the banks of Wye$NEWLINE$And sandy-bottomed Severn have I sent him$NEWLINE$Bootless home and weather-beaten back.
paragraphs.translated:
GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Three times now, Henry Bolingbroke has raised an army against mine. And three times, I turned him back from the banks of the River Wye, and the sandy-bottomed River Severn. I sent him home,
bootless and beaten by foul weather.$NEWLINE$bootless$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Home without boots, and in foul weather too!$NEWLINE$How ’scapes he agues, in the devil’s name?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$You sent him home without his boots, and in foul weather? How in the devil’s name did he avoid catching fevers?

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Come, here’s the map. Shall we divide our right$NEWLINE$According to our threefold order ta'en?
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$All right, here’s the map. Shall we divide up our territories according to our three-way agreement?

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$The Archdeacon hath divided it$NEWLINE$Into three limits very equally:$NEWLINE$England, from Trent and Severn hitherto,$NEWLINE$By south and east is to my part assigned;
paragraphs.translated:
MORTIMER$NEWLINE$The
Archdeacon has divided the land into three very equal parts. All of England southeast of the Trent and Severn rivers goes to me.$NEWLINE$Archdeacon$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: All westward, Wales beyond the Severn shore,$NEWLINE$And all the fertile land within that bound$NEWLINE$To Owen Glendower; and, dear coz, to you$NEWLINE$The remnant northward, lying off from Trent.$NEWLINE$And our indentures tripartite are drawn,$NEWLINE$Which being sealèd interchangeably—$NEWLINE$A business that this night may execute—$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, cousin Percy, you and I$NEWLINE$And my good Lord of Worcester will set forth$NEWLINE$To meet your father and the Scottish power,$NEWLINE$As is appointed us, at Shrewsbury.$NEWLINE$My father Glendower is not ready yet,$NEWLINE$Not shall we need his help these fourteen days.$NEWLINE$(to GLENDOWER ) Within that space you may have drawn together$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Your tenants, friends, and neighboring gentlemen.
paragraphs.translated: All of Wales, and everything west of the Severn—including all the fertile land within those boundaries—goes to Owen Glendower. And, my dear kinsman, you get everything that remains to the north, coming up from the Trent. Our agreement is drawn up in triplicate. We can all sign it tonight, and then, kinsman Percy, tomorrow you, me, and Worcester will set off to meet your father and the Scottish army at Shrewsbury, as planned. My father-in-law Glendower isn’t ready yet, but we won’t need his army for another two weeks. (to GLENDOWER) By that time, you will have raised an army of the farmers on your land, your allies, and your neighbors.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$A shorter time shall send me to you, lords,$NEWLINE$And in my conduct shall your ladies come,$NEWLINE$From whom you now must steal and take no leave,$NEWLINE$For there will be a world of water shed$NEWLINE$Upon the parting of your wives and you.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$I’ll be ready sooner than that, my lords; and I’ll bring your wives along with me. You should sneak away from them now, and leave without saying goodbye. Otherwise, they’ll cry an ocean of tears when you leave them.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Methinks my moiety, north from Burton here,$NEWLINE$In quantity equals not one of yours.$NEWLINE$See how this river comes me cranking in$NEWLINE$And cuts me from the best of all my land$NEWLINE$A huge half-moon, a monstrous cantle out.$NEWLINE$I’ll have the current in this place dammed up,$NEWLINE$And here the smug and silver Trent shall run$NEWLINE$In a new channel, fair and evenly.$NEWLINE$It shall not wind with such a deep indent,$NEWLINE$To rob me of so rich a bottom here.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I think my share, north of Burton here, isn’t as big as any of yours. Look how this river swoops in. It cuts out a huge chunk of my best land, in the shape of a half-moon. I’ll have a dam built. I’ll re-route the Trent River so it won’t go winding so far into my land and rob me of a fertile valley.

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Not wind? It shall, it must. You see it doth.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$It won’t go winding? It will. It must. You see that it does.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$Yea, but Mark how he bears his course, and runs me up$NEWLINE$With like advantage on the other side,$NEWLINE$Gelding the opposèd continent as much$NEWLINE$As on the other side it takes from you.
paragraphs.translated: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$Yes, but look how the Trent runs its course and winds a similar distance into my share. It cuts out the same amount of land from my side as it does from yours.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Yea, but a little charge will trench him here$NEWLINE$And on this north side win this cape of land,$NEWLINE$And then he runs straight and even.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Yes, but a small sum of money will pay to dig a trench, which will reclaim this bit of land on the north side. Then it will run straight along.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I’ll have it so. A little charge will do it.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I’ll do that. It will only take a little money.

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$I’ll not have it altered.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$I won’t have it changed.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Will not you?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$You won’t?

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$No, nor you shall not.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$No, and neither will you.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Who shall say me nay?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Who’s going to stop me?

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Why, that will I.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Why, I will.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Let me not understand you, then; speak it in Welsh.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Well, say it in Welsh then, so I can’t understand you.

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$I can speak English, lord, as well as you,$NEWLINE$For I was trained up in the English court,$NEWLINE$Where being but young I framèd to the harp$NEWLINE$Many an English ditty lovely well$NEWLINE$And gave the tongue a helpful ornament—$NEWLINE$A virtue that was never seen in you.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$My lord, I can speak English just as well as you. I was brought up in the English court. There, in my youth, I composed many English songs for the harp, lending the language lovely ornaments of music. That is an accomplishment you have never achieved.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Marry,$NEWLINE$And I am glad of it with all my heart:$NEWLINE$I had rather be a kitten and cry “mew”$NEWLINE$Than one of these same meter balladmongers.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Indeed, and my whole heart is glad for that. I’d rather be a kitten and say “meow” than be a courtly balladeer.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I had rather hear a brazen can’stick turned,$NEWLINE$Or a dry wheel grate on the axletree,$NEWLINE$And that would set my teeth nothing an edge,$NEWLINE$Nothing so much as mincing poetry.$NEWLINE$'Tis like the forced gait of a shuffling nag.
paragraphs.translated: I’d rather hear a piece of brass turned on a lathe, or a ungreased wheel grind on its axle. Nothing sets my teeth on edge so as much as finicky poetry; it’s like the lurching steps of a lame horse.

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Come, you shall have Trent turned.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Fine. Change the Trent’s course.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I do not care. I’ll give thrice so much land$NEWLINE$To any well-deserving friend;$NEWLINE$But in the way of bargain, mark you me,$NEWLINE$I’ll cavil on the ninth part of a hair.$NEWLINE$Are the indentures drawn? Shall we be gone?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I don’t care. I’d gladly give away three times as much land to any friend who deserved it. But when it comes to negotiating a deal, mark my words: I’ll haggle over the smallest fraction of a hair. Are the agreements drawn up? Are we ready to leave?

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$The moon shines fair. You may away by night.$NEWLINE$I’ll haste the writer, and withal$NEWLINE$Break with your wives of your departure hence.$NEWLINE$I am afraid my daughter will run mad,$NEWLINE$So much she doteth on her Mortimer.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$The moon is bright; you can leave during the night. I’ll tell the man writing up our documents to hurry, and I’ll tell your wives you’re leaving. I’m afraid my daughter will go mad because she loves Mortimer so much.

paragraphs.original: Exit GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$GLENDOWER
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER exits.$NEWLINE$GLENDOWER

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$Fie, cousin Percy, how you cross my father!
paragraphs.translated: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$Damn, kinsman Percy! How angry you make my father-in-law!

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I cannot choose. Sometime he angers me$NEWLINE$With telling me of the moldwarp and the ant,$NEWLINE$Of the dreamer Merlin and his prophecies,$NEWLINE$And of a dragon and a finless fish,$NEWLINE$A clip-winged griffin and a moulten raven,$NEWLINE$A couching lion and a ramping cat,$NEWLINE$And such a deal of skimble-skamble stuff$NEWLINE$As puts me from my faith. I tell you what—$NEWLINE$He held me last night at least nine hours$NEWLINE$In reckoning up the several devils' names$NEWLINE$That were his lackeys. I cried “Hum,” and “Well, go to,”$NEWLINE$But marked him not a word. O, he is as tedious
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I can’t help it. He makes me angry with all his talk. Moles and ants, Merlin and his prophecies, dragons, a fish with no fins, a griffin without wings, a raven without feathers, a crouching lion and a cat rearing up to pounce. He talks so much mumbo-jumbo that I don’t know what to believe anymore. I’ll tell you this: he kept me awake last night for at least nine hours, listing the names of all the devils that serve him. I said, “Hmm,” and, “How interesting,” but he didn’t hear a word. Oh, he’s as tedious as a tired horse or a nagging wife; he’s worse than a smoke-filled house.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: As a tired horse, a railing wife,$NEWLINE$Worse than a smoky house: I had rather live$NEWLINE$With cheese and garlic in a windmill, far,$NEWLINE$Than feed on cates and have him talk to me$NEWLINE$In any summerhouse in Christendom.
paragraphs.translated: I’d rather live in a windmill and eat nothing but cheese and garlic than in a luxurious home eating delicacies, if it meant I had to listen to him talk.

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$In faith, he is a worthy gentleman,$NEWLINE$Exceedingly well read and profited$NEWLINE$In strange concealments, valiant as a lion,$NEWLINE$And as wondrous affable, and as bountiful$NEWLINE$As mines of India. Shall I tell you, cousin?$NEWLINE$He holds your temper in a high respect$NEWLINE$And curbs himself even of his natural scope$NEWLINE$When you come cross his humor. Faith, he does.$NEWLINE$I warrant you that man is not alive$NEWLINE$Might so have tempted him as you have done$NEWLINE$Without the taste of danger and reproof.$NEWLINE$But do not use it oft, let me entreat you.
paragraphs.translated: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$Truly, he’s a worthy man. He’s exceedingly well-read, and proficient in the occult; he’s as brave as a lion, incredibly charming, and as generous as the jewel mines of India. And do you know what, cousin? He holds you in great respect. He restrains his temper when you do something to put him in a bad mood. I promise you, there isn’t a man alive who could have challenged him as you have, and gotten away without being hurt or punished. But don’t try it too often, I beg you.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$(to HOTSPUR) In faith, my lord, you are too willful-blame,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And, since your coming hither, have done enough$NEWLINE$To put him quite beside his patience.$NEWLINE$You must needs learn, lord, to amend this fault.$NEWLINE$Though sometimes it show greatness, courage, blood—$NEWLINE$And that’s the dearest grace it renders you—$NEWLINE$Yet oftentimes it doth present harsh rage,$NEWLINE$Defect of manners, want of government,$NEWLINE$Pride, haughtiness, opinion, and disdain,$NEWLINE$The least of which, haunting a nobleman,$NEWLINE$Loseth men’s hearts and leaves behind a stain$NEWLINE$Upon the beauty of all parts besides,$NEWLINE$Beguiling them of commendation.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$(to HOTSPUR) Truly, my lord, you are to blame in your stubbornness. Since you arrived, you have done enough to test his patience. You must learn, sir, to correct this fault. Sometimes it demonstrates greatness, courage, strength—and that honors you. But often it reveals fury, bad manners, lack of self-control, pride, arrogance, conceitedness, and contempt. In a gentlemen, the least of these qualities will make you lose people’s affections. It stains your beautiful qualities, making it impossible for them to be noticed.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Well, I am schooled. Good manners be your speed!$NEWLINE$Here come our wives, and let us take our leave.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Well, I have had my lesson. May good manners bring you success! Here come our wives; let’s say our goodbyes.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter GLENDOWER with the LADIES PERCY AND MORTIMER$NEWLINE$GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$LADIES PERCY AND MORTIMER
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER enters with the LADIES PERCY AND MORTIMER$NEWLINE$GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$LADIES PERCY AND MORTIMER

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$This is the deadly spite that angers me:$NEWLINE$My wife can speak no English, I no Welsh.
paragraphs.translated: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$This is the bad luck that angers me: my wife speaks no English, and I speak no Welsh.

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$My daughter weeps; she’ll not part with you.$NEWLINE$She’ll be a soldier too, she’ll to the wars.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$My daughter is weeping: she doesn’t want to be parted from you. She wants to be a soldier and join you in the war.

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$Good father, tell her that she and my aunt Percy$NEWLINE$Shall follow in your conduct speedily.
paragraphs.translated: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$Father-in-law, tell her that she and Lady Percy will come with you after us.

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER speaks to THE LADY in Welsh, and she answers him in the same$NEWLINE$GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$THE LADY
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER and THE LADY speak in Welsh.$NEWLINE$GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$THE LADY

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$She is desperate here, a peevish self-willed harlotry,$NEWLINE$One that no persuasion can do good upon.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$She’s desperate now; a cranky, selfish hussy. Nobody can change her mind.

paragraphs.original: THE LADY speaks again in Welsh$NEWLINE$THE LADY
paragraphs.translated: THE LADY speaks more Welsh.$NEWLINE$THE LADY

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$I understand thy looks. That pretty Welsh$NEWLINE$Which thou pourest down from these swelling heavens$NEWLINE$I am too perfect in, and but for shame$NEWLINE$In such a parley should I answer thee.
paragraphs.translated: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$I understand you by the look on your face. Those pretty Welsh tears streaming from your heavenly eyes I understand perfectly; I’d answer in the same language, if it weren’t shameful for a man to cry.

paragraphs.original: THE LADY speaks again in Welsh$NEWLINE$THE LADY
paragraphs.translated: THE LADY speaks more Welsh.$NEWLINE$THE LADY

paragraphs.original: I understand thy kisses and thou mine,$NEWLINE$And that’s a feeling disputation;$NEWLINE$But I will never be a truant, love,$NEWLINE$Till I have learned thy language; for thy tongue$NEWLINE$Makes Welsh as sweet as ditties highly penned,$NEWLINE$Sung by a fair queen in a summer’s bower,$NEWLINE$With ravishing division, to her lute.
paragraphs.translated: I understand your kisses and you mine; that’s a conversation of emotion. I’ll study continuously, my love, until I learn your language. Your voice makes Welsh sound as sweet as the most eloquently written songs, sung by a fair queen in a garden of summer flowers, with a gorgeous accompaniment on her a lute.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Nay, if you melt, then will she run mad.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$No, if you start to cry, you’ll drive her mad.

paragraphs.original: THE LADY speaks again in Welsh$NEWLINE$THE LADY
paragraphs.translated: THE LADY speaks more Welsh.$NEWLINE$THE LADY

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$O, I am ignorance itself in this!
paragraphs.translated: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$Oh, I have no idea what she’s saying!

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$She bids you on the wanton rushes lay you down$NEWLINE$And rest your gentle head upon her lap,$NEWLINE$And she will sing the song that pleaseth you$NEWLINE$And on your eyelids crown the god of sleep,$NEWLINE$Charming your blood with pleasing heaviness,$NEWLINE$Making such difference ’twixt wake and sleep$NEWLINE$As is the difference betwixt day and night$NEWLINE$The hour before the heavenly harnessed team$NEWLINE$Begins his golden progress in the east.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$She wants you to lie down on the rush-covered floor and rest your head in her lap. She’ll sing whatever song you like, and she’ll lull you to sleep. She’ll bewitch you into a pleasant heaviness, halfway between waking and sleeping; like the hour just before the sun begins its golden rise in the east.

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$With all my heart I’ll sit and hear her sing.$NEWLINE$By that time will our book, I think, be drawn
paragraphs.translated: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$I’ll gladly sit and hear her sing. By the time she’s done, I think our documents will be prepared.

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Do so and those musicians that shall play to you$NEWLINE$Hang in the air a thousand leagues from hence,$NEWLINE$And straight they shall be here. Sit, and attend.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Do so. The musicians who are going to play are now floating in the air a thousand leagues from here. They’ll be here shortly; so sit, and listen.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Come, Kate, thou art perfect in lying down.$NEWLINE$Come, quick, quick, that I may lay my head in thy lap.
paragraphs.translated:
HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Kate! You’re good at lying down. Come quickly, so that I can put my
head in your lap.$NEWLINE$head in your lap$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Go, you giddy goose.
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Stop it, you silly goose.

paragraphs.original: The music plays
paragraphs.translated: Music plays.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Now I perceive the devil understands Welsh,$NEWLINE$And ’tis no marvel he is so humorous.$NEWLINE$By 'r Lady, he is a good musician.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Now I see that the devil understands Welsh; it’s no surprise he’s so moody. By God, he’s a good musician.

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Then should you be nothing but musical, for you are altogether governed by humors. Lie still, you thief, and hear the lady sing in Welsh.
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Then you should be incredibly musical, for you’re the moodiest man alive. Lie still, you thief. Listen to the lady sing in Welsh.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I had rather hear Lady, my brach, howl in Irish.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I’d rather hear Lady, my dog, howl in Irish.

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Wouldst thou have thy head broken?
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Do you want your head broken in?

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$No.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$No.

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Then be still.
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Then be still.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Neither;’tis a woman’s fault.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Never; that’s a womanly trait.

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Now God help thee!
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Now God help you—

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$To the Welsh lady’s bed.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Into the Welsh lady’s bed!

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$What’s that?
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$What did you say?

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Peace, she sings.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Quiet! She’s singing.

paragraphs.original: Here THE LADY sings a Welsh song$NEWLINE$THE LADY
paragraphs.translated: THE LADY sings a Welsh song.$NEWLINE$THE LADY

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Come, Kate, I’ll have your song too.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Come on, Kate. I want to hear your song, too.

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Not mine, in good sooth.
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$Not mine, darn it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Not yours, in good sooth! Heart, you swear like a comfit-maker’s wife! “Not you, in good sooth,” and “as true as I live,” and “as God shall mend me,” and “as sure as day”—$NEWLINE$And givest such sarcenet surety for thy oaths$NEWLINE$As if thou never walk’st further than Finsbury.$NEWLINE$Swear me, Kate, like a lady as thou art,$NEWLINE$A good mouth-filling oath, and leave “in sooth,”$NEWLINE$And such protest of pepper-gingerbread,$NEWLINE$To velvet-guards and Sunday citizens.$NEWLINE$Come, sing.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Not yours? Darn it? Honestly! You swear like a candymaker’s wife. “Not you, darn it.” And “I swear on my life,” and “God forgive me,” and “as plain as day.” Your curse words are smooth as silk. You’d think you’d never gone further than Finsbury in your life. Swear like the real lady you are, Kate. Let loose a good mouthful of curses; leave “darn” and such watered-down cursewords to those citizens, trimmed in velvet and wearing their Sunday best. Come on, sing.

paragraphs.original: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$I will not sing.
paragraphs.translated: LADY PERCY$NEWLINE$I will not sing.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$'Tis the next way to turn tailor, or be red-breast teacher. An the indentures be drawn, I’ll away within these two hours, and so come in when ye will.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$It’s the quickest way to become a tailor; tailors love to sing. Or you could teach songs to birds. If our agreements are drawn up, I’ll be gone within two hours; come find me whenever you want.

paragraphs.original: Exit HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR exits.$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR

paragraphs.original: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Come, come, Lord Mortimer; you are as slow$NEWLINE$As hot Lord Percy is on fire to go.$NEWLINE$By this our book is drawn. We’ll but seal,$NEWLINE$And then to horse immediately.
paragraphs.translated: GLENDOWER$NEWLINE$Come now, Mortimer. You’re as reluctant to leave as Percy is on fire to go. Our agreements are drawn up by now. We’ll sign and then go straight to our horses.

paragraphs.original: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$With all my heart.
paragraphs.translated: MORTIMER$NEWLINE$I go with all my heart.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter KING, PRINCE HENRY of Wales, and others$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: The KING, PRINCE HENRY of Wales, and others enter.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Lords, give us leave; the Prince of Wales and I$NEWLINE$Must have some private conference, but be near at hand,$NEWLINE$For we shall presently have need of you.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Gentlemen, please leave; the Prince of Wales and I must speak in private. But stay close by, for I’ll need you in a moment.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt lords
paragraphs.translated: The lords exit.

paragraphs.original: I know not whether God will have it so$NEWLINE$For some displeasing service I have done,$NEWLINE$That, in his secret doom, out of my blood$NEWLINE$He’ll breed revengement and a scourge for me.$NEWLINE$But thou dost in thy passages of life$NEWLINE$Make me believe that thou art only marked$NEWLINE$For the hot vengeance and the rod of heaven$NEWLINE$To punish my mistreadings. Tell me else,$NEWLINE$Could such inordinate and low desires,$NEWLINE$Such poor, such bare, such lewd, such mean attempts,$NEWLINE$Such barren pleasures, rude society$NEWLINE$As thou art matched withal, and grafted to,$NEWLINE$Accompany the greatness of thy blood,$NEWLINE$And hold their level with thy princely heart?
paragraphs.translated: I don’t know whether God decided, because of some displeasing crime I have committed, to turn my own flesh and blood into a punisher and a plague upon me. The course of your life has me convinced that you are only meant for one purpose in this world: to be God’s vengeance against me for all my misdeeds. Why else would such disorderly and low desires, such poor, such wretched, such lewd, such despicable actions, such wasteful pleasures, and such vulgar company become associated with your high-born self, and call themselves equals with a Prince like you?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$So please your Majesty, I would I could$NEWLINE$Quit all offenses with as clear excuse$NEWLINE$As well as I am doubtless I can purge$NEWLINE$Myself of many I am charged withal.$NEWLINE$Yet such extenuation let me beg$NEWLINE$As, in reproof of many tales devised,$NEWLINE$Which oft the ear of greatness needs must hear,$NEWLINE$By smiling pickthanks and base newsmongers,$NEWLINE$I may for some things true, wherein my youth$NEWLINE$Hath faulty wandered and irregular,$NEWLINE$Find pardon on my true submission.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Your majesty, I wish I could be proven innocent of all those accusations, for I can certainly clear myself of many of them. But let me beg one favor of you: if I can demonstrate that I’m not guilty of the false charges of these smiling flatterers and wretched gossips (the kinds of stories that are always told about great men), then you will forgive me when I confess to the youthful indiscretions I actually did commit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$God pardon thee. Yet let me wonder, Harry,$NEWLINE$At thy affections, which do hold a wing$NEWLINE$Quite from the flight of all thy ancestors.$NEWLINE$Thy place in council thou hast rudely lost,$NEWLINE$Which by thy younger brother is supplied,$NEWLINE$And art almost an alien to the hearts$NEWLINE$Of all the court and princes of my blood.$NEWLINE$The hope and expectation of thy time$NEWLINE$Is ruined, and the soul of every man$NEWLINE$Prophetically doth forethink thy fall.$NEWLINE$Had I so lavish of my presence been,$NEWLINE$So common-hackneyed in the eyes of men,$NEWLINE$So stale and cheap to vulgar company,$NEWLINE$Opinion, that did help me to the crown,$NEWLINE$Had still kept loyal to possession$NEWLINE$And left me in reputeless banishment,$NEWLINE$A fellow of no mark nor likelihood.$NEWLINE$By being seldom seen, I could not stir$NEWLINE$But like a comet I was wondered at;$NEWLINE$That men would tell their children “This is he.”$NEWLINE$Others would say “Where? Which is Bolingbroke?”$NEWLINE$And then I stole all courtesy from heaven,$NEWLINE$And dressed myself in such humility$NEWLINE$That I did pluck allegiance from men’s hearts,$NEWLINE$Loud shouts and salutations from their mouths,$NEWLINE$Even in the presence of the crownèd King.$NEWLINE$Thus did I keep my person fresh and new,$NEWLINE$My presence, like a robe pontifical,$NEWLINE$Ne'er seen but wondered at, and so my state,$NEWLINE$Seldom but sumptuous, showed like a feast$NEWLINE$And won by rareness such solemnity.$NEWLINE$The skipping King, he ambled up and down$NEWLINE$With shallow jesters and rash bavin wits,$NEWLINE$Soon kindled and soon burnt; carded his state,$NEWLINE$Mingled his royalty with cap'ring fools,
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Let God forgive you! But I’m amazed, Harry, at your inclinations, which run completely contrary to those of your ancestors. Your vulgar behavior has cost you your place on my council, a position now held by your younger brother. You have almost completely alienated yourself from the good graces of the courtiers and the other members of the royal family. The hopes of your youth are now ruined; every man, in his heart, thinks he can see your downfall. If I had been so publicly visible, so overly familiar to people, so freely accessible, so cheap and available to the common hordes, then public opinion (which helped me get the crown) would have stayed loyal to King Richard. I would have stayed a banished man, with no reputation and no promise of success. But because I was so rarely seen in public, people were amazed by me when I did appear; they acted as if I were a comet. Men would tell their children, “That’s him!” Others would ask, “Where? Which one’s Bolingbroke?” I was more gracious than heaven; I acted so modestly that I won the allegiance of their hearts, and the shouts and salutes of their mouths. They even did so when the King himself was present.$NEWLINE$This is how I kept myself fresh and new. I was like a priest’s ceremonial vestments: rarely seen, but admired. I appeared seldomly, but marvelously, like a feast made all the more impressive by its rarity. Now, ridiculous King Richard pranced about with vapid clowns and superficial wits, quickly lit and just as quickly burnt out. He degraded himself, mingling his royal self with those skipping fools.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Had his great name profanèd with their scorns,$NEWLINE$And gave his countenance, against his name,$NEWLINE$To laugh at gibing boys and stand the push$NEWLINE$Of every beardless vain comparative;$NEWLINE$Grew a companion to the common streets,$NEWLINE$Enfeoffed himself to popularity,$NEWLINE$That, being daily swallowed by men’s eyes,$NEWLINE$They surfeited with honey and began$NEWLINE$To loathe the taste of sweetness, whereof a little$NEWLINE$More than a little is by much too much.$NEWLINE$So, when he had occasion to be seen,$NEWLINE$He was but as the cuckoo is in June,$NEWLINE$Heard, not regarded; seen, but with such eyes$NEWLINE$As, sick and blunted with community,$NEWLINE$Afford no extraordinary gaze$NEWLINE$Such as is bent on sunlike majesty$NEWLINE$When it shines seldom in admiring eyes,$NEWLINE$But rather drowsed and hung their eyelids down,$NEWLINE$Slept in his face, and rendered such aspect$NEWLINE$As cloudy men use to their adversaries,$NEWLINE$Being with his presence glutted, gorged, and full.$NEWLINE$And in that very line, Harry, standest thou,$NEWLINE$For thou has lost thy princely privilege$NEWLINE$With vile participation. Not an eye$NEWLINE$But is aweary of thy common sight,$NEWLINE$Save mine, which hath desired to see thee more,$NEWLINE$Which now doth that I would not have it do,$NEWLINE$Make blind itself with foolish tenderness.
paragraphs.translated: His reputation was ruined by their scornful attitudes. He lost face by laughing with those joking boys, and tolerating the rudeness of every smooth-faced, disdainful prankster. He spent his time in common, public places, surrendering himself to the pursuit of popularity. Soon, they saw him every day and it was like overdosing on honey; they began to hate the taste of that sweetness. A little too much is as bad as far too much. Seeing him became as common a sight as a cuckoo in June—heard but not paid attention to; seen, but by eyes so used to seeing that they took it for granted. They didn’t look with a special gaze, as they do at the sun when it shines only rarely. Instead, they grew bored, they looked away.$NEWLINE$They slept in front of him and watched him dully, the way a sullen man looks at his enemy. They were stuffed, gorged, and full with his presence. And that is just where you stand, Harry. You have lost your princely status by associating with vile criminals: there’s not an eye in the kingdom that isn’t weary of looking at you. No eyes except mine, that is, which had wished to see more of you; and now they’re acting against me, blinding themselves with foolish tears.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I shall hereafter, my thrice gracious lord,$NEWLINE$Be more myself.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$From now on, my very gracious father, I will behave more like myself.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$For all the world$NEWLINE$As thou art to this hour was Richard then$NEWLINE$When I from France set foot at Ravenspurgh,$NEWLINE$And even as I was then is Percy now.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$At this moment, you seem just like Richard did when I returned from France to lead the revolt. And just as I was then, Percy seems now.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Now, by my scepter, and my soul to boot,$NEWLINE$He hath more worthy interest to the state$NEWLINE$Than thou, the shadow of succession.$NEWLINE$For of no right, nor color like to right,$NEWLINE$He doth fill fields with harness in the realm,$NEWLINE$Turns head against the lion’s armèd jaws,$NEWLINE$And, being no more in debt to years than thou,$NEWLINE$Leads ancient lords and reverend bishops on$NEWLINE$To bloody battles and to bruising arms.$NEWLINE$What never-dying honor hath he got$NEWLINE$Against renownèd Douglas, whose high deeds,$NEWLINE$Whose hot incursions and great name in arms,$NEWLINE$Holds from all soldiers chief majority$NEWLINE$And military title capital$NEWLINE$Through all the kingdoms that acknowledge Christ.$NEWLINE$Thrice hath this Hotspur, Mars in swathling clothes,$NEWLINE$This infant warrior, in his enterprises$NEWLINE$Discomfited great Douglas, ta'en him once,$NEWLINE$Enlargèd him, and made a friend of him,$NEWLINE$To fill the mouth of deep defiance up$NEWLINE$And shake the peace and safety of our throne.$NEWLINE$And what say you to this? Percy, Northumberland,$NEWLINE$The Archbishop’s Grace of York, Douglas, Mortimer,$NEWLINE$Capitulate against us and are up.$NEWLINE$But wherefore do I tell these news to thee?$NEWLINE$Why, Harry, do I tell thee of my foes,$NEWLINE$Which art my nearest and dearest enemy?$NEWLINE$Thou that art like enough, through vassal fear,$NEWLINE$Base inclination, and the start of spleen,$NEWLINE$To fight against me under Percy’s pay,$NEWLINE$To dog his heels, and curtsy at his frowns,$NEWLINE$To show how much thou art degenerate.
paragraphs.translated:
I swear on my scepter and my soul, he has more of a right to the throne than you, you shadowy copy of a king. For without a right to the throne—nor anything even resembling a right—he has filled the kingdom’s battlefields with armies. He seeks to lead an army against the King, into the jaws of the lion. And even though he is no older than you are, he leads old statesmen and venerable bishops into bloody battles and violent wars. What lasting honor he won, by beating the renowned Douglas! That man’s great exploits, violent invasions, and glorious military reputation had won him praise throughout the Christian world as the most outstanding soldier.$NEWLINE$And yet Hotspur, this
Mars in baby clothes, this infant warrior, has defeated Douglas three times, captured him once, then freed him and made him his ally. Now they have become a huge threat to my throne. And what do you have to say about this? Percy, Northumberland, the Archbishop of York, Douglas, and Mortimer have banded together, and now they are after me. But why am I telling you this?$NEWLINE$Mars$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Why should I tell you about my foes, Harry, when you are my most beloved and most dangerous enemy? With your sycophantic fear, your vulgar inclinations, and your short temper, I wouldn’t be surprised if you left me to fight under Percy, following his heels like a dog and bowing to him when he frowns. Just to prove what a degenerate you are.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Do not think so. You shall not find it so.$NEWLINE$And God forgive them that so much have swayed$NEWLINE$Your Majesty’s good thoughts away from me.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Don’t think that; that will not happen. God forgive whoever turned you against me like this! I’ll redeem myself by beating Percy. And at the end of some

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I will redeem all this on Percy’s head,$NEWLINE$And, in the closing of some glorious day,$NEWLINE$Be bold to tell you that I am your son,$NEWLINE$When I will wear a garment all of blood$NEWLINE$And stain my favors in a bloody mask,$NEWLINE$Which, washed away, shall scour my shame with it.$NEWLINE$And that shall be the day, whene'er it lights,$NEWLINE$That this same child of honor and renown,$NEWLINE$This gallant Hotspur, this all-praisèd knight,$NEWLINE$And your unthought-of Harry chance to meet.$NEWLINE$For every honor sitting on his helm,$NEWLINE$Would they were multitudes, and on my head$NEWLINE$My shames redoubled! For the time will come$NEWLINE$That I shall make this northern youth exchange$NEWLINE$His glorious deeds for my indignities.$NEWLINE$Percy is but my factor, good my lord,$NEWLINE$To engross up glorious deeds on my behalf.$NEWLINE$And I will call him to so strict account$NEWLINE$That he shall render every glory up,$NEWLINE$Yea, even the slightest worship of his time,$NEWLINE$Or I will tear the reckoning from his heart.$NEWLINE$This in the name of God I promise here,$NEWLINE$The which if He be pleased I shall perform,$NEWLINE$I do beseech your Majesty may salve$NEWLINE$The long-grown wounds of my intemperance.$NEWLINE$If not, the end of life cancels all bands,$NEWLINE$And I will die a hundred thousand deaths$NEWLINE$Ere break the smallest parcel of this vow.
paragraphs.translated: glorious victory, I’ll come to you and proudly say that I am your son. I will wear a garment made of blood, and my face will be stained by a bloody mask which, when washed away, will clean me of my shame. This will be the day, whenever it happens, that this famous and honored child—this brave Hotspur, this highly praised knight—will meet your disregarded Harry in battle.$NEWLINE$I wish that every honor he’s earned were multiplied, and that every one of my shames were doubled. For the time will come when I’ll make this youth from the north exchange his glorious deeds for my embarrassments. Percy is working for me, my lord. He’s collecting glories on my behalf, and I’m going to hold him strictly accountable for them. He’ll either have to surrender every last one of those glories to me, no matter how small, or I’ll tear them right out of his heart.$NEWLINE$This I promise you, in the name of God. And if God allows me to do these things, then I beg you to heal the wound caused by my long years of bad behavior. If not, then my death will cancel all my debts. I would rather die a hundred-thousand deaths than break even the smallest part of this promise.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$A hundred thousand rebels die in this.$NEWLINE$Thou shalt have charge and sovereign trust herein.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Through this vow, a hundred-thousand rebels are killed. You will be given a position of command, and absolute trust in this undertaking.

paragraphs.original: Enter BLUNT$NEWLINE$BLUNT
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT enters.$NEWLINE$BLUNT

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: How now, good Blunt? Thy looks are full of speed.
paragraphs.translated: What’s wrong, Blunt? You look like there’s an emergency.

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$So hath the business that I come to speak of.$NEWLINE$Lord Mortimer of Scotland hath sent word$NEWLINE$That Douglas and the English rebels met$NEWLINE$The eleventh of this month at Shrewsbury.$NEWLINE$A mighty and a fearful head they are,$NEWLINE$If promises be kept on every hand,$NEWLINE$As ever offered foul play in the state.
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$There is, which is what I’ve come to tell you. Lord Mortimer of Scotland sent word that Douglas and the English rebels met at Shrewsbury, on the eleventh of this month. If everyone involved keeps their word, they will have an army as enormous and terrifying as any that ever caused trouble in this kingdom.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$The Earl of Westmoreland set forth today,$NEWLINE$With him my son, Lord John of Lancaster,$NEWLINE$For this advertisement is five days old.—$NEWLINE$On Wednesday next, Harry, you shall set forward.$NEWLINE$On Thursday we ourselves will march. Our meeting$NEWLINE$Is Bridgenorth. And, Harry, you shall march$NEWLINE$Through Gloucestershire; by which account,$NEWLINE$Our business valuèd, some twelve days hence$NEWLINE$Our general forces at Bridgenorth shall meet.$NEWLINE$Our hands are full of business. Let’s away.$NEWLINE$Advantage feeds him fat while men delay.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$We heard this news five days ago. The Earl of Westmoreland left today, along with my son Lord John of Lancaster. Harry, you’ll go next Wednesday. On Thursday, I will go myself. We’ll meet at Bridgenorth. Harry, you will march through Gloucestershire. Given the amount of time we’ll all need, we should come together with our full forces at Bridgenorth twelve days from now. There’s a lot to do, so let’s go. Our enemies will take advantage if we’re slow.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF and BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF and BARDOLPH enter.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Bardolph, am I not fallen away vilely since this last action? Do I not bate? Do I not dwindle? Why, my skin hangs about me like an like an old lady’s loose gown. I am withered like an old applejohn. Well, I’ll repent, and that suddenly, while I am in some liking. I shall be out of heart shortly, and then I shall have no strength to repent. An I have not forgotten what the inside of a church is made of, I am a peppercorn, a brewer’s horse. The inside of a church! Company, villanous company, hath been the spoil of me.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Bardolph, haven’t I shrivelled since our last robbery? Haven’t I gotten thin? Aren’t I shrinking? My skin is hanging off me like a loose gown on an old lady; I’m puckered like a rotten apple. I’d better repent my sins, and fast, while there’s still something left of me. I’ll be in bad shape soon, and then I won’t have the strength to repent. If I haven’t forgotten what the inside of a church looks like, I’m a withered berry, a lame old nag. The inside of a church! The wrong crowd, the wrong crowd has ruined me.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Sir John, you are so fretful you cannot live long.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Sir John, you complain so much, you’re sure not to live much longer.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Why, there is it. Come sing me a bawdy song, make me merry. I was as virtuously given as a gentleman need to be, virtuous enough: swore little; diced not above seven times— a week; went to a bawdy house once in a quarter—of an hour; paid money that I borrowed, three or four times; lived well and in good compass; and now I live out of all order, out of all compass.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You’re absolutely right. Come on then, sing me a dirty song. Make me laugh. I lived my life as properly as a gentleman should. Well, properly enough, anyway. I didn’t swear much. I didn’t gamble—more than seven days a week. I went to a whorehouse no more than once—every fifteen minutes. I paid my debts—three or four times. I lived well and within reasonable boundaries. And now, I live poorly and out of moderation.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Why, you are so fat, Sir John, that you must needs be out of all compass, out of all reasonable compass, Sir John.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$You’re so fat, Sir John, that you have no choice but to live out of moderation: moderation could not fit you.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Do thou amend thy face, and I’ll amend my life. Thou art our admiral, thou bearest the lantern in the poop, but ’tis in the nose of thee. Thou art the knight of the burning lamp.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You fix your face and I’ll fix my life. You’re like the flagship of our fleet, with a light on its bow—except that your light is in your nose.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Why, Sir John, my face does you no harm.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Why, Sir John, my face isn’t hurting you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No, I’ll be sworn, I make as good use of it as many a man doth of a death’s-head or a memento mori. I never see thy face but I think upon hellfire and Dives that lived in purple, for there he is in his robes, burning, burning. If thou wert any way given to virtue, I would swear by thy face. My oath should be “By this fire, that’s God’s angel.” But thou art altogether given over, and wert indeed, but for the light in thy face, the son of utter darkness. When thou rannest up Gadshill in the night to catch my horse, if I did not think thou hadst been an ignis fatuus, or a ball of wildfire, there’s no purchase in money. O, thou art a perpetual triumph, an everlasting bonfire-light! Thou hast saved me a thousand marks in links and torches, walking with thee in the night betwixt tavern and tavern: but the sack that thou hast drunk me would have bought me lights as good cheap at the dearest chandler’s in Europe. I have maintained that salamander of yours with fire any time this two and thirty years, God reward me for it.$NEWLINE$memento mori$NEWLINE$ignis fatuus
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No, you’re right. I actually get some good from your face: it’s like a skull, or a death token. I can’t look at your face without thinking of the flames of hell, and Dives from the Bible, who burned eternally. If there were anything pious about you, I could swear oaths on your face. I could say, “Now, by this
fire, which is God’s angel …” But you’re a complete sinner, and if it weren’t for the light in your face, you’d be the son of darkness. When you ran up Gadshill at night to find my horse, I could have sworn you were a will-o-the-wisp or a fireball. You’re an endless torchlight parade, a permanent bonfire. Walking with you from tavern to tavern at night has saved me a thousand
marks in candles and flashlights. But the money I’ve spent on wine for you would have been enough to buy the most expensive candles in Europe. I’ve kept that nose of yours burning for thirty-two years, God bless me.$NEWLINE$fire$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$marks$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$'Sblood, I would my face were in your belly!
paragraphs.translated:
BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Dammit! I wish my face were in your
belly.$NEWLINE$belly$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Godamercy, so should I be sure to be heart-burned!
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$God have mercy! Then I’d surely have heartburn.

paragraphs.original: Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY enters.$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY

paragraphs.original: How now, Dame Partlet the hen, have you enquired yet who picked my pocket?
paragraphs.translated: Hello there, Madame Clucking Chicken! Have you figured out yet who picked my pocket?

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Why, Sir John, what do you think, Sir John, do you think I keep thieves in my house? I have searched, I have enquired, so has my husband, man by man, boy by boy, servant by servant. The tithe of a hair was never lost in my house before.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Now Sir John, what do you think, Sir John? Do you think I have thieves in my establishment? I’ve searched, I’ve asked questions; so has my husband. We’ve asked every man, boy and servant here. No one’s ever lost so much as a fraction of a hair in this tavern before.
