paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You lie, hostess. Bardolph was shaved and lost many a hair; and I’ll be sworn my pocket was picked. Go to, you are a woman, go.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You lie! Bardolph got a shave here, and he lost a lot of hair. And I swear my pocket was picked. To hell with you, you’re a woman. To hell with you.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Who, I? No; I defy thee! God’s light, I was never called so in mine own house before.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Who, me? No, I say. By God, I’ve never been called such a thing in my own tavern before.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Go to, I know you well enough.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Oh come on, I know all about you.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$No, Sir John, you do not know me, Sir John. I know you, Sir John. You owe me money, Sir John, and now you pick a quarrel to beguile me of it. I bought you a dozen of shirts to your back.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$No, Sir John; you don’t know me, Sir John. I know you, Sir John. You owe me money, Sir John, and now you’re making a fuss so that you can cheat me out of it. I have bought you a dozen shirts to wear.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Dowlas, filthy dowlas. I have given them away to bakers' wives; they have made bolters of them.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Junk, cheap junk. I gave them away to bakers' wives, to sift flour with.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Now, as I am a true woman, holland of eight shillings an ell. You owe money here besides, Sir John, for your diet and by- drinkings, and money lent you, four and twenty pound.
paragraphs.translated:
MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$I swear, as an honest woman, that they were made of expensive fabric, eight shillings an
ell. Besides, you owe me money for food and drink, plus twenty-four pounds I lent you.$NEWLINE$ell$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(points at BARDOLPH) He had his part of it. Let him pay.$NEWLINE$(points at$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$(points at BARDOLPH) He had some of it. Let him pay.$NEWLINE$(points at$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$He? Alas, he is poor. He hath nothing.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Him? He’s poor, he has nothing.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$How, poor? Look upon his face. What call you rich? Let them coin his nose. Let them coin his cheeks. I’ll not pay a denier. What, will you make a younker of me? Shall I not take mine case in mine inn but I shall have my pocket picked? I have lost a seal ring of my grandfather’s worth forty mark.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What? Poor? Look at his face. What do you call rich? They could make coins from his nose, mint his cheeks. I won’t pay a
denier. You think I’m a rube? What, I can’t relax at a tavern without getting my pocket picked? I lost my grandfather’s sealing ring, worth forty marks.$NEWLINE$denier$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$O Jesu, I have heard the Prince tell him, I know not how oft, that that ring was copper!
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Jesus! I’ve heard the Prince tell him countless times that ring was only made out of copper.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$How? The Prince is a jack, a sneak-up. 'Sblood, an he were here, I would cudgel him like a dog if he would say so.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What? The Prince is a bastard, a sneak. Dammit, if he were here and said something like that, I’d beat him like a dog.

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY and PETO, marching, and FALSTAFF meets them laying on his truncheon like a fife$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PETO$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY and PETO enter, marching like soldiers. FALSTAFF joins them, pretending that his cudgel is a fife, or military flute.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PETO$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: How now, lad, is the wind in that door, i' faith? Must we all march?
paragraphs.translated: Hey there, lad! Is that what’s happening? Are we all going to march?

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yea, two and two, Newgate fashion.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Yes, side by side, like prisoners to the gallows.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$My lord, I pray you, hear me.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$My lord, please, listen to me.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What sayest thou, Mistress Quickly? How doth thy husband? I love him well; he is an honest man.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What is it, Mistress Quickly? How’s your husband? I think highly of him; he’s an honest man.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Good my lord, hear me.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$My lord, please listen to me.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Prithee, let her alone, and list to me.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Forget about her, and listen to me.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What say’st thou, Jack?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What is it, Jack?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$The other night I fell asleep here behind the arras, and had my pocket picked. This house is turned bawdy house; they pick pockets.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$The other night I fell asleep here behind the arras and I had my pocket picked. This bar’s like a whorehouse: they pick your pockets.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What didst thou lose, Jack?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What did you lose, Jack?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Wilt thou believe me, Hal, three or four bonds of forty pound apiece, and a seal ring of my grandfather’s.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Would you believe it, Hal? Three or four I.O.U.’s worth forty pounds each, and my grandfather’s sealing ring.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$A trifle, some eightpenny matter.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Junk, not worth more than eight pennies.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$So I told him, my lord, and I said I heard your Grace say so. And, my lord, he speaks most vilely of you, like a foul- mouthed man as he is;,and said he would cudgel you.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$That’s what I said, my lord. And I said I’d heard you say so, and then he said awful things about you, like the foul-mouthed man that he is. He said he’d beat you.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What, he did not!
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What? He did?

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$There’s neither faith, truth, nor womanhood in me else.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$If he didn’t, I’m not faithful, trustworthy or womanly.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$There’s no more faith in thee than in a stewed prune, nor no more truth in thee than in a drawn fox, and for womanhood, Maid Marian may be the deputy’s wife of the ward to thee. Go, you thing, go.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You’re about as faithful as a whore, as trustworthy as a fox on the run, and—as for womanhood—a man in a dress is the minister’s wife compared to you. Get out of here, you thing, get out.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Say, what thing, what thing?
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Thing? What thing?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What thing! Why, a thing to thank God on.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What thing? A thing to say “thank God” for.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$I am no thing to thank God on, I would thou shouldst know it! I am an honest man’s wife, and, setting thy knighthood aside, thou art a knave to call me so.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$I am not a thing to say “thank God” for, I want you to know; I am an honest man’s wife. And ignoring the fact that you are a knight, you are a brute for calling me that.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Setting thy womanhood aside, thou art a beast to say otherwise.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, if you ignore the fact that you’re a woman, then I suppose that would make you an animal.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Say, what beast, thou knave, thou?
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$What animal, you brute?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What beast? Why, an otter.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What animal? Why, an otter.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$An otter, Sir John. Why an otter?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$An otter, Sir John? Why an otter?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Why, she’s neither fish nor flesh; a man knows not where to have her.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Because she’s not quite a fish and not quite a mammal. A man wouldn’t know where to put her.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Thou art an unjust man in saying so. Thou or any man knows where to have me, thou knave, thou.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$You’re awful for saying so: you or any man would know where to put me, you brute, you!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Thou sayest true, hostess, and he slanders thee most grossly.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You’re right, hostess, and he has really insulted you.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$So he doth you, my lord, and said this other day you owed him a thousand pound.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$He insulted you, too, my lord. Just the other day, he said you owed him a thousand pounds.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Sirrah, do I owe you a thousand pound?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Sirrah, do I owe you a thousand pounds?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A thousand pound, Hal? A million. Thy love is worth a million; thou owest me thy love.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$A thousand pounds, Hal? A million. Your love is worth a million, and you owe me your love.

paragraphs.original: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Nay, my lord, he called you “jack,” and said he would cudgel you.
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$No, sir. He called you a bastard and said he’d beat you.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Did I, Bardolph?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Did I, Bardolph?

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Indeed, Sir John, you said so.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Indeed, Sir John, you said so.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Yea, if he said my ring was copper.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$That’s right, if he said my ring was junk and made of copper.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I say ’tis copper. Darest thou be as good as thy word now?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And I do say that it’s made of copper. So will you dare keep your word and beat me?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Why, Hal, thou knowest, as thou art but man, I dare, but as thou art Prince, I fear thee as I fear the roaring of a lion’s whelp.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hal, know this: if you were only a man, I would dare. But since you’re also a Prince, I’m scared of you, as much as I’m scared by the roar of a lion’s cub.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$And why not as the lion?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why the cub and not the lion?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$The King is to be feared as the lion. Dost thou think I’ll fear thee as I fear thy father? Nay, an I do, I pray God my girdle break.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Only the King is as frightening as the lion. You think I’m as scared of you as I am of your father? If I am, I pray to God for my
belt to break.$NEWLINE$belt$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$O, if it should, how would thy guts fall about thy knees! But, sirrah, there’s no room for faith, truth, nor honesty in this bosom of thine. It is all filled up with guts and midriff. Charge an honest woman with picking thy pocket? Why, thou whoreson, impudent, embossed rascal, if there were anything in thy pocket but tavern reckonings, memorandums of bawdy houses, and one poor pennyworth, of sugar candy to make thee long-winded, if thy pocket were enriched with any other injuries but these, I am a villain. And, yet you will stand to it! You will not pocket up wrong! Art thou not ashamed?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Oh, but if it did, your guts would fall down to your knees! Sirrah, there’s no room in your chest for trustworthiness, truthfulness, or honesty. It’s all filled up with guts and stomach. Accuse an honest woman of picking your pocket? You son of a whore; you rude, bloated cheat. I’ll be damned if there was anything in your pocket besides tavern bills, notes about whorehouses, and a penny’s worth of candy for energy. If you had anything else in your pockets, then I’m a liar; yet you stand by your lies. You won’t even try to hide how bad you are. Aren’t you ashamed of yourself?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Dost thou hear, Hal? Thou knowest in the state of innocency Adam fell, and what should poor Jack Falstaff do in the days of villany? Thou seest I have more flesh than another man and therefore more frailty. You confess, then, you picked my pocket?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Don’t you know, Hal? Adam fell from grace when the world was innocent. What should poor Jack Falstaff do, now that the world is wicked? You see I have more flesh than other men. It follows that I’m more fallible than other men.—So you’re confessing to picking my pocket?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$It appears so by the story.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$It looks that way.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hostess, I forgive thee. Go make ready breakfast, love thy, husband, look to thy servants, cherish thy guests. Thou shalt find me tractable to any honest reason. Thou seest I am pacified still. Nay, prithee, be gone.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hostess, I forgive you. Go get breakfast ready; love your husband; tend to your servants; cherish your guests. You’ll find me a perfectly reasonable man. See? I’m calm, as always. Now please, get going!

paragraphs.original: Exit MISTRESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY exits.$NEWLINE$MISTRESS QUICKLY

paragraphs.original: Now, Hal, to the news at court. For the robbery, lad, how is that answered?
paragraphs.translated: Now Hal, what’s the news at court? What ever happened about our robbery?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$O, my sweet beef, I must still be good angel to thee. The money is paid back again.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I’m your guardian angel again, you fresh piece of meat. The money’s been paid back.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$O, I do not like that paying back. 'Tis a double labor.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I don’t like that “paying back.” It means twice the work!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I am good friends with my father and may do anything.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$My father and I are friends again, and I can do whatever I want.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Rob me the Exchequer the first thing thou dost, and do it with unwashed hands too.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Then rob the treasury right away, and don’t even delay long enough to wash your hands.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Do, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Do it, my lord.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I have procured thee, Jack, a charge of foot.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I have gotten you an infantry company to command, Jack.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I would it had been of horse. Where shall I find one that can steal well? O, for a fine thief of the age of two and twenty or thereabouts! I am heinously unprovided. Well, God be thanked for these rebels. They offend none but the virtuous. I laud them; I praise them.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I wish it were the horse brigade. Where can I recruit a talented crook? Oh, if I only had a gifted thief, about twenty-two years old! I’m terribly lacking in help. Well, thank God for these rebels. The only people they bother are the good people. I like that. I honor and salute them.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Bardolph!
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Bardolph!

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$My lord.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$My lord?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Go bear this letter to Lord John of Lancaster,$NEWLINE$To my brother John; this to my Lord of Westmoreland.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Deliver this letter to Lord John of Lancaster, my brother. Give this one to Westmoreland.

paragraphs.original: Exit BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH exits.$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: Go, Peto, to horse, to horse, for thou and I have thirty miles to ride yet ere dinner time.
paragraphs.translated: Peto, get to your horse, get to your horse! You and I have to be thirty miles from here by lunchtime.

paragraphs.original: Exit PETO$NEWLINE$PETO
paragraphs.translated: PETO exits.$NEWLINE$PETO

paragraphs.original: Jack, meet me tomorrow in the Temple hall$NEWLINE$At two o'clock in the afternoon;$NEWLINE$There shalt thou know thy charge, and there receive$NEWLINE$Money and order for their furniture.$NEWLINE$The land is burning. Percy stands on high,$NEWLINE$And either we or they must lower lie.
paragraphs.translated:
Jack, meet me at
Temple Hall at two o'clock tomorrow. You’ll get the list of your troops there, plus some money and an order for their equipment. The country is on fire, and Percy’s riding high. Either they or we must die.$NEWLINE$Temple Hall$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exit PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY exits.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Rare words, brave world!—Hostess, my breakfast, come.—$NEWLINE$O, I could wish this tavern were my drum.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well spoken! What a splendid world! Bring my breakfast, hostess! I wish that I could lead my troops from here!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter HOTSPUR, WORCESTER, and DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR, WORCESTER , and DOUGLAS enter.$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Well said, my noble Scot. If speaking truth$NEWLINE$In this fine age were not thought flattery,$NEWLINE$Such attribution should the Douglas have$NEWLINE$As not a soldier of this season’s stamp$NEWLINE$Should go so general current through the world.$NEWLINE$By God, I cannot flatter. I do defy$NEWLINE$The tongues of soothers. But a braver place$NEWLINE$In my heart’s love hath no man than yourself.$NEWLINE$Nay, task me to my word; approve me, lord.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Well said, you excellent Scotsman. If people these days didn’t confuse the truth with flattery, I would praise you highly. No other soldier so newly tested in battle would have gained such a widespread reputation. God knows, I don’t flatter: I hate people who give out praise too easily. But you have a place in my heart that no other man has. Make me prove it; try me.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Thou art the king of honor.$NEWLINE$No man so potent breathes upon the ground$NEWLINE$But I will beard him.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$You are the most honorable man alive, and if any man challenges that—no matter how powerful—I’ll defy him.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Do so, and ’tis well.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$You do that. Well done.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER with letters$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters with letters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: What letters hast thou there? (to DOUGLAS) I can but thank you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: What letters have you got there? (to DOUGLAS ) All I can do is thank you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$These letters come from your father.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$These letters come from your father.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Letters from him! Why comes he not himself?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Letters from him? Why isn’t he here in person?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He cannot come, my lord. He is grievous sick.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He can’t come, my lord; he’s terribly sick.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Zounds, how has he the leisure to be sick$NEWLINE$In such a justling time? Who leads his power?$NEWLINE$Under whose government come they along?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Damn! How can he take the leisure of being sick at such a frantic time? Who’s in charge of his army? Who’s leading them here?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$His letters bear his mind, not I, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$His letters will tell you his plans, my lord, not I.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$I prithee, tell me, doth he keep his bed?
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Pardon me, but is he bedridden?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He did, my lord, four days ere I set forth,$NEWLINE$And, at the time of my departure thence,$NEWLINE$He was much feared by his physicians.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He had been, sir, for four days before I left. And on the day I left, his doctors were extremely concerned.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$I would the state of time had first been whole$NEWLINE$Ere he by sickness had been visited.$NEWLINE$His health was never better worth than now.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$I wish he’d waited till things were settled before he went and got sick. We’ve never needed him more than now.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Sick now? Droop now? This sickness doth infect$NEWLINE$The very lifeblood of our enterprise.$NEWLINE$'Tis catching hither, even to our camp.$NEWLINE$He writes me here that inward sickness—$NEWLINE$And that his friends by deputation$NEWLINE$Could not so soon be drawn, nor did he think it meet$NEWLINE$To lay so dangerous and dear a trust$NEWLINE$On any soul removed but on his own;$NEWLINE$Yet doth he give us bold advertisement$NEWLINE$That with our small conjunction we should on$NEWLINE$To see how fortune is disposed to us,$NEWLINE$For, as he writes, there is no quailing now,$NEWLINE$Because the King is certainly possessed$NEWLINE$Of all our purposes. What say you to it?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Sick now? Faint now? His disease is infecting our entire project. It’s spread all the way to here, right to our camp. He writes that some internal illness—and that his allies couldn’t be gathered so quickly by one of his deputies. Besides, he didn’t think it was appropriate to delegate such a dangerous and important task to someone other than himself. But he also says that we should be bold and press on with our small contingent. For, as he writes, there’s no turning back now, since the King surely knows our plans. What do you think?

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Your father’s sickness is a maim to us.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Your father’s sickness is a serious injury to us.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$A perilous gash, a very limb lopped off!$NEWLINE$And yet, in faith, it is not. His present want$NEWLINE$Seems more than we shall find it. Were it good$NEWLINE$To set the exact wealth of all our states$NEWLINE$All at one cast? To set so rich a main$NEWLINE$On the nice hazard of one doubtful hour?$NEWLINE$It were not good, for therein should we read$NEWLINE$The very bottom and the soul of hope,$NEWLINE$The very list, the very utmost bound$NEWLINE$Of all our fortunes.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$It’s a perilous wound, like losing a limb. And yet, truly, it’s not that bad; the loss of my father seems worse than it is. After all, is it a good idea to bet all our resources on one throw of the dice? Or to gamble such a rich stake on a single hazardous event? No, because that would mean we had reached the end of our hope, and the very limit of our luck.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Faith, and so we should, where now remains$NEWLINE$A sweet reversion. We may boldly spend$NEWLINE$Upon the hope of what is to come in.$NEWLINE$A comfort of retirement lives in this.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$That’s right. We have a chance at a rich inheritance; we can take a risk now, based on the promise of success to come. That gives us comfort, something to fall back on.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$A rendezvous, a home to fly unto,$NEWLINE$If that the devil and mischance look big$NEWLINE$Upon the maidenhead of our affairs.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$It gives us a refuge, a home we can always run to, in case the devil or misfortune ruins these early plans.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$But yet I would your father had been here.$NEWLINE$The quality and hair of our attempt$NEWLINE$Brooks no division. It will be thought$NEWLINE$By some that know not why he is away$NEWLINE$That wisdom, loyalty, and mere dislike$NEWLINE$Of our proceedings kept the Earl from hence.$NEWLINE$And think how such an apprehension$NEWLINE$May turn the tide of fearful faction$NEWLINE$And breed a kind of question in our cause.$NEWLINE$For well you know, we of the off'ring side$NEWLINE$Must keep aloof from strict arbitrament,$NEWLINE$And stop all sight-holes, every loop from whence$NEWLINE$The eye of reason may pry in upon us.$NEWLINE$This absence of your father’s draws a curtain$NEWLINE$That shows the ignorant a kind of fear$NEWLINE$Before not dreamt of.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$I still wish your father were here. Our endeavor here won’t withstand any division. People who don’t realize your father is sick will assume that he knows some kind of secret, or that he is loyal to the King, or that he doesn’t approve of how we’re handling things. And just imagine how that kind of mistrust could frighten our more timid supporters, and lead them to doubt us. You know very well that the challenger must always avoid careful examination. We must seal every crack, every loophole, which skeptics might look through to see weaknesses. Your father’s absence draws the curtains back and reveals frightful things to ignorant people, who had never had a reason to fear before.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$You strain too far.$NEWLINE$I rather of his absence make this use:$NEWLINE$It lends a luster and more great opinion,$NEWLINE$A larger dare, to our great enterprise$NEWLINE$Than if the Earl were here, for men must think$NEWLINE$If we without his help can make a head$NEWLINE$To push against a kingdom, with his help$NEWLINE$We shall o'erturn it topsy-turvy down.$NEWLINE$Yet all goes well, yet all our joints are whole.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$You’re taking this too far. I’d rather think about his absence this way: it makes us look even better. It makes our great undertaking seem even more daring than it would if Northumberland were here. People will think that if we can raise an army against the King without my father, that once he joins we’ll turn the whole kingdom upside down. Everything is fine, we’re all in one piece.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$As heart can think. There is not such a word$NEWLINE$Spoke of in Scotland as this term of fear.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$We’re as well off as we could have hoped. In Scotland, we don’t even know the meaning of the word fear.

paragraphs.original: Enter Sir Richard VERNON$NEWLINE$VERNON
paragraphs.translated: Sir Richard VERNON enters$NEWLINE$VERNON

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$My cousin Vernon, welcome, by my soul.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Welcome, kinsman Vernon, from the bottom of my heart.

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$Pray God my news be worth a welcome, lord.$NEWLINE$The Earl of Westmoreland, seven thousand strong,$NEWLINE$Is marching hitherwards, with him Prince John.
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$I pray to God that what I have to say is worth welcoming, my lord. The Earl of Westmoreland, with seven thousand men, is marching this way. Prince John is with him.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$No harm, what more?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Nothing to be worried about. What else?

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$And further I have learned,$NEWLINE$The King himself in person is set forth,$NEWLINE$Or hitherwards intended speedily,$NEWLINE$With strong and mighty preparation.
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$I’ve also learned that the King himself is coming this way, or at least plans to very soon, with a huge and powerful force.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$He shall be welcome too. Where is his son,$NEWLINE$The nimble-footed madcap Prince of Wales,$NEWLINE$And his comrades, that daffed the world aside$NEWLINE$And bid it pass?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$We’ll welcome him too. Where’s his son, that sporting, foolhardy Prince of Wales, and his comrades, who don’t care about anything?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$All furnished, all in arms,$NEWLINE$All plumed like estridges that with the wind$NEWLINE$Baited like eagles having lately bathed,$NEWLINE$Glittering in golden coats like images,$NEWLINE$As full of spirit as the month of May,$NEWLINE$And gorgeous as the sun at midsummer,$NEWLINE$Wanton as youthful goats, wild as young bulls.$NEWLINE$I saw young Harry with his beaver on,$NEWLINE$His cuisses on his thighs, gallantly armed$NEWLINE$Rise from the ground like feathered Mercury$NEWLINE$And vaulted with such ease into his seat$NEWLINE$As if an angel dropped down from the clouds,$NEWLINE$To turn and wind a fiery Pegasus$NEWLINE$And witch the world with noble horsemanship.
paragraphs.translated:
VERNON$NEWLINE$They’re all in uniform, all armed. They look like feathered ostriches; like eagles beating their wings after a bath; like statues painted gold. They’re as lively as the springtime; as gorgeous as the midsummer sun; as giddy as young goats; as wild as young bulls. I saw young Harry with his helmet on, and armor on his thighs. Armed with powerful weapons, he rose off the ground like the winged god Mercury, and leaped so effortlessly into his saddle, it was as if an angel had dropped out of the sky to ride a fiery
Pegasus, and bewitch the world with his incredible horsemanship.$NEWLINE$Pegasus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$No more, no more! Worse than the sun in March$NEWLINE$This praise doth nourish agues. Let them come.$NEWLINE$They come like sacrifices in their trim,$NEWLINE$And to the fire-eyed maid of smoky war$NEWLINE$All hot and bleeding will we offer them.$NEWLINE$The mailèd Mars shall on his altar sit$NEWLINE$Up to the ears in blood. I am on fire$NEWLINE$To hear this rich reprisal is so nigh$NEWLINE$And yet not ours. Come, let me taste my horse,$NEWLINE$Who is to bear me like a thunderbolt$NEWLINE$Against the bosom of the Prince of Wales.$NEWLINE$Harry to Harry shall, hot horse to horse,$NEWLINE$Meet and ne'er part till one drop down a corse.$NEWLINE$O, that Glendower were come!
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Stop, stop! This praise of him makes me sicker than the sun on an early spring day. Let them come, like sacrifices in all their finery; we’ll offer them, hot and bleeding, to the fire-eyed goddess of smoky war. The war-god Mars will sit on his altar, up to his ears in blood. I am on fire, knowing that this rich prize is so near, and yet still not ours. Come, bring me my horse, who will carry me like a lightning bolt to face the Prince of Wales. Then this Harry will meet that Harry, my horse against his horse; we’ll meet and never separate, till one of us falls down as a corpse. Oh, I wish that Glendower were here!

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$There is more news.$NEWLINE$I learned in Worcester, as I rode along,$NEWLINE$He cannot draw his power this fourteen days.
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$I have more news: as I passed through the town of Worcester, I heard that Glendower won’t be able to collect his army for two more weeks.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$That’s the worst tidings that I hear of yet.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$That’s the worst news I’ve heard so far.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Ay, by my faith, that bears a frosty sound.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Yes, truly, that news makes me cold.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$What may the King’s whole battle reach unto?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$How many men in the King’s army?

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$To thirty thousand.
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$Thirty thousand.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Forty let it be.$NEWLINE$My father and Glendower being both away,$NEWLINE$The powers of us may serve so great a day.$NEWLINE$Come, let us take a muster speedily.$NEWLINE$Doomsday is near. Die all, die merrily.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Let it be forty. Even with both my father and Glendower absent, our armies may still be enough to win. Come on, let’s gather our troops right now. It’s almost doomsday; if we die, we die cheerfully.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Talk not of dying. I am out of fear$NEWLINE$Of death or death’s hand for this one half year.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Don’t talk about dying. I won’t even worry about dying for the next six months.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF and BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF and BARDOLPH enter.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Bardolph, get thee before to Coventry. Fill me a bottle of sack. Our soldiers shall march through. We’ll to Sutton Coldfield tonight.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Bardolph, go ahead of us to Coventry, and fill me a bottle of wine. Our army will keep marching, and we’ll make it to Sutton Coldfield tonight.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Will you give me money, captain?
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Will you give me some money, captain?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Lay out, lay out.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Spend your own.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$This bottle makes an angel.
paragraphs.translated:
BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$If I buy you this bottle, that makes me
an angel.$NEWLINE$an angel$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$An if it do, take it for thy labor. An if it make twenty, take them all. I’ll answer the coinage. Bid my lieutenant Peto meet me at town’s end.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, if this bottle earns you an angel, then keep it for your troubles. If you earn twenty angels, then keep them all; I’m good for it. Tell my lieutenant Peto to meet me at the city limit.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I will, captain. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I will, captain. Farewell.

paragraphs.original: Exit BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH exits.$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$If I be not ashamed of my soldiers, I am a soused gurnet. I have misused the King’s press damnably. I have got, in exchange of a hundred and fifty soldiers, three hundred and odd pounds. I press me none but good householders, yeomen’s sons; inquire me out contracted bachelors, such as had been asked twice on the banns; such a commodity of warm slaves—as had as lief hear the devil as a drum, such as fear the report of a caliver worse than a struck fowl or a hurt wild duck. I pressed me none but such toasts-and-butter, with hearts in their bellies no bigger than pins' heads, and
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$If I’m not ashamed of my soldiers, then I’m a pickled fish. I’ve taken terrible advantage of my position. I’ve pressed a hundred and fifty soldiers into service, and for that, the treasury has paid me over three hundred pounds. I recruited only well-to-do property owners and rich farmer’s sons. I looked for men who were engaged to be married, who were already halfway through their preparations. I found a whole supply of pampered cowards who would rather listen to the devil than a military march; who feared the sound of gunfire

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: they have bought out their services, and now my whole charge consists of ancients, corporals, lieutenants, gentlemen of companies—slaves as ragged as Lazarus in the painted cloth, where the glutton’s dogs licked his sores; and such as indeed were never soldiers, but discarded, unjust servingmen, younger sons to younger brothers, revolted tapsters, and ostlers tradefallen, the cankers of a calm world and a long peace, ten times more dishonorable-ragged than an old feazed ancient; and such have I to fill up the rooms of them that have bought out their services, that you would think that I had a hundred and fifty tattered prodigals lately come from swine-keeping, from eating draff and husks. A mad fellow met me on the way and told me I had unloaded all the gibbets and pressed the dead bodies. No eye hath seen such scarecrows. I’ll not march through Coventry with them, that’s flat. Nay, and the villains march wide betwixt the legs as if they had gyves on, for indeed I had the most of them out of prison. There’s not a shirt and a half in all my company, and the half shirt is two napkins tacked together and thrown over the shoulders like a herald’s coat without sleeves; and the shirt, to say the truth, stolen from my host at Saint Albans or the red-nose innkeeper of Daventry. But that’s all one; they’ll find linen enough on every hedge.
paragraphs.translated:
more than a wounded bird or a maimed duck might. I recruited only the soft-hearted, who each had as much courage as could fit on a pin head and bribed me to avoid fighting. So now, my battalion is made up of flag bearers, corporals, lieutenants, and crooks as ragged as
Lazarus in those paintings where the dogs are licking the sores on his body. I have men who’ve never been soldiers: servants dismissed for their dishonesty; youngest sons with no hope of an inheritance; runaway apprentice bartenders; unemployed stable boys. When the world is calm and peaceful, these men are blisters on society. They’re ten times more ragged than an old, tattered flag, and they’re the kind of men I have to replace the ones who bribed me. You’d think I had a hundred and fifty men who’d just come from pig farming, who eat scraps and garbage. One madman saw us on the march and told me that it looked as if I’d unloaded all the gallows and drafted all the dead bodies. No one’s ever seen such a group of scarecrows. I’m not going to march through Coventry with them tonight, that’s for sure. They march with their legs wide apart, as though they had chains on their ankles. Which makes sense, since I drafted most of them out of jails. There’s only a shirt and a half in the whole group, and the half-shirt is really just two napkins sewn together and thrown over the shoulders like a cape. And the whole shirt, to tell the truth, was stolen from a tavern owner in St. Alban’s, or maybe that drunken innkeeper in Daventry. But that doesn’t matter. They’ll be able to steal plenty of clothing from the hedges, where the washers hang the laundry out to dry.$NEWLINE$Lazarus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY and Lord WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY and Lord WESTMORELAND enter.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$How now, blown Jack? How now, quilt?
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What’s up, swollen
Jack! What’s up, quilt?$NEWLINE$Jack!$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What, Hal, how now, mad wag? What a devil dost thou in Warwickshire?—My good Lord of Westmoreland, I cry you mercy: I thought your Honor had already been at Shrewsbury.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hello there, Hal, you crazy boy! What in the devil’s name are you doing in Warwickshire? And Lord Westmoreland, I beg your pardon. I thought you were already at Shrewsbury.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Faith, Sir John,’tis more than time that I were there and you too, but my powers are there already. The King, I can tell you, looks for us all. We must away all night.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$You’re right, Sir John; it’s about time I got there, and you, too. But my army’s already there. The King is waiting for us, so we must march all night.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Tut, never fear me. I am as vigilant as a cat to steal cream.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Don’t worry about me. I’m as focused as a cat looking for cream to steal.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I think to steal cream indeed, for thy theft hath already made thee butter. But tell me, Jack, whose fellows are these that come after?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Steal cream is right—you’ve stolen so much that it’s turned you into butter. But tell me, Jack, whose soldiers are those?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Mine, Hal, mine.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Mine, Hal, mine.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I did never see such pitiful rascals.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I never saw such pitiful-looking losers.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Tut, tut, good enough to toss; food for powder, food for powder. They’ll fill a pit as well as better. Tush, man, mortal men, mortal men.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Now, now: they’re good enough to die. Cannon fodder, cannon fodder—they’ll fill a mass grave as well as better men would. They’re just men, just men.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Ay, but, Sir John, methinks they are exceeding poor and bare, too beggarly.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Maybe so, Sir John, but I think they look terribly poor and bare; they look like beggars.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Faith, for their poverty, I know not where they had that, and for their bareness, I am sure they never learned that of me.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, I don’t know where they got their poverty, but their bareness—or their bare-bonedness—well, they didn’t get that from me.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$No, I’ll be sworn, unless you call three fingers in the ribs bare. But, sirrah, make haste. Percy is already in the field.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$That’s for sure. Unless you think several inches of fat over your ribs makes you “bare-boned.” But hurry up, sirrah: Percy is already at the battlefield.

paragraphs.original: Exit PRINCE.$NEWLINE$PRINCE
paragraphs.translated: PERCY exits.$NEWLINE$PERCY

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What, is the King encamped?
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$What, has the King already made camp?

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$He is, Sir John. I fear we shall stay too long.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$He has, Sir John: I’m afraid we may be too late.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well,$NEWLINE$To the latter end of a fray and the beginning of a feast$NEWLINE$Fits a dull fighter and a keen guest.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, a hungry guest arrives early for a feast, but a poor soldier arrives late to a battle.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter HOTSPUR, WORCESTER, DOUGLAS, and VERNON$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$VERNON
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR, WORCESTER, DOUGLAS, and VERNON enter.$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$VERNON

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$We’ll fight with him tonight.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$We’ll fight him tonight.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$It may not be.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$We can’t do that.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$You give him then advantage.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Then you’re giving him the advantage.

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$Not a whit.
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$Not in the least.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Why say you so? Looks he not for supply?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Why do you say that? Doesn’t he have backup coming?

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$So do we.
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$So do we.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$His is certain; ours is doubtful.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$His is guaranteed. Ours isn’t.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Good cousin, be advised. Stir not tonight.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Nephew, I’m telling you. Don’t start the fighting tonight.

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$(to HOTSPUR ) Do not, my lord.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$(to HOTSPUR ) Don’t, my lord.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$You do not counsel well.$NEWLINE$You speak it out of fear and cold heart.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$You’re giving poor advice, based on fear and cowardice.

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$Do me no slander, Douglas. By my life$NEWLINE$(And I dare well maintain it with my life),$NEWLINE$If well-respected honor bid me on,$NEWLINE$I hold as little counsel with weak fear$NEWLINE$As you, my lord, or any Scot that this day lives.$NEWLINE$Let it be seen tomorrow in the battle$NEWLINE$Which of us fears.
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$Don’t slander me, Douglas. I swear on my life—and I’ll prove it with my life—that if I’m roused to fight through thoughtful, careful consideration, I’m just as unafraid as you, my lord, or any Scotsman alive. In tomorrow’s battle, we’ll see which one of us is afraid.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Yea, or tonight.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Fine. Or tonight.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$Content.
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$That’s enough.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Tonight, say I.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Tonight, I say.

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$Come, come it nay not be. I wonder much,$NEWLINE$Being men of such great leading as you are,$NEWLINE$That you foresee not what impediments$NEWLINE$Drag back our expedition. Certain horse$NEWLINE$Of my cousin Vernon’s are not yet come up.$NEWLINE$Your Uncle Worcester’s horse came but today,$NEWLINE$And now their pride and mettle is asleep,$NEWLINE$Their courage with hard labor tame and dull,$NEWLINE$That not a horse is half the half of himself.
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$Come on, we can’t do that. I wonder how—being the great leaders you are—you cannot see the problems we’re facing. My cousin has yet to arrive with his horses, and your Uncle Worcester’s troops only arrived today. Their spirit and their bravery is asleep; their courage is dulled and tamed by the hard journey. They don’t have even a quarter of their usual strength.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$So are the horses of the enemy$NEWLINE$In general journey-bated and brought low.$NEWLINE$The better part of ours are full of rest.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$The enemy’s horses are tired from the journey as well. The majority of ours are well-rested.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$The number of the King exceedeth ours.$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, cousin, stay till all come in.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$But the King has more men then we do. For God’s sake, nephew, wait until everyone arrives.

paragraphs.original: The trumpet sounds a parley
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet announces the approach of an envoy.

paragraphs.original: Enter BLUNT$NEWLINE$BLUNT
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT enters.$NEWLINE$BLUNT

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$I come with gracious offers from the King,$NEWLINE$If you vouchsafe me hearing and respect.
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$I’m here with a generous offer from the King, if you’ll listen to me and treat me with respect.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Welcome, Sir Walter Blunt, and would to God$NEWLINE$You were of our determination.$NEWLINE$Some of us love you well, and even those some$NEWLINE$Envy your great deservings and good name$NEWLINE$Because you are not of our quality$NEWLINE$But stand against us like an enemy.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Welcome, Sir Walter Blunt. I wish to God you were on our side. Many of us think very highly of you, though we begrudge you your honor and reputation, since you fight on the enemy’s side.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$And God defend but still I should stand so,$NEWLINE$So long as out of limit and true rule$NEWLINE$You stand against anointed majesty.$NEWLINE$But to my charge. The king hath sent to know$NEWLINE$The nature of your griefs, and whereupon$NEWLINE$You conjure from the breast of civil peace$NEWLINE$Such bold hostility, teaching his duteous land$NEWLINE$Audacious cruelty. If that the king$NEWLINE$Have any way your good deserts forgot,$NEWLINE$Which he confesseth to be manifold,$NEWLINE$He bids you name your griefs, and with all speed$NEWLINE$You shall have your desires with interest$NEWLINE$And pardon absolute for yourself and these$NEWLINE$Herein misled by your suggestion.
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$And I hope to God I always will, so long as you overstep the bounds of allegiance and duty by standing against the anointed King. But let me get to the point. The King sent me to learn your complaints, and to find out why you are stirring up warfare in a time of peace, and spreading violent dissent throughout his loyal country. If the King has somehow overlooked one of your deserving acts—which, he admits, there are many—he asks you to name your complaints. He’ll meet your demands, with interest, as quickly as possible, and grant an absolute pardon to you and everyone who has followed your mistaken lead.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$The king is kind, and well we know the king$NEWLINE$Knows at what time to promise, when to pay.$NEWLINE$My father and my uncle and myself$NEWLINE$Did give him that same royalty he wears,$NEWLINE$And when he was not six-and-twenty strong,$NEWLINE$Sick in the world’s regard, wretched and low,$NEWLINE$A poor unminded outlaw sneaking home,$NEWLINE$My father gave him welcome to the shore;$NEWLINE$And when he heard him swear and vow to God$NEWLINE$He came but to be Duke of Lancaster,$NEWLINE$To sue his livery, and beg his peace,$NEWLINE$With tears of innocency and terms of zeal,$NEWLINE$My father, in kind heart and pity moved,$NEWLINE$Swore him assistance and performed it too.$NEWLINE$Now when the lords and barons of the realm$NEWLINE$Perceived Northumberland did lean to him,$NEWLINE$The more and less came in with cap and knee,$NEWLINE$Met him in boroughs, cities, villages,$NEWLINE$Attended him on bridges, stood in lanes,$NEWLINE$Laid gifts before him, proffered him their oaths,$NEWLINE$Gave him their heirs as pages, followed him$NEWLINE$Even at the heels in golden multitudes.$NEWLINE$He presently, as greatness knows itself,$NEWLINE$Steps me a little higher than his vow$NEWLINE$Made to my father while his blood was poor$NEWLINE$Upon the naked shore at Ravenspurgh,$NEWLINE$And now forsooth takes on him to reform$NEWLINE$Some certain edicts and some strait decrees$NEWLINE$That lie too heavy on the commonwealth,$NEWLINE$Cries out upon abuses, seems to weep$NEWLINE$Over his country’s wrongs, and by this face,$NEWLINE$This seeming brow of justice, did he win$NEWLINE$The hearts of all that he did angle for,$NEWLINE$Proceeded further—cut me off the heads$NEWLINE$Of all the favourites that the absent King$NEWLINE$In deputation left behind him here$NEWLINE$When he was personal in the Irish war.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$That’s kind of the King. We know all too well about the promises the King makes, and the ways he keeps his word. My father, my uncle, and I put that crown on his head. And when he had barely twenty-six men supporting him, when no one cared about him, when he was wretched and low, a poor, forsaken criminal trying to sneak home, my father welcomed him. When he swore an oath to God, weeping and speaking passionately, that he had come back to England only to reclaim his father’s title and make peace with King Richard, my father took pity on him, swore to help him and did so.$NEWLINE$When the country’s most important men saw that Northumberland was on his side, they came to see Henry, and bowed down to him. They met him in towns, cities, villages; they waited for him on bridges, stood in the streets, lay gifts before him, swore their loyalty, pledged the support of their sons, followed him like servants. Soon enough, he began to understand his power. He overstepped the promise he’d made to my father at Ravenspurgh, when his blood was still humble. And then, suddenly, he took it upon himself to reform certain laws and strict decrees that weighed too heavily on the kingdom. He made angry speeches about the abuses we were suffering, and seemed to weep over the country’s problems.$NEWLINE$And with this face, this mask of righteousness, he won everyone’s hearts. Then he went even further, and cut off the heads of all of Richard’s deputies, who stayed behind to run the country while Richard was waging war in Ireland.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$Tut, I came not to hear this.
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$I didn’t come here to listen to this.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Then to the point.$NEWLINE$In short time after, he deposed the King,$NEWLINE$Soon after that deprived him of his life$NEWLINE$And, in the neck of that, tasked the whole state.$NEWLINE$To make that worse, suffered his kinsman March$NEWLINE$(Who is, if every owner were well placed,$NEWLINE$Indeed his king) to be engaged in Wales,$NEWLINE$There without ransom to lie forfeited,$NEWLINE$Disgraced me in my happy victories,$NEWLINE$Sought to entrap me by intelligence,$NEWLINE$Rated mine uncle from the council board,$NEWLINE$In rage dismissed my father from the court,$NEWLINE$Broke oath on oath, committed wrong on wrong,$NEWLINE$And in conclusion drove us to seek out$NEWLINE$This head of safety, and withal to pry$NEWLINE$Into his title, the which we find$NEWLINE$Too indirect for long continuance.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Then I’ll get to the point. A little while later, he overthrew King Richard. Soon after that, he killed him. And right after that, he raised taxes on everyone. To make matters worse, he allowed his kinsman Mortimer—who by rights ought to be the king—to be imprisoned in Wales, and remain there without ransom. He tried to use my victories to disgrace me, and tried to trap me with spies. He dismissed my uncle from his royal Council, threw my father out of the royal court, broke promise after promise, and committed crime after crime. In conclusion, he forced us to raise this army for our own safety, and to question his claim on the crown, which we believe is too flimsy to stand.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$Shall I return this answer to the King?
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$Should I bring this answer to the King?

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Not so, Sir Walter. We’ll withdraw awhile.$NEWLINE$Go to the King, and let there be impawned$NEWLINE$Some surety for a safe return again,$NEWLINE$And in the morning early shall my uncle$NEWLINE$Bring him our purposes. And so farewell.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$No, Sir Walter. We’ll stand down for a while. Go to the King. My uncle will bring him our demands early in the morning, provided that you arrange for a guarantee that he’ll be allowed to return safely. And so, farewell.

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$I would you would accept of grace and love.
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$I wish you would accept the King’s offer of kindness and love.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$And maybe so we shall.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Perhaps we will.

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$Pray God you do.
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$I pray to God you do.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the ARCHBISHOP of York and SIR MICHAEL$NEWLINE$ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$SIR MICHAEL
paragraphs.translated: The ARCHBISHOP of York and SIR MICHAEL enter.$NEWLINE$ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$SIR MICHAEL

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Hie, good Sir Michael, bear this sealèd brief$NEWLINE$With winged haste to the Lord Marshal,$NEWLINE$This to my cousin Scroop, and all the rest$NEWLINE$To whom they are directed. If you knew$NEWLINE$How much they do import, you would make haste.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Hurry, Sir Michael, bring this sealed letter as fast as you can to the Lord Marshal. Bring this one to Scroop, and all the rest to whom they are addressed. If you knew how important they were, you would hurry.

paragraphs.original: SIR MICHAEL$NEWLINE$My good lord, I guess their tenor.
paragraphs.translated: SIR MICHAEL$NEWLINE$My good lord, I can guess what they say.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Like enough you do.$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, good Sir Michael, is a day$NEWLINE$Wherein the fortune of ten thousand men$NEWLINE$Must bide the touch. For, sir, at Shrewsbury,$NEWLINE$As I am truly given to understand,$NEWLINE$The King with mighty and quick-raisèd power$NEWLINE$Meets with Lord Harry. And I fear, Sir Michael,$NEWLINE$What with the sickness of Northumberland,$NEWLINE$Whose power was in the first proportion,$NEWLINE$And what with Owen Glendower’s absence thence,$NEWLINE$Who with them was a rated sinew too$NEWLINE$And comes not in, o'er-ruled by prophecies,$NEWLINE$I fear the power of Percy is too weak$NEWLINE$To wage an instant trial with the King.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$I’m sure you can. Tomorrow, Sir Michael, ten thousand men will try their luck. I’m told that at Shrewsbury, the King—with a huge and quickly assembled army—will fight Harry Percy. I’m afraid, Michael, that without Northumberland, whose army was the largest of all, and without Owen Glendower, who was also being counted on but is absent because his horoscope told him to stay away, I’m afraid that Percy’s army will be too weak to fight the King right now.

paragraphs.original: SIR MICHAEL$NEWLINE$Why, my good lord, you need not fear.$NEWLINE$There is Douglas and Lord Mortimer.
paragraphs.translated: SIR MICHAEL$NEWLINE$Don’t worry, sir. Douglas and Mortimer are there.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$No, Mortimer is not there.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$No, Mortimer isn’t there.

paragraphs.original: SIR MICHAEL$NEWLINE$But there is Mordake, Vernon, Lord Harry Percy,$NEWLINE$And there is my Lord of Worcester and a head$NEWLINE$Of gallant warriors, noble gentlemen.
paragraphs.translated: SIR MICHAEL$NEWLINE$But Mordake is there, and Vernon, and Harry Percy, and Worcester and a slew of brave warriors and excellent men.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$And so there is. But yet the King hath drawn$NEWLINE$The special head of all the land together:$NEWLINE$The Prince of Wales, Lord John of Lancaster,$NEWLINE$The noble Westmoreland, and warlike Blunt,$NEWLINE$And many more corrivals and dear men$NEWLINE$Of estimation and command in arms.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$That’s correct. But the King has pulled together the best men in the country: the Prince of Wales, Lord John of Lancaster, the noble Westmoreland, warlike Blunt, and many other acquaintances and valuable men of good reputation, with great skill in battle.

paragraphs.original: SIR MICHAEL$NEWLINE$Doubt not, my lord, they shall be well opposed.
paragraphs.translated: SIR MICHAEL$NEWLINE$No doubt they will face great opposition.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$I hope no less, yet needful ’tis to fear;$NEWLINE$And to prevent the worst, Sir Michael, speed.$NEWLINE$For if Lord Percy thrive not, ere the King$NEWLINE$Dismiss his power, he means to visit us,$NEWLINE$For he hath heard of our confederacy,$NEWLINE$And ’tis but wisdom to make strong against him:$NEWLINE$Therefore make haste. I must go write again$NEWLINE$To other friends. And so farewell, Sir Michael.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$I hope so, but still I’m afraid. Now hurry, Sir Michael, to prevent an absolute disaster. For if Percy doesn’t prevail, the King will come after us before he disbands his army. He’s heard that we’re part of the rebellion, so we’d be wise to prepare against him. Now hurry. I have to go write to more friends. Farewell, Sir Michael.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the KING, PRINCE HENRY of Wales, Lord John of LANCASTER, Earl of WESTMORELAND, BLUNT, and FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: The KING, PRINCE HENRY of Wales, Lord John of LANCASTER, Earl of WESTMORELAND, Sir Walter BLUNT, and FALSTAFF enter.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$How bloodily the sun begins to peer$NEWLINE$Above yon busky hill. The day looks pale$NEWLINE$At his distemp'rature.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$How bloody the sun looks as it peers over that massive hill. The day looks pale—it must be sick to see the sun in such a mood.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$The southern wind$NEWLINE$Doth play the trumpet to his purposes,$NEWLINE$And by his hollow whistling in the leaves$NEWLINE$Foretells a tempest and a blust'ring day.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$The southern wind is playing its trumpet, to announce to the world what the sun means. And judging by the whistling leaves, it’s going to be a stormy, windy day.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Then with the losers let it sympathize,$NEWLINE$For nothing can seem foul to those that win.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Then let it take the losers' side. To winners, nothing seems unpleasant.

paragraphs.original: The trumpet sounds. Enter WORCESTER and VERNON$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$VERNON
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet sounds. WORCESTER and VERNON enter.$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$VERNON

paragraphs.original: How now, my Lord of Worcester? 'Tis not well$NEWLINE$That you and I should meet upon such terms$NEWLINE$As now we meet. You have deceived our trust$NEWLINE$And made us doff our easy robes of peace$NEWLINE$To crush our old limbs in ungentle steel.$NEWLINE$This is not well, my lord; this is not well.$NEWLINE$What say you to it? Will you again unknit$NEWLINE$This curlish knot of all-abhorrèd war$NEWLINE$And move in that obedient orb again$NEWLINE$Where you did give a fair and natural light,$NEWLINE$And be no more an exhaled meteor,$NEWLINE$A prodigy of fear and a portent$NEWLINE$Of broachèd mischief to the unborn times?
paragraphs.translated: Hello there, my lord of Worcester! It isn’t right that you and I are meeting under these circumstances. You have betrayed my trust. You forced me to put aside my comfortable peacetime clothing and instead have made me crush my old body into hard, military armor. That isn’t right, sir, that isn’t right. What do you have to say about it? Will you untie this ill-tempered knot of hateful war? Will you return to my loyalty? When you circled me, your King, in your obedient orbit, you shone beautifully and naturally. Now you blaze like a comet: a fearful omen, and a signal that evil will be released into the future.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Hear me, my liege:$NEWLINE$For mine own part I could be well content$NEWLINE$To entertain the lag end of my life$NEWLINE$With quiet hours. For I do protest$NEWLINE$I have not sought the day of this dislike.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Listen, my lord. For me, I would love nothing more than to spend my old age in peace and quiet. I protest: I did not seek out this day of aggression.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$You have not sought it. How comes it then?
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$You did not seek it? Then how did it come here?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Rebellion lay in his way, and he found it.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Rebellion was standing in front of him, and he bumped into it.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Peace, chewet, peace.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Quiet, you chatterer, quiet!

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$(to the KING) It pleased your Majesty to turn your looks$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Of favour from myself and all our house;$NEWLINE$And yet I must remember you, my lord,$NEWLINE$We were the first and dearest of your friends.$NEWLINE$For you my staff of office did I break$NEWLINE$In Richard’s time, and posted day and night$NEWLINE$To meet you on the way, and kiss your hand$NEWLINE$When yet you were in place and in account$NEWLINE$Nothing so strong and fortunate as I.$NEWLINE$It was myself, my brother, and his son$NEWLINE$That brought you home and boldly did outdare$NEWLINE$The dangers of the time. You swore to us,$NEWLINE$And you did swear that oath at Doncaster,$NEWLINE$That you did nothing purpose 'gainst the state,$NEWLINE$Nor claim no further than your new-fall'n right,$NEWLINE$The seat of Gaunt, dukedom of Lancaster.$NEWLINE$To this we swore our aid. But in short space$NEWLINE$It rained down fortune show'ring on your head,$NEWLINE$And such a flood of greatness fell on you—$NEWLINE$What with our help, what with the absent King,$NEWLINE$What with the injuries of a wanton time,$NEWLINE$The seeming sufferances that you had borne,
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$(to the KING) Your Highness chose to turn your back on me and my family. I must remind you, sir, that we were your first and dearest friends. For you, I quit my position under Richard, and ran day and night to meet you on the road and kiss your hand. At that time, you were far less powerful than I was. But my brother, his son, and I brought you home and ignored the danger. At Doncaster you swore an oath to us that you were not going to challenge the King; all you wanted was your late father’s estate, the dukedom of Lancaster, and in this we promised to help you.$NEWLINE$(to the$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$But soon, good luck began to pour on you like rain, and a flood of greatness fell upon you. You had a swarm of advantages: you had our assistance; and the King had been away so long; and the country was suffering under violence; and you seemed to have been so grievously wronged; and difficult winds were keeping

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And the contrarious winds that held the King$NEWLINE$So long in his unlucky Irish wars$NEWLINE$That all in England did repute him dead—$NEWLINE$And from this swarm of fair advantages$NEWLINE$You took occasion to be quickly wooed$NEWLINE$To gripe the general sway into your hand,$NEWLINE$Forget your oath to us at Doncaster;$NEWLINE$And being fed by us, you used us so$NEWLINE$As that ungentle gull, the cuckoo’s bird,$NEWLINE$Useth the sparrow—did oppress our nest,$NEWLINE$Grew by our feeding to so great a bulk$NEWLINE$That even our love durst not come near your sight$NEWLINE$For fear of swallowing; but with nimble wing$NEWLINE$We were enforced for safety sake to fly$NEWLINE$Out of sight and raise this present head,$NEWLINE$Whereby we stand opposèd by such means$NEWLINE$As you yourself have forged against yourself$NEWLINE$By unkind usage, dangerous countenance,$NEWLINE$And violation of all faith and troth$NEWLINE$Sworn to us in your younger enterprise.
paragraphs.translated: Richard so long in those unlucky Irish wars, people thought he was dead. You seized the opportunity, and used the general feeling to your advantage. You forgot the oath you swore to us at Doncaster.$NEWLINE$We nourished you, but you used us, like the cuckoo bird uses the sparrow: you settled in our nest, ate our food, and as you grew, you crowded us out. We loved you, but we couldn’t even come near you, for fear that you’d swallow us up. For our own safety, we were forced to run away and secretly raise this army. And now we stand with it, armed with powers that you yourself have caused to stand against you. You treated us poorly, you looked at us with anger, and you broke the faith and trust you swore to us when you were younger.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$These things indeed you have articulate,$NEWLINE$Proclaimed at market crosses, read in churches,$NEWLINE$To face the garment of rebellion$NEWLINE$With some fine color that may please the eye$NEWLINE$Of fickle changelings and poor discontents,$NEWLINE$Which gape and rub the elbow at the news$NEWLINE$Of hurlyburly innovation.$NEWLINE$And never yet did insurrection want$NEWLINE$Such water colors to impaint his cause,$NEWLINE$Nor moody beggars starving for a time$NEWLINE$Of pellmell havoc and confusion.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$You’ve said all this already. You’ve announced it in marketplaces, given sermons on it in churches. You’ve tried to make rebellion look pleasant in the eyes of all the fickle turncoats and poor malcontents, who laugh and clap eagerly at the news that a revolution is coming. But rebellion always trades in these kinds of thin excuses, and never lacks angry beggars, desperate for mayhem and chaos.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$In both your armies there is many a soul$NEWLINE$Shall pay full dearly for this encounter$NEWLINE$If once they join in trial. Tell your nephew,
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Both our armies are full of men who will make the ultimate sacrifice in this battle, once it starts. Tell your nephew that the Prince of Wales joins the whole world

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The Prince of Wales doth join with all the world$NEWLINE$In praise of Henry Percy. By my hopes,$NEWLINE$This present enterprise set off his head,$NEWLINE$I do not think a braver gentleman,$NEWLINE$More active-valiant, or more valiant-young,$NEWLINE$More daring or more bold, is now alive$NEWLINE$To grace this latter age with noble deeds.$NEWLINE$For my part, I may speak it to my shame,$NEWLINE$I have a truant been to chivalry,$NEWLINE$And so I hear he doth account me too.$NEWLINE$Yet this before my father’s majesty:$NEWLINE$I am content that he shall take the odds$NEWLINE$Of his great name and estimation,$NEWLINE$And will, to save the blood on either side,$NEWLINE$Try fortune with him in a single fight.
paragraphs.translated: in praising Henry Percy. Except for his current endeavor, I don’t think there’s a man alive who is braver, more heroic, more daring, or more bold.$NEWLINE$As for me, I’m ashamed to admit that I’ve shirked my responsibilities. I hear that he agrees with me on that point. And yet—and I say this in front of my father—in order to avoid casualties on both sides, I want to challenge him in hand-to-hand combat. And I’m content to admit that, based on his good name and reputation, he’s the favorite to win.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$And, Prince of Wales, so dare we venture thee,$NEWLINE$Albeit considerations infinite$NEWLINE$Do make against it.—No, good Worcester, no,$NEWLINE$We love our people well, even those we love$NEWLINE$That are misled upon your cousin’s part.$NEWLINE$And, will they take the offer of our grace,$NEWLINE$Both he and they and you, yea, every man$NEWLINE$Shall be my friend again, and I’ll be his.$NEWLINE$So tell your cousin, and bring me word$NEWLINE$What he will do. But if he will not yield,$NEWLINE$Rebuke and dread correction wait on us,$NEWLINE$And they shall do their office. So begone.$NEWLINE$We will not now be troubled with reply.$NEWLINE$We offer fair. Take it advisedly.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Prince of Wales, I’d support that idea, except that there are countless reasons why I shouldn’t. No, Worcester, no. I love my subjects, even those who have mistakenly followed your nephew’s lead. If they accept our pardon, then he, you, and they will all be my friends again, and I’ll be theirs. Tell your nephew this, and bring back his answer.$NEWLINE$But if he doesn’t surrender, he will be rebuked and harshly punished. So, be gone. I don’t want to hear anymore from you now. I offer a fair deal; I advise you to accept it.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt WORCESTER and VERNON$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$VERNON
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER and VERNON exit.$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$VERNON

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$It will not be accepted, on my life.$NEWLINE$The Douglas and the Hotspur both together$NEWLINE$Are confident against the world in arms.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$He won’t accept. I’ll bet my life on it. Douglas and Hotspur are convinced that they could take on the whole world together.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Hence, therefore, every leader to his charge,$NEWLINE$For on their answer will we set on them,$NEWLINE$And God befriend us as our cause is just.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Then everyone get to their battalions. As soon as they respond, we’ll attack. May God be with us. Our cause is just!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but PRINCE HENRY and FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except PRINCE HENRY and FALSTAFF.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hal, if thou see me down in the battle and bestride me, so;$NEWLINE$’tis a point of friendship.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Hal, if you see me fall in battle, stand over me, like this. It would be an act of friendship.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Nothing but a colossus can do thee that friendship.$NEWLINE$Say thy prayers, and farewell.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Only a giant could do you that friendship. Say your prayers, and farewell.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I would ’twere bedtime, Hal, and all well.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I wish it were bedtime, Hal, and everything were okay.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, thou owest God a death.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$But you owe God a death.

paragraphs.original: Exit PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY exits.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$'Tis not due yet. I would be loath to pay Him before His day. What need I be so forward with Him that calls not on me? Well, ’tis no matter. Honour pricks me on. Yea, but how if honor prick me off when I come on? How then? Can honor set to a leg? no. Or an arm? no. Or take away the grief of a wound? No. Honor hath no skill in surgery, then? No. What is honor? A word. What is in that word “honor”? What is that “honor”? Air. A trim reckoning. Who hath it? He that died o' Wednesday. Doth he feel it? No. Doth he hear it? No. 'Tis insensible, then? Yea, to the dead. But will it not live with the living? No. Why? Detraction will not suffer it. Therefore, I’ll none of it. Honor is a mere scutcheon. And so ends my catechism.
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$It’s not due yet. I’d hate to pay him before the due date. Why should I be so eager to pay him before he even asks for it? Well, it doesn’t matter: honor spurs me on. Yeah, but what if honor spurs me off once I’m on, and picks me out to die? What happens then? Can honor set a broken leg? No. Or an arm? No. Can it make a wound stop hurting? No. Honor can’t perform surgery, then? No. What is honor? A word. What is in that word, “honor?” What is that “honor?” Air. Quite a bargain! Who has it? A guy who died last Wednesday. Does he feel it? No. Does he hear it? No. It can’t be detected, then? Right—not by the dead, anyway. But won’t it live with the living? No. Why? Slander won’t allow it. That’s why I don’t want any part of it. Honor is nothing more than a gravestone, and that concludes my
catechism.$NEWLINE$catechism$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter WORCESTER and Sir Richard VERNON$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$VERNON
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER and Sir Richard VERNON enter.$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$VERNON

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$O no, my nephew must not know, Sir Richard,$NEWLINE$The liberal and kind offer of the King.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Oh no, Sir Richard, my nephew cannot be told about the generous and kind offer the King made.

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$'Twere best he did.
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$But he should be told.
