paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$Then are we all undone.$NEWLINE$It is not possible, it cannot be$NEWLINE$The King should keep his word in loving us.$NEWLINE$He will suspect us still and find a time$NEWLINE$To punish this offense in other faults.$NEWLINE$Suspicion all our lives shall be stuck full of eyes,$NEWLINE$For treason is but trusted like the fox,$NEWLINE$Who, never so tame, so cherished and locked up,$NEWLINE$Will have a wild trick of his ancestors.$NEWLINE$Look how we can, or sad or merrily,$NEWLINE$Interpretation will misquote our looks,$NEWLINE$And we shall feed like oxen at a stall,$NEWLINE$The better cherished still the nearer death.$NEWLINE$My nephew’s trespass may be well forgot;$NEWLINE$It hath the excuse of youth and heat of blood,$NEWLINE$And an adopted name of privilege—$NEWLINE$A hairbrained Hotspur governed by a spleen:$NEWLINE$All his offenses live upon my head$NEWLINE$And on his father’s. We did train him on,$NEWLINE$And, his corruption being ta'en from us,$NEWLINE$We as the spring of all shall pay for all.$NEWLINE$Therefore, good cousin, let not Harry know$NEWLINE$In any case the offer of the King.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$It will be the end of all of us! There is absolutely no way that the King will keep his word and trust us again. He will always be wary of us. He’ll find other reasons to punish us for this rebellion. For the rest of our lives he and his loyalists will look on us with suspicion. Treason is like a fox: you can tame it, care for it, and put it in a cage, but it will always have the wild instincts it inherited from its ancestors. No matter how we look—sad or happy—people will interpret our looks in the worst possible light. We’ll be like oxen in a stall: the better they’re fed, the closer they are to being slaughtered.$NEWLINE$My nephew’s disloyalty might be forgiven: his young age and hot temper will excuse it. Plus, his nickname gives him permission: Hotspur the Harebrain, always flaring up. All his offenses will be blamed on me and his father. After all, we encouraged him, and since we taught him to be angry at the King, we’ll pay for it. So cousin, don’t by any means let Harry know what the King offered.

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$Deliver what you will; I’ll say ’tis so.
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$Tell him what you want, and I’ll back you up.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter HOTSPUR and DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR and DOUGLAS enter.$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS

paragraphs.original: Here comes your cousin.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes your nephew.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$My uncle is returned.$NEWLINE$Deliver up my Lord of Westmoreland.—$NEWLINE$Uncle, what news?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$My uncle’s back. Free Westmoreland, his hostage. Uncle, what’s happening?

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$The King will bid you battle presently.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$The King will beckon you to battle shortly.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Defy him by the Lord of Westmoreland.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Have Westmoreland deliver your message of defiance.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Lord Douglas, go you and tell him so.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Douglas, go tell him to do that.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Marry, and shall, and very willingly.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Indeed, I will, and gladly.

paragraphs.original: Exit DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS exits.$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$There is no seeming mercy in the King.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$The King doesn’t appear willing to forgive us.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Did you beg any? God forbid!
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Did you ask him to? God forbid!

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$I told him gently of our grievances,$NEWLINE$Of his oath-breaking, which he mended thus$NEWLINE$By now forswearing that he is forsworn.$NEWLINE$He calls us “rebels,” “traitors,” and will scourge$NEWLINE$With haughty arms this hateful name in us.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$I politely told him what our issues were. I accused him of breaking his promise to us, and here’s how he answered: he lied about the fact that he lied. He called us rebels, traitors, and said he’d punish us with his mighty army.

paragraphs.original: Enter DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS enters.$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Arm, gentlemen, to arms. For I have thrown$NEWLINE$A brave defiance in King Henry’s teeth,$NEWLINE$And Westmoreland, that was engaged, did bear it,$NEWLINE$Which cannot choose but bring him quickly on.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Get your weapons, gentlemen, get your weapons! I sent King Henry a brave and defiant message, and Westmoreland, who was our hostage, will deliver it. This will surely bring the battle on immediately.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$The Prince of Wales stepped forth before the King,$NEWLINE$And, nephew, challenged you to single fight.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$The Prince of Wales stepped forward, nephew, and challenged you to a one-on-one fight.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$O, would the quarrel lay upon our heads,$NEWLINE$And that no man might draw short breath today$NEWLINE$But I and Harry Monmouth! Tell me, tell me,$NEWLINE$How showed his tasking? Seemed it in contempt?
paragraphs.translated:
HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Oh, I wish the whole battle were between us, and that the only people who would lose their breath today would be me and Harry
Monmouth! Tell me, tell me, what was the tone of his challenge? Did he show contempt for me?$NEWLINE$Monmouth!$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: VERNON$NEWLINE$No, by my soul. I never in my life$NEWLINE$Did hear a challenge urged more modestly,$NEWLINE$Unless a brother should a brother dare$NEWLINE$To gentle exercise and proof of arms.$NEWLINE$He gave you all the duties of a man,$NEWLINE$Trimmed up your praises with a princely tongue,$NEWLINE$Spoke your deservings like a chronicle,$NEWLINE$Making you ever better than his praise$NEWLINE$By still dispraising praise valued in you,$NEWLINE$And, which became him like a prince indeed,$NEWLINE$He made a blushing cital of himself,$NEWLINE$And chid his truant youth with such a grace$NEWLINE$As if he mastered there a double spirit$NEWLINE$Of teaching and of learning instantly.$NEWLINE$There did he pause: but let me tell the world:$NEWLINE$If he outlive the envy of this day,$NEWLINE$England did never owe so sweet a hope,$NEWLINE$So much misconstrued in his wantonness.
paragraphs.translated: VERNON$NEWLINE$No, I swear; I never heard a challenge issued more gracefully. It was like a brother asking a brother to a little friendly competition. He paid you all due respect, and he summed up your good qualities in the most princely language. He spoke of how deserving you are, as though he were your biographer. He claimed you were even above praise, for simple praise could never measure up to your true merits. And he gave a modest account of himself, as well, which made him seem like a true prince indeed. He berated himself for having behaved wildly, but he said this so gracefully that he sounded like a teacher giving a lesson and a student learning one at the same time. There he stopped, but let me say this: if he survives this battle, then England never had a sweeter hope, nor one so misunderstood in his recklessness.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Cousin, I think thou art enamorèd$NEWLINE$On his follies. Never did I hear$NEWLINE$Of any Prince so wild a liberty.$NEWLINE$But be he as he will, yet once ere night$NEWLINE$I will embrace him with a soldier’s arm,$NEWLINE$That he shall shrink under my courtesy.—$NEWLINE$Arm, arm with speed, and, fellows, soldiers, friends,$NEWLINE$Better consider what you have to do$NEWLINE$Than I that have not well the gift of tongue$NEWLINE$Can lift your blood up with persuasion.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I think you’ve been charmed by his foolishness. I’ve never heard of a Prince who was so wild and loose. But however he wants to seem, before night falls I will embrace him with these soldier’s arms, and he will tremble at my affection.$NEWLINE$Get ready, get ready quickly! And friends, partners, soldiers, take a moment to think for yourselves about what you have to do. I’m not a good enough speaker to motivate you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My lord, here are letters for you.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My lord, I have some letters for you.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I cannot read them now.—$NEWLINE$O gentlemen, the time of life is short;$NEWLINE$To spend that shortness basely were too long$NEWLINE$If life did ride upon a dial’s point,$NEWLINE$Still ending at the arrival of an hour.$NEWLINE$An if we live, we live to tread on kings;$NEWLINE$If die, brave death, when princes die with us.$NEWLINE$Now, for our consciences, the arms are fair$NEWLINE$When the intent of bearing them is just.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I can’t read them now. Oh, gentlemen, life is short. But if you spend that brief time shamefully, you are wasting your time: even if life lasted only an hour, it would still be too long. If we live, it will be in triumph over kings. If we die, it will be a glorious death, since princes will die with us. As for our consciences, our battle is fair: it’s right to bear arms when the cause is just.

paragraphs.original: Enter another MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: Another MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My lord, prepare. The King comes on apace.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My lord, get ready. The King has launched his attack.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I thank him that he cuts me from my tale,$NEWLINE$For I profess not talking. Only this:$NEWLINE$Let each man do his best. And here draw I a sword,$NEWLINE$Whose temper I intend to stain$NEWLINE$With the best blood that I can meet withal$NEWLINE$In the adventure of this perilous day.$NEWLINE$Now, Esperance! Percy! And set on.$NEWLINE$Sound all the lofty instruments of war,$NEWLINE$And by that music let us all embrace,$NEWLINE$For, heaven to earth, some of us never shall$NEWLINE$A second time do such a courtesy.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I thank him for cutting off my speech, since I have no talent for speaking. Only one more thing: each man should do his best, and with that I will draw my sword. On this dangerous day, I intend to stain it with the best blood I can find. “Hope is my comfort!” Percy! Let’s go! Sound all the imposing instruments of battle, and let’s embrace one another to the tune of that music. For, by heaven, some of us will never be able to do that again.

paragraphs.original: Here they embrace. The trumpets sound.
paragraphs.translated: They embrace. The trumpets sound.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The KING enters with his power and they cross the stage. Alarum to the battle.$NEWLINE$KING
paragraphs.translated: The KING crosses the stage with his army. The trumpets sound the call to battle.$NEWLINE$KING

paragraphs.original: Then enter DOUGLAS and Sir Walter BLUNT, disguised as the KING$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$KING
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS and Sir Walter BLUNT enter. BLUNT is disguised as the KING$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$KING

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$What is thy name that in the battle thus$NEWLINE$Thou crossest me? What honor dost thou seek$NEWLINE$Upon my head?
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$What is your name—you, who are attacking me like this? What honor do you think you’ll get by fighting me?

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Know then, my name is Douglas,$NEWLINE$And I do haunt thee in the battle thus$NEWLINE$Because some tell me that thou art a king.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$My name is Douglas, and I’m haunting you in this battle because they tell me you are a king.

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$They tell thee true.
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$They tell you the truth.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$The Lord of Stafford dear today hath bought$NEWLINE$Thy likeness, for instead of thee, King Harry,$NEWLINE$This sword hath ended him. So shall it thee,$NEWLINE$Unless thou yield thee as my prisoner.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Today, Lord Stafford paid for resembling you so well, for instead of you, King Harry, my sword killed him. Now it will kill you, unless you surrender as my prisoner.

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$I was not born a yielder, thou proud Scot,$NEWLINE$And thou shalt find a king that will revenge$NEWLINE$Lord Stafford’s death.
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$I was not born to surrender, you arrogant Scotsman. You’re about to see a king take revenge for Stafford’s death.

paragraphs.original: They fight. DOUGLAS kills BLUNT. Enter HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR
paragraphs.translated: They fight. DOUGLAS kills BLUNT. HOTSPUR enters.$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$O Douglas, hadst thou fought at Holmedon thus,$NEWLINE$I never had triumphed upon a Scot.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Oh, Douglas! If you’d fought like this at Holmedon, I would never have been able to beat you.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$All’s done, all’s won; here breathless lies the King.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$It’s over, we’ve won: here’s the King, dead.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Where?
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Where?

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Here.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Here.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$This, Douglas? No, I know this face full well.$NEWLINE$A gallant knight he was; his name was Blunt,$NEWLINE$Semblably furnished like the King himself.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$This, Douglas? No. I know this man: he was a brave knight, by the name of Blunt; he is disguised as the King.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$(to BLUNT) A fool go with thy soul whither it goes!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$A borrowed title hast thou bought too dear.$NEWLINE$Why didst thou tell me that thou wert a king?
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$(to BLUNT) Wherever your soul is off to now, let it carry the name of fool! You paid too much for that borrowed title. Why did you tell me you were a king?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$The King hath many marching in his coats.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$The King has many men on the battlefield disguised in his uniform.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Now, by my sword, I will kill all his coats.$NEWLINE$I’ll murder all his wardrobe, piece by piece,$NEWLINE$Until I meet the King.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Now, I swear on my sword, I’ll kill all his uniforms! I’ll murder every item of his clothing, one piece at a time, until I find the King himself.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Up and away!$NEWLINE$Our soldiers stand full fairly for the day.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Get going! Our side looks like it will win today.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Enter FALSTAFF alone.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: The trumpets play a call to arms.FALSTAFF enters, alone.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Though I could ’scape shot-free at London, I fear the shot here. Here’s no scoring but upon the pate.—Soft, who are you? Sir Walter Blunt. There’s honor for you. Here’s no vanity. I am as hot as molten lead, and as heavy too. God keep lead out of me; I need no more weight than mine own bowels. I have led my ragamuffins where they are peppered. There’s not three of my hundred and fifty left alive, and they are for the town’s end, to beg during life. But who comes here?
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I could always
escape shot-free in London, but I’m scared of getting shot out here. Here, you take it on the head. Wait a minute—who’s this? Sir Walter Blunt! There’s honor for you, but no vanity! I’m as hot as molten lead, and as heavy, too; so God keep the lead out of me. I don’t need any lead bullets in my belly—my own guts are heavy enough. My army of ragged bums has been massacred. Not even three of my hundred-fifty troops are still alive, and the ones who are have run away, to panhandle in the streets. Who’s coming?$NEWLINE$escape shot-free$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY enters.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What, stand’st thou idle here? Lend me thy sword.$NEWLINE$Many a nobleman lies stark and stiff$NEWLINE$Under the hoofs of vaunting enemies,$NEWLINE$Whose deaths are yet unrevenged. I prithee,$NEWLINE$Lend me thy sword.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What, are you standing here doing nothing? Give me your sword. Many good men are lying cold and dead on the ground, with the enemy’s horses galloping over them. Their deaths have not been revenged. Come, give me your sword.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$O Hal, I prithee, give me leave to breathe awhile. Turk Gregory never did such deeds in arms as I have done this day. I have paid Percy; I have made him sure.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Oh, Hal, please, give me a moment to catch my breath. No one has ever fought as heroically as I did today. I’ve killed Percy, I’ve made him safe.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$He is indeed, and living to kill thee.$NEWLINE$I prithee, lend me thy sword.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You’re right; he’s safe, and now he’s coming to kill you. Now please, give me your sword.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Nay, before God, Hal, if Percy be alive, thou gett’st not my sword; but take my pistol, if thou wilt.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No, Hal, I swear to God! If Percy’s alive, you’re not taking my sword. But you can have my gun, if you want.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Give it to me. What, is it in the case?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Give it to me. Is it in its holster?

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Ay, Hal, ’tis hot, ’tis hot. There’s that will sack a city. ( PRINCE$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$HENRY draws it out and finds it to be a bottle of sack)$NEWLINE$draws it out and finds it to be a bottle of sack)
paragraphs.translated:
FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Yup. It’s hot, hot; it could
sack a city. ( PRINCE HENRY opens the holster and finds a bottle of white wine)$NEWLINE$sack$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$opens the holster and finds a bottle of white wine)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$What, is it a time to jest and dally now?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Is this a time to joke and fool around?

paragraphs.original: He throws the bottle at him.
paragraphs.translated: He throws the bottle at FALSTAFF.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: Exit PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY exits.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well, if Percy be alive, I’ll pierce him. If he do come in my way, so; if he do not, if I come in his willingly, let him make a carbonado of me. I like not such grinning honor as Sir Walter hath. Give me life, which if I can save, so: if not, honor comes unlooked for, and there’s an end.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$If Percy’s alive, I’ll pierce him. If he runs into me, fine. If he doesn’t run into me, but I run into him, let him slice me like a butcher. I don’t want the kind of honor Sir Walter has: give me life. If I manage to save my life, fine. If not, I’ll have honor that I never looked for, and that’ll be that.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Excursions. Enter the KING, PRINCE HENRY, Lord John of LANCASTER, and the Earl of WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound battle calls. Soldiers skirmish. The KING, PRINCE HENRY, injured and bleeding, Lord John of LANCASTER, and WESTMORELAND enter.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$I prithee, Harry, withdraw thyself. Thou bleedest too much.$NEWLINE$Lord John of Lancaster, go you with him.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Please, Harry, get out of here: you’re bleeding too heavily. John of Lancaster, go with him.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Not I, my lord, unless I did bleed too.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$I won’t leave, my lord, unless I am bleeding too.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I beseech your Majesty, make up,$NEWLINE$Lest your retirement do amaze your friends.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I beg your highness, advance. Your army will lose heart if it sees you falling back.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$I will do so.—My Lord of Westmoreland,$NEWLINE$Lead him to his tent.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$I will. My Lord of Westmoreland, take him to his tent.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Come, my lord, I’ll lead you to your tent.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$(to PRINCE HENRY) Come, my lord. I’ll lead you to your tent.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Lead me, my lord? I do not need your help,$NEWLINE$And God forbid a shallow scratch should drive$NEWLINE$The Prince of Wales from such a field as this,$NEWLINE$Where stained nobility lies trodden on,$NEWLINE$And rebels' arms triumph in massacres.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Lead me, my lord? I don’t need your help. God forbid that a shallow scratch could make the Prince of Wales retreat from a battlefield like this one, where great men are falling and being trampled upon, and rebels are triumphing in their massacres!

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$We breathe too long. Come, cousin Westmoreland,$NEWLINE$Our duty this way lies. For God’s sake, come.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$We’ve stopped for too long. Come, Westmoreland. We have work to do. For God’s sake, come on!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt Lord John of LANCASTER and WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER and WESTMORELAND exit.$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$By God, thou hast deceived me, Lancaster.$NEWLINE$I did not think thee lord of such a spirit.$NEWLINE$Before, I loved thee as a brother, John,$NEWLINE$But now, I do respect thee as my soul.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$By God, you have deceived me, Lancaster. I didn’t think you were that brave. Before, I loved you as a brother; now, I respect you as my soulmate.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$I saw him hold Lord Percy at the point$NEWLINE$With lustier maintenance than I did look for$NEWLINE$Of such an ungrown warrior.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$He had Percy cornered, and he carried himself more bravely than I would have expected of such a young warrior.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$O, this boy lends mettle to us all.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Oh, this boy lends us all courage!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY exits.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: Enter DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS enters.$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Another king! they grow like Hydra’s heads.—$NEWLINE$I am the Douglas, fatal to all those$NEWLINE$That wear those colors on them. What art thou$NEWLINE$That counterfeit’st the person of a king?
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$Another king! The more of them we kill, the more of them spring up. I am Douglas, and I bring death to everyone wearing that uniform. Who are you, disguised as a king?

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$The King himself, who, Douglas, grieves at heart,$NEWLINE$So many of his shadows thou hast met$NEWLINE$And not the very king. I have two boys$NEWLINE$Seek Percy and thyself about the field,$NEWLINE$But, seeing thou fall’st on me so luckily,$NEWLINE$I will assay thee. And defend thyself.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$The King himself. And it pains me, Douglas, that you ran into so many of my shadows, and not me. I have two sons on the field, looking for Percy and for you. But, since you were lucky enough to come upon me, I’ll fight you myself. Defend yourself.

paragraphs.original: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$I fear thou art another counterfeit,$NEWLINE$And yet, in faith, thou bear’st thee like a king.$NEWLINE$But mine I am sure thou art, whoe'er thou be,$NEWLINE$And thus I win thee.
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$I fear that you’re another fake; and yet, you bear yourself like a king. Whoever you are, you’re mine, and I’ll defeat you.

paragraphs.original: They fight. The KING being in danger, enter PRINCE HENRY of Wales$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: They fight. The KING begins to lose. PRINCE HENRY of Wales enters.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Hold up thy head, vile Scot, or thou art like$NEWLINE$Never to hold it up again. The spirits$NEWLINE$Of valiant Shirley, Stafford, Blunt are in my arms.$NEWLINE$It is the Prince of Wales that threatens thee,$NEWLINE$Who never promiseth but he means to pay.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Look at me, you nasty Scotsman, or you’ll never look at anything again. I have the spirits of brave Shirley, Stafford, and Blunt in me. It is the Prince of Wales who threatens you, and I never make promises I cannot keep.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: They fight. DOUGLAS flieth$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS
paragraphs.translated: They fight.DOUGLAS runs away.$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS

paragraphs.original: Cheerly, my lord. How fares your Grace?$NEWLINE$Sir Nicholas Gawsey hath for succor sent,$NEWLINE$And so hath Clifton. I’ll to Clifton straight.
paragraphs.translated: Cheer up, father. How are you? Sir Nicholas Gawsey called for reinforcements, and so has Clifton. I’m going to Clifton right now.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Stay, and breathe awhile.$NEWLINE$Thou hast redeemed thy lost opinion$NEWLINE$And showed thou mak’st some tender of my life$NEWLINE$In this fair rescue thou hast brought to me.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Wait, and breathe for a moment. You have redeemed your bad reputation, and show that you care something for me, by rescuing me like this.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$O God, they did me too much injury$NEWLINE$That ever said I hearkened for your death.$NEWLINE$If it were so, I might have let alone$NEWLINE$The insulting hand of Douglas over you,$NEWLINE$Which would have been as speedy in your end$NEWLINE$As all the poisonous potions in the world,$NEWLINE$And saved the treacherous labor of your son.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Oh God! Anyone who ever said I wished for you to die did me a terrible wrong. If I wanted that, I would have let Douglas continue his attack. That would have killed you faster than any dose of poison, and it would have saved me the trouble of treachery.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Make up to Clifton. I’ll to Sir Nicholas Gawsey.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Go to Clifton; I’ll go to Sir Nicholas Gawsey.

paragraphs.original: Exit the KING$NEWLINE$KING
paragraphs.translated: The KING exits.$NEWLINE$KING

paragraphs.original: Enter HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR enters.$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$If I mistake not, thou art Harry Monmouth.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$If I’m not mistaken, you’re Harry Monmouth.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Thou speak’st as if I would deny my name.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$You make it sound as if I’d deny it.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$My name is Harry Percy.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$My name is Harry Percy.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, then I see$NEWLINE$A very valiant rebel of the name.$NEWLINE$I am the Prince of Wales; and think not, Percy,$NEWLINE$To share with me in glory any more.$NEWLINE$Two stars keep not their motion in one sphere,$NEWLINE$Nor can one England brook a double reign,$NEWLINE$Of Harry Percy and the Prince of Wales.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why then, I’m looking at a very brave rebel by that name. I am the Prince of Wales, and don’t think, Percy, that you can share in my glory any longer. There isn’t enough room for two stars in the same orbit; England cannot handle a double reign, Harry Percy and the Prince of Wales ruling at once.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Nor shall it, Harry, for the hour is come$NEWLINE$To end the one of us, and would to God$NEWLINE$Thy name in arms were now as great as mine.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$It won’t have to, Harry, for the time has come for one of us to die. I only wish that you had as great a reputation in warfare as I do.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I’ll make it greater ere I part from thee,$NEWLINE$And all the budding honors on thy crest$NEWLINE$I’ll crop, to make a garland for my head.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$My reputation will be greater by the time we part. I’ll take all the flowers of honor from your helmet, and turn them into a garland for myself.

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I can no longer brook thy vanities.
paragraphs.translated: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$I can’t stand your arrogance any longer.

paragraphs.original: They fight
paragraphs.translated: They fight.

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF enters.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well said, Hal! To it Hal! Nay, you shall find no boys' play here, I can tell you.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Well said, Hal! Go for it, Hal! This isn’t child’s play, I’ll tell you that much!

paragraphs.original: Enter DOUGLAS. He fighteth with FALSTAFF, who falls down as if he were ead.$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS returns and fights with FALSTAFF, who falls down and plays dead.$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: Exit DOUGLAS$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS
paragraphs.translated: DOUGLAS exits.$NEWLINE$DOUGLAS

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY killeth HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY kills HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$HOTSPUR

paragraphs.original: HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$O Harry, thou hast robbed me of my youth.$NEWLINE$I better brook the loss of brittle life$NEWLINE$Than those proud titles thou hast won of me.$NEWLINE$They wound my thoughts worse than thy sword my flesh.$NEWLINE$But thoughts, the slave of life, and life, time’s fool,$NEWLINE$And time, that takes survey of all the world,$NEWLINE$Must have a stop. O, I could prophesy,$NEWLINE$But that the earthy and cold hand of death$NEWLINE$Lies on my tongue. No, Percy, thou art dust,$NEWLINE$And food for— (he dies)$NEWLINE$(he dies)
paragraphs.translated:
HOTSPUR$NEWLINE$Oh, Harry, you’ve
taken away my youth. I can handle the loss of my fragile life, but not the loss of all the honors you have won from me: that loss wounds my thoughts more than your sword wounds my flesh. But thought depends on life, and life depends on time, and time, which watches over the whole world, must stop eventually. Oh, I could make prophecies, but the cold hand of death is stopping my tongue. No, Percy. You are dust, and food for—(he dies)$NEWLINE$taken away$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(he dies)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$For worms, brave Percy. Fare thee well, great heart.$NEWLINE$Ill-weaved ambition, how much art thou shrunk!$NEWLINE$When that this body did contain a spirit,$NEWLINE$A kingdom for it was too small a bound,$NEWLINE$But now two paces of the vilest earth$NEWLINE$Is room enough. This earth that bears thee dead$NEWLINE$Bears not alive so stout a gentleman.$NEWLINE$If thou wert sensible of courtesy,$NEWLINE$I should not make so dear a show of zeal.$NEWLINE$But let my favors hide thy mangled face;$NEWLINE$And even in thy behalf I’ll thank myself$NEWLINE$For doing these fair rites of tenderness.$NEWLINE$Adieu, and take thy praise with thee to heaven.$NEWLINE$Thy ignominy sleep with thee in the grave,$NEWLINE$But not remembered in thy epitaph.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$For worms, brave Percy. Farewell, brave soul. Your ambition, aimed at evil, ends—look at how withered it has become. When this body contained a soul, an entire kingdom was too small to hold it. But now, two paces of wretched earth is plenty of room. The ground that you lie dead upon doesn’t have a single living man upon it as brave as you. If you could hear me, I wouldn’t praise you so lavishly. But let me cover your battered face with part of my uniform. I’ll thank myself on your behalf for doing these rites of respect.$NEWLINE$Adieu, and take my praise of you to heaven. Let your disgraces sleep with you in the grave, and let them be kept off your tombstone!

paragraphs.original: He spieth FALSTAFF on the ground$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: He sees FALSTAFF lying on the ground.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: What, old acquaintance, could not all this flesh$NEWLINE$Keep in a little life? Poor Jack, farewell.$NEWLINE$I could have better spared a better man.$NEWLINE$O, I should have a heavy miss of thee$NEWLINE$If I were much in love with vanity.$NEWLINE$Death hath not struck so fat a deer today,$NEWLINE$Though many dearer in this bloody fray.$NEWLINE$Emboweled will I see thee by and by;$NEWLINE$Till then in blood by noble Percy lie.
paragraphs.translated: What? My old friend? Couldn’t all this flesh hold onto a little life? Poor Jack, farewell. I would rather have lost a more valuable soldier. If I were in love with vanity, I’d really miss you.$NEWLINE$Death hasn’t taken anyone as fat today, though it has taken many better men in this vicious battle. I’ll have you embowelled soon; till then, lie here in blood, by the great Percy.

paragraphs.original: Exit PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY exits.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF riseth up$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF stands up.$NEWLINE$FALSTAFF

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Emboweled? If thou embowel me today, I’ll give you leave to powder me and eat me too tomorrow. 'Sblood, ’twas time
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Embowelled? If you cut me open today, I’ll let you pickle me and eat me tomorrow. Damn! I had to fake

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: to counterfeit, or that hot termagant Scot had paid me scot and lot too. Counterfeit? I lie. I am no counterfeit. To die is to be a counterfeit, for he is but the counterfeit of a man who hath not the life of a man; but to counterfeit dying when a man thereby liveth is to be no counterfeit, but the true and perfect image of life indeed. The better part of valor is discretion, in the which better part I have saved my life. Zounds, I am afraid of this gunpowder Percy, though he be dead. How if he should counterfeit too and rise? By my faith, I am afraid he would prove the better counterfeit. Therefore I’ll make him sure, yea, and I’ll swear I killed him. Why may not he rise as well as I? Nothing confutes me but eyes, and nobody sees me. Therefore, sirrah, (stabs the body) with a new wound in your thigh, come you along with me. (he takes up HOTSPUR on his back)$NEWLINE$(stabs the body)$NEWLINE$(he takes up$NEWLINE$on his back)
paragraphs.translated: being dead, or that raging rebel of a Scotsman would have ended me. Fake? No, I tell a lie: I’m not a faker. To die is to be a faker, because a dead body is an imitation of a living one. But to fake being dead, in order to stay alive, that’s no kind of faking. That’s the truest kind of living there is. Bravery is mostly about precaution; I’m careful, and it saved my life. Damn, I’m scared of this bombshell Percy, even though he’s dead. What if he’s faking, too, and he gets up? I swear, he’d be the better faker. Therefore, I’ll make sure he’s dead; in fact, I’ll swear that I killed him. Why couldn’t he just get up, like I did? Only a witness could stop me, and there are no witnesses here. Therefore, sirrah, (stabs the body)you’re coming with me—complete with a new wound in your thigh. (he throws HOTSPUR’s body over his shoulder)$NEWLINE$(stabs the body)$NEWLINE$(he throws$NEWLINE$’s body over his shoulder)

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY and Lord John of LANCASTER$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$LANCASTER
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY and Lord John of LANCASTER enter.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$LANCASTER

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Come, brother John. Full bravely hast thou fleshed$NEWLINE$Thy maiden sword.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$John, my brother, you’ve bravely proven yourself in this, your first battle.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$But soft, whom have we here?$NEWLINE$Did you not tell me this fat man was dead?
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Wait! Who do we have here? Didn’t you say this fat man was dead?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I did; I saw him dead,$NEWLINE$Breathless and bleeding on the ground.—Art thou alive?$NEWLINE$Or is it fantasy that plays upon our eyesight?$NEWLINE$I prithee, speak. We will not trust our eyes$NEWLINE$Without our ears. Thou art not what thou seem’st.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$I did. I saw him dead on the ground, bleeding and not breathing. Are you alive? Or is this some kind of dream, playing with our sight? Talk to us. We won’t trust our eyes without our ears. You aren’t what you seem to be.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$No, that’s certain. I am not a double man. But if I be not Jack Falstaff, then am I a jack. There is Percy. If your father will do me any honor,so; if not, let him kill the next Percy himself. I look to be either earl or duke, I can assure you.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$That’s for sure. I’m not a double man. But if I’m not Jack Falstaff, then I’m a crook. Here’s Percy. If the king will honor me for this, fine. If not, let him kill the next Percy himself. I expect to me made an earl or a Duke for this, I’ll tell you that much.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, Percy I killed myself, and saw thee dead.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, I killed Percy myself and I saw you dead.

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$Didst thou? Lord, Lord, how this world is given to lying. I grant you, Iwas down and out of breath, and so was he, but we rose both at an instant and fought a long hour by Shrewsbury clock. If I may be believed, so; if not, let them that should reward valor bear the sin upon their own heads. I’ll take it upon my death, I gave him this wound in the thigh. If the man were alive and would deny it, zounds, I would make him eat a piece of my sword.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$You did? Lord, Lord, how people love to lie! I admit I had fallen and was out of breath, and so was he. But we both stood up at the same time and fought for a long hour. If I am to be believed, fine. If I’m not believed, then the guilt will lie with the people who are supposed to reward bravery. I swear on my life, I gave him this gash in the leg. Damn, if he were alive and said I didn’t, I’d shove my sword down his throat.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$This is the strangest tale that ever I heard.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$This is the strangest story I’ve ever heard.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$This is the strangest fellow, brother John.—$NEWLINE$Come, bring your luggage nobly on your back.$NEWLINE$For my part, if a lie may do thee grace,$NEWLINE$I’ll gild it with the happiest terms I have.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$This is the strangest man, John. All right then, display your prize on your back. As far as I’m concerned, if lying will help you out, I’ll decorate your lie as prettily as I can.

paragraphs.original: A retreat is sounded
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet blows a call of retreat.

paragraphs.original: The trumpet sounds retreat; the day is ours.$NEWLINE$Come, brother, let us to the highest of the field$NEWLINE$To see what friends are living, who are dead.
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet is blowing retreat: we’ve won. Come on, brother. Let’s get to high ground and see which of our friends are alive, and which are dead.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PRINCE HENRY and Lord John of LANCASTER$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$LANCASTER
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY and Lord John of LANCASTER exit.$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$LANCASTER

paragraphs.original: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’ll follow, as they say, for reward. He that rewards me, God reward him. If I do grow great, I’ll grow less, for I’ll purge and leave sack and live cleanly as a nobleman should do.
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF$NEWLINE$I’ll follow them and claim my reward. May God reward whoever rewards me. If I grow into a great man, I’ll grow thinner: I’ll go on a diet, quit drinking, and live properly, like a great man should.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The trumpets sound. Enter the KING, PRINCE HENRY, Lord John of LANCASTER, Earl of WESTMORELAND, with WORCESTER and VERNON prisoners$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$VERNON
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound. The KING, PRINCE HENRY, Lord John of LANCASTER, and WESTMORELAND enter, with WORCESTER and VERNON as prisoners.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$LANCASTER$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$VERNON

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Thus ever did rebellion find rebuke.—$NEWLINE$Ill-spirited Worcester, did not we send grace,$NEWLINE$Pardon, and terms of love to all of you?$NEWLINE$And wouldst thou turn our offers contrary,$NEWLINE$Misuse the tenor of thy kinsman’s trust?$NEWLINE$Three knights upon our party slain today,$NEWLINE$A noble earl, and many a creature else$NEWLINE$Had been alive this hour,$NEWLINE$If like a Christian thou hadst truly borne$NEWLINE$Betwixt our armies true intelligence.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$This is how rebellions always end—defeated. Evil-spirited Worcester! Didn’t I offer kindness, forgiveness and friendship to all of you? And you pretended that I did the opposite? Your relatives and friends trusted you, yet you lied to them? Three of our knights who were killed today, a noble earl, and many other men might have been alive right now if you had been a decent man and reported truthfully on the negotiations between our two armies.

paragraphs.original: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$What I have done my safety urged me to.$NEWLINE$And I embrace this fortune patiently,$NEWLINE$Since not to be avoided it falls on me.
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER$NEWLINE$I did what I had to do for the sake of my own well-being. I accept my fate patiently, since there’s no way I can avoid it.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Bear Worcester to the death, and Vernon too.$NEWLINE$Other offenders we will pause upon.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$Put Worcester to death, and Vernon too: I’ll wait a while before I decide what to do about the others.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt WORCESTER and VERNON under guard$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$VERNON
paragraphs.translated: WORCESTER and VERNON are escorted away by guards.$NEWLINE$WORCESTER$NEWLINE$VERNON

paragraphs.original: How goes the field?
paragraphs.translated: What’s happening on the battlefield?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$The noble Scot, Lord Douglas, when he saw$NEWLINE$The fortune of the day quite turned from him,$NEWLINE$The noble Percy slain, and all his men$NEWLINE$Upon the foot of fear, fled with the rest,$NEWLINE$And, falling from a hill, he was so bruised$NEWLINE$That the pursuers took him. At my tent$NEWLINE$The Douglas is, and I beseech your Grace$NEWLINE$I may dispose of him.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$When that brave Scotsman, Lord Douglas, saw that things were turning against him, that Percy had been killed, and that his men were fleeing in terror, he ran away too. He fell down a hill and was so badly injured that our men were able to capture him. He’s being held prisoner at my tent.$NEWLINE$I ask your highness to let me decide what to do with him.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$With all my heart.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$With all my heart.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Then, brother John of Lancaster, to you$NEWLINE$This honorable bounty shall belong.$NEWLINE$Go to the Douglas, and deliver him$NEWLINE$Up to his pleasure, ransomless and free.$NEWLINE$His valor shown upon our crests today$NEWLINE$Hath taught us how to cherish such high deeds,$NEWLINE$Even in the bosom of our adversaries.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY$NEWLINE$Brother, John of Lancaster, I’m going to give you the honor of this generous act. Go to Douglas and set him free, with no ransom due. Let him do whatever he wants. His brave fighting against us today should be valued, even though he was our enemy.

paragraphs.original: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$I thank your Grace for this high courtesy,$NEWLINE$Which I shall give away immediately.
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER$NEWLINE$Thank you for giving me this honor. I’ll take care of it immediately.

paragraphs.original: KING$NEWLINE$Then this remains, that we divide our power.$NEWLINE$You, son John, and my cousin Westmoreland,$NEWLINE$Towards York shall bend you with your dearest speed$NEWLINE$To meet Northumberland and the prelate Scroop,$NEWLINE$Who, as we hear, are busily in arms.$NEWLINE$Myself and you, son Harry, will towards Wales$NEWLINE$To fight with Glendower and the Earl of March.$NEWLINE$Rebellion in this land shall lose his sway,$NEWLINE$Meeting the check of such another day.$NEWLINE$And since this business so fair is done,$NEWLINE$Let us not leave till all our own be won.
paragraphs.translated: KING$NEWLINE$All that’s left is for us to split up our armies. You, my son John, and you, Westmoreland, head towards York as quickly as you can. Confront Northumberland and that churchman the Archbishop, who, I gather, are raising armies against us. You and I, Harry my son, will head for Wales to fight Glendower and Mortimer. The rebellion in this land will break apart once it meets battles like the one we fought today. And since we have accomplished our business so well, let’s not quit until everything has been won.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.
